He was understandably upset because he had already paid for the food though. I am NEVER ordering from here again.

2.description: So I got an email from Domino's pizza for 50% off promotion with online orders. I can only think one thing: cheat day, yay! I noticed you have to be careful with ordering fast food from major chains in the city. Seems like the level of accountability sinks. Since I had my coupon, I didn't care. I have ordered from this location in the past, and what I am talking about here is a lack of cheese. You go to any Domino's in the suburbs and there is an ample amount. I was already out, so I picked up my pizza. After getting yelled at by a delivery guy (not Domino's) for not tipping enough, I decided it was less stressful to just pick up the food. Plus I am not tipping a driver to deliver me an overpriced pizza. I'm not ruining my 50% off by having to tip either. Yeah I am stingy, but after such a sour past experience, I will never tip another delivery person. Whether I was tipping enough at the time or not.For $7 bucks I got extra cheese, pineapple, and bacon. I think I made the workers nervous because I got there so quickly that they felt like they had to rush with my order. I was happy because my pizza wasn't over cooked. When you don't eat a ton of fast food, you taste everything that's amazing about it. In this case, butter and garlic on the crust, the comforting creamy flavor of the cheese, salty chewy bacon, and sweet pineapple. It was heaven. Domino's had just opened and I'm pretty sure I was one of the first pizza orders of the day. I think this is also why my pizza tasted so fresh, textured (crispy/soft crust), and full of flavor dimensions. The staff was polite for all of the three minutes I had to wait for my pizza. Great job, guys! I'd just change the way you add your cheese. I think the "extra cheese" option should be the standard.

18.description: This place was so bad! I used to be a regular but after so many bad experiences with customer service i gatta say im done they also forget things and under cook their food

13.description: I got there at 11:20 and this store close at 12. I asked to make order but he said get off my store cuz i come on this time

4.description: not even one star nobody helped me open the door and my pizza fell !!!!! Not Even gentlemen they are a**holes they even laughed

24.description: Using a coupon, I ordered a pizza on line for pick up @ this Dominos. The buy one get one free pizza was $15.99. When I picked up this pizza, I noticed that the exact same pizza was really $12.99. When I asked why, the woman claimed innocence &  had nothing to do with the price of the pizza. So it's not buy one, get one free, it's really Buy one, get one for $3.00. That's really a piddly sum, but the concept is what really bothered me. I felt cheated, tricked, & grumbled all the way home. Domino's campaign is that they really listen to the feedback, & they got it when I returned home.  Now, if they respond, I'll post it.Meanwhile... the review of the pizza (thanks for your patience)The American Legends Pizza was very tasty. Toppings were generous, and crust was acceptable (Her Majesty has spoil't me w/ her home made pizzas, but she didn't have the time on this day). With tax, it was $17, & what I came home with was not a $17 pizza. I did however come home with 2 pizzas because of the coupon, & for $17, 2 of those pizzas is a terrific value. If you go by the regular price of $13, you will get a good pizza, at a fair price.

6.description: I ordered online and it arrived in 20 mins!  It was still hot.  The delivery guy was polite and chill.   Awesome pizza.

22.description: I work in the area and after giving them more tries than I should have, I give up. The food never gets here hot, the service is rude, and I was told that maybe if I tipped better they would provide better service. I called the corporate office and have yet to hear from them. I was also told that most of the staff does not speak English and that is why we have such a hard time placing and getting our orders. If and when I get a response, I will let you know. If they can make this right with me and my co-workers, I will repost the positive results, I hope.

15.description: Have a hard time giving them three stars but hey they have a decent online system, the pizza arrived on time and it tastes better than their old recipe.  I ordered out of desperation but I'll go back, what the hell.  I guess it's sacrosanct to order from these guys in a great pizza town, but then again I don't give a _____.  This isn't a first date place, more like I'm shit tired and need to eat but can't get up to do anything option.

7.description: EVERY time we order from this Domino's the thin crust pizza comes totally burnt all around the edges. I can deal with it - but the thin crust is for my children and they won't eat it that way.  For 5+ years we ordered from the one on Irving Park near our former home we NEVER had this problem once.  This location is poorly run and the management is rude and unwilling to work with customers.

8.description: Since we've moved into the area, we've ordered from this location a bunch of times. They've always been prompt and the food has always been hot. The last time, the pizza was still a little too hot to even bite into, it was so fresh from the oven! ^_^There's been only 2 times when a miscommunication had led to us being delivered the wrong pizza and we had to call back. But they've always been courteous and fast with coming back with the correct one.Love this place for a cheap meal on a lazy day. They always have great coupons and deals.

3.description: Horrible service and rude staff. This place need a complete revamp. Food is decent for the price but no one likes to be treated like a burdon!!!

14.description: Pizza is better than Pizza Hut on foster and Pulaski. Their deep dish is really good and they don't add so much sauce. Their sandwiches are not that great and the wings are over priced. I only recommend their pizza.

0.description: This place CLOSED a long time ago. One of many failed attempts to fill the shoes of the former business known as JangMoNim's where you can go at 3am for some quality Seoul food.

1.description: While studying late on a Sunday, I feared that my food delivery options were slim and fading fast....I was pleasantly surprised how quick delivery was, considering I'm about 5 (city) miles away. I was also very happy with the great fresh veggies in the pepper steak, and loved the very tasty fried pot stickers, which were a perfect compliment.

9.description: No reservations needed cause most of their business is take out! Order the Tom kha soup! It's the best in the city! Outstanding and clean and great music!

23.description: Note: As I'm writing this on 4/19/15, their website is not up yet - but they're working on it! For reference, this restaurant is next to Hoanh Long. It has street parking with meter; I'm not sure about neighborhood parking.This is more of a 3.75 star rating - if only that were possible!The restaurant is brand new and my family orders spicy (and A LOT)! So here goes...-Chicken satay: Cooked very well and at the right consistency-Calamari: Breaded lighter than in American restaurants, delicious!-Mee grob (or mee krob): Sweet and crunchy noodle appetizer that we love. The chef made it super crunchy and used a different sauce (maybe sweet and sour?) than we were used to, but it was an interesting take on the dish-Tom yum goong: We ordered this extra spicy and they seemed to add red peppers to up the spice instead of Thai peppers. The soup could've been made a bit sweeter too.-Som tam: Spicy and good as in other restaurants!-Basil fried rice: Maybe skip it for now, as it tasted like Chinese fried rice... give it a few months and maybe the chef will add more basil taste to it.-Red snapper with spicy basil sauce: Not sweet as we expected, but fish was fried deliciously and sauce was still pretty tasty - if you're the chef, please offer a sweet and spicy sauce too! We would love that!-Pad see eiw: Unfortunately, I only had one bite, but it was pretty good.For dessert, we had the fried ice cream. Not bad, but we probably won't order it again. (Too much batter and the ice cream could've been richer.)Final impressions:PROS: Server was very attentive (albeit a bit nervous from being new), restaurant has simple but elegant decor, fresh and high-quality food, unique spice-takes on dishes, inexpensive lunch deals ($7.99?), welcoming ambience for dates, families, etc., dishes were a decent size, pretty artistic with food designCONS: Spices for some dishes were different from what we were used to, difficult to spot when driving on LincolnFor sure, I'll go back to try the lunch specials and see how they do for dinner in about a month or so! I'm excited to see how this restaurant fares!

12.description: Had a nice lunch today.. started with Thai salad with ginger dressing. (part of $7.95 lunch special) followed with Bangkok spring rolls... super fresh and tasty.. had the tom kha soup with chicken.. fairly average could have used a little more heat.. the rest of the lunch special was a red curry with pork.. medium heat was perfect ..not overpowering. Portion was perfect if you had additional dishes.Service was attentive and prompt. Clean and well designed surroundings.Nice Thai iced coffee.Would recommend a stop if in the area.

21.description: Best spicy basil fried rice!! My husband & I have not had a bad dish here yet.  Pad ginger pepper steak nam tuck all delish!  Can't speak to the ambiance - we've never actually eaten in the restaurant but the takeout/delivery is delicious.  Definitely give this place a try!

16.description: Everyone has their favorite Thai place. This is my new fav and hidden gem on Lincoln next to another secret gem: Hoang Loanh. We ordered all the basics: spring rolls, pad Thai, pad see eww, curry fried rice with pineapple and chicken to compare to my other fav place. Each dish was the same as usual but elevated by the details and presentation. No giant portions here, quality over quantity. Gorgeous and delicious touches included: toasted sesame seeds on the tops of the spring roll bites...who ever made these used to make sushi bc the julienned carrots inside were perfectly arranged in the rice paper which was perfectly prepared ie not the chewy sloppy mess you get at most places...we asked for "crispy" on the pad see ewe...perfectly crispy noodles...they put fresh mint leaves on the plate with the sticky rice and mango! Love it! Best Thai food in Chicago with high attention to detail and obviously someone cooking who is a chef, not a cook! Hurry before the crowds come!

17.description: Best spicy basil fried rice!! My husband & I have not had a bad dish here yet.  Pad ginger pepper steak nam tuck all delish!  Can't speak to the ambiance - we've never actually eaten in the restaurant but the takeout/delivery is delicious.  Definitely give this place a try!

10.description: Loved the Fried Banana with Honey and Fried Banana with Green Tea ice cream desserts! We went there late at night 8:30-9pm. Even though we were the only table we enjoyed the warm atmosphere.  The dining room was very clean and the table settings looked elegant. We think some photos or artwork on the big dining wall would be a nice addition. The waitress who served us was very nice and new to the restaurant. The owner also greeted us and recommended some Thai dishes for us to try. We ordered a delicious papaya salad, chicken satay, and 3 entrees. The pad see yew with shrimp was wonderful (no leftovers to take home), The Massaman with chicken was very tender (loved the mild curry sauce). I saved the leftover sauce for my next meal (yummy)   The Basil Fried Rice with beef was delicious. The portion is slightly on the small size for 4 people.  I wish they provide a choice of large and small sizes to order from. Their drinks are good but small. The bill was very reasonable, considering that we ordered appetizers, entrees, desserts and drinks for four adults.

5.description: So far, I've been here a couple of times, but I'm not sure if I want to dine here again.The first time we went, I went with a group of 6 friends and had very attentive service. There was 1 other table at the place with us for lunch. This last time we went, I went with a group of 5 friend and had HORRIBLE SERVICE. There were 2 other tables of 2 people and maybe 1-2 carry orders. There was no excuse really.It took at least 20 minutes for them to fill our water cups and the cups are smaller than most places. The restaurant is pretty open, so it's not like it is so difficult for them to glance at our tables. It then took like 25 minutes for us to get our check after asking for it! What the heck were they doing? I have no idea. I was pretty frustrated by the end of the meal. Don't get me wrong, they were very nice, but we were definitely neglected.Food:I've had the calamari with was very tasty with the spicy fish sauce. It was yummy, but not spectacular. It is fairly small.The chicken satay is pretty tasty. The chicken was juicy and the peanut sauce complimented the chicken very well.The crab fried rice was okay. It was good, but I've had better. There was not a lot of crab in the fried rice itself, but presentation counts. They shaped it like a cone!The pork pad sie ew was very good. Very sweet and savoury. It was a tad on the greasy side, but still good. Pretty standard pad sie ew.Parking is Chicago metered box parking on the street out front.

11.description: Note: As I'm writing this on 4/19/15, their website is not up yet - but they're working on it! For reference, this restaurant is next to Hoanh Long. It has street parking with meter; I'm not sure about neighborhood parking.This is more of a 3.75 star rating - if only that were possible!The restaurant is brand new and my family orders spicy (and A LOT)! So here goes...-Chicken satay: Cooked very well and at the right consistency-Calamari: Breaded lighter than in American restaurants, delicious!-Mee grob (or mee krob): Sweet and crunchy noodle appetizer that we love. The chef made it super crunchy and used a different sauce (maybe sweet and sour?) than we were used to, but it was an interesting take on the dish-Tom yum goong: We ordered this extra spicy and they seemed to add red peppers to up the spice instead of Thai peppers. The soup could've been made a bit sweeter too.-Som tam: Spicy and good as in other restaurants!-Basil fried rice: Maybe skip it for now, as it tasted like Chinese fried rice... give it a few months and maybe the chef will add more basil taste to it.-Red snapper with spicy basil sauce: Not sweet as we expected, but fish was fried deliciously and sauce was still pretty tasty - if you're the chef, please offer a sweet and spicy sauce too! We would love that!-Pad see eiw: Unfortunately, I only had one bite, but it was pretty good.For dessert, we had the fried ice cream. Not bad, but we probably won't order it again. (Too much batter and the ice cream could've been richer.)Final impressions:PROS: Server was very attentive (albeit a bit nervous from being new), restaurant has simple but elegant decor, fresh and high-quality food, unique spice-takes on dishes, inexpensive lunch deals ($7.99?), welcoming ambience for dates, families, etc., dishes were a decent size, pretty artistic with food designCONS: Spices for some dishes were different from what we were used to, difficult to spot when driving on LincolnFor sure, I'll go back to try the lunch specials and see how they do for dinner in about a month or so! I'm excited to see how this restaurant fares!

22.description: Had a nice lunch today.. started with Thai salad with ginger dressing. (part of $7.95 lunch special) followed with Bangkok spring rolls... super fresh and tasty.. had the tom kha soup with chicken.. fairly average could have used a little more heat.. the rest of the lunch special was a red curry with pork.. medium heat was perfect ..not overpowering. Portion was perfect if you had additional dishes.Service was attentive and prompt. Clean and well designed surroundings.Nice Thai iced coffee.Would recommend a stop if in the area.

0.description: If you look at my other reviews, several are for Thai places all over the country.  I stopped in today for lunch.  There wasn't anyone dining yet, but the quaint little place was very well decorated, nice chairs, and had an inviting feel.  A friendly elderly man brought me water and told me lunch specials were on the back.  I got green curry with chicken, which usually is my litmus test for good authentic Thai or an Americanized hack job wannabe.  With it came a crab Rangoon appetizer.  Fully expecting a heat and serve Rangoon that is very standard, I was pleasantly surprised when a very fresh, hand made, with crabmeat Rangoon came out.  And there was two on the plate.  After that, a nice size bowl (lunch serving but was plenty) of green curry and white rice came out.  Everything was wonderful.  The curry was fresh, rich, spicy (I asked for spicy), delicate, and delicious.  The chicken was tender, the veggies still were al dente', and the sauce was velvety.  The best part is when I went to pay the lady was unfortunate to tell me there was a $10 minimum for the charge card.  My meal (w/water) was only $8!  So I got a Thai coffee to go ($3) to get past the minimum.  It, as well, was very good.  I can not believe this place didn't have a line out the door for lunch.  That may be the best under $10 meal in Chicago in my opinion.  Most of the prices on the dinner menu are $10 - $13, and the place is BYOB.  So you could walk in with a bottle of Kim Crawford, have a fabulous meal and get out the door for $35 - $40 (including what you paid for the wine).  That is ridiculous considering the bottle of Crawford would cost you that alone at most places.I initially think this place is the best Thai I have had in Chicago so far.  I will be back to continue to test that theory.  This is a straight up mom and pop, super reasonable, excellent food kind of place.  These are exactly the kinds of places I look for when I travel for work.Other info... They do deliver.  They don't have a parking lot so you may have to pay to park on the street (I parked right in front of the restaurant).  I think it would be a great date spot if she/he likes Thai.

20.description: I liked the interior of the place and the food was varied. The cooks are managed by someone with great thai food cooking  experience

19.description: We order for,carry out at least two,times a week. Outstanding food withGreat attention to detail. I would not even consider thinking of,going to Any other Thai restaurants in the area!  This,place is a gem! You won't Be disappointed! everything we have ordered is outstanding! We are Thai foodies and have been to,Thailand many times. Congratulations to,this new establishment!

2.description: This place serves authentic Thai food that is absolutely delicious. There are many Thai places in the area, but the food here is head and shoulders above the rest. Check it out, but don't ask for "hot" unless you are serious -- it's "Thai hot" and pretty over the top. I am a fan of spicy cuisine and quite enjoy the "mild" here just fine.

18.description: You have to come for the weekday lunch specials. We had ordered 3 lunches; Pad See Eew, Panang Curry and Basil Fried Rice. Everything was perfect and made with love. Best Thai food in the neighborhood.

13.description: I liked the interior of the place and the food was varied. The cooks are managed by someone with great thai food cooking  experience

4.description: My boyfriend and I just ordered for delivery and it was delicious!! The chicken satay was yummy and the dumplings were outstanding. Whatever soy sauce they gave with the dumplings was a little sweet and a perfect compliment to the perfectly cooked dumplings. For our entrees, I got the drunken noodle and my boyfriend got the Thai noodles. Everything was amazing!!!

6.description: I ordered Take Out here for Lunch. The Lunch specials are cheap and numerous! I ordered the Pad Thai with Chicken lunch special with an order of the Crispy Tofu and it was ready for pickup within 10-15 minutes.The Sweet Chili Garlic Sauce that came with the Crispy Tofu was AMAZING: sweet, tangy, with just the right amount of heat to linger on the lips. The tofu itself was no longer crispy by the time I got back to the office 5 minutes after pick up because of the build up of steam in the container, however. But the tofu was springy, soft, and delicious.The side salad was small and simple, mostly lettuce and carrots but the dressing was great.The Pad Thai came in a large portion; it was very filling and satisfying. However, it was topped with some crispy chips (they looked like very small and thin Fritos) which I'd have preferred if they kept out. They didn't really add to the taste and it was not a texture I enjoy with Pad Thai and it's not something I've seen served on Pad Thai before. I would have preferred if they topped with more crunchy fresh mung bean sprouts. The dish did have bean sprouts but they were cooked in and therefore soft only.But because these are personal preferences and not a comment on the quality of the food. I'd definitely come here again and most likely try one of their curries.

15.description: This place is sooooooooo good!!! I ate the papaya salad and sticky rice and i went back the next day to eat it again! Yum!

7.description: We've ordered takeout from here a couple times and it has been pretty darn good.  Today we tried going in to the restaurant and it was just lovely.  The place is very clean and everything looks well taken care of.  Their vegetarian (chive) dumplings are scrumptious and the papaya salad is consistently yummy.  We ordered the Jumping Noodle soup which is now a new favorite.  Massaman curry was a solid choice and we also tried the Kai Yang which was a seasoned chicken breast served with plenty of fresh veggies cooked to perfection.  Topped off the meal with sticky rice custard and we were some happy campers.  This place gets 5 stars for being fresh, clean, and delicious in a convenient location to us.  Only thing I missed was the peppers in vinegar typical in the condiment options at Thai restaurants.

8.description: God I hope this place survives.  Some of the best Thai I've ever had.  The wife and I stopped for lunch here last week and had a fantastic meal.  The green curry and crab rangoon were probably the best I've had.   My wife loved her meal too(can't recall what she had to be honest).  BYOB and some of the friendliest service you will find.  Go here please so they can stay open.

3.description: Everything tasted great, some of the best thai food I have had in years - definitely stands out and I have ordered from dozens of thai places in Chicago. The fried basil catfish (even w/ delivery) was crispy and fresh, the crab rangoon had real crab, the pad thai was excellent. Definitely worth even the steep delivery fee.

14.description: This place has a fine dining type of feel, so when we ordered many dishes to share amongst 3 people, it was a little hard-- but that's not a problem when the food is sooo freaking good! I recommend the fried rice, papaya salad, any of the curry, and the tom yum soup. Definitely coming back :)

3.description: I absolutely love this place! It's a hidden gem. Though the menu could use an update, the Sul long Tang (Ox Tail Soup) is the best in Chicago. When Han Bat Sul Long Tang closed, this became my new spot. The owners are so friendly too.She runs the front of the kitchen, so be patient when the service may be a little slow. The food is so worth it...I go here at least once every two weeks. They usually have some Korean Soap Opera on the TV. Check it out!

1.description: Feel disappointed at all. I understand there is only one waitress that she might be too busy to serve all. But here's something happened I really don't understand. First, she didn't explain that only if we order 2 meat dishes then we could cook everything on a pan. Second, when we returned the first cooked beef, and required a new one, she looked unhappy and almost ignored us for no service for the rest time. No cutting for our late meats, and no water served unless we require. Our meat even burnt to black at last for no one came to tell us it is OK. Is it because we are only 2 girls??? Bad experience at all and won't recommend to my friend.

2.description: So much yum!!! I ordered the bi bim bap which was made perfectly. There was only a little meat but I didn't mind because usually bi bim bap only has egg, but the egg was cooked perfectly!!! This is a mom and pop joint so expect authenticity. There isn't a HUGE selection of Korean foods but what they make is very good!I will definitely return!

9.description: I went here the other day and got a dolSot bi bim bop. It was so good. I'm not a huge fan of barley tea, though and they didn't have diet coke.

10.description: This just may be the best Korean restaurant we have tried so far. Clean, GREAT service, and amazing food. Most meals are about $7.00 and they come with plenty of spicy kim-chi and warm barley tea. Try this place, it is worth the drive up that way.

4.description: I wasn't able to make the neighborhood spotlight event, but my friend ordered me maeuntang to go. The take-out is amazing. I didn't think they'd pack some banchan (fresh kimichi, sigeumchi namul [spinach], dubu buchim [tofu], etc.) and rice with it.I love maeuntang; it's probably one of my favorite Korean soup. Dal Paeng Yi's maeuntang is delicious. It's not as spicy as Da Rae Jung's, and I think it lacks ssukgat (edible chrysanthemum), which is essential for good maeuntang. I wondered if my friend told the restaurant that he's getting this for a non-Korean... Maybe they thought non-Korean = non-Asian, which may also mean non-spicy and no ssukgat. My friend tells me that the menu was more extensive than he thought it would be, so I'm curious enough to want to try it out one day when the weather gets warmer.

6.description: First of all, I am utterly charmed by this strip of Bryn Mawr. I spend far too little time here and the cluster of businesses and facades just seem so... homey to me. This strip is perfect for a slightly nippy fall day. Or, at least according to all the crazy in my brain. While I wouldn't go to Dal Paeng over some of my other Korean go-tos, I would definitely stop in if in the neighborhood. Everything's done family-style, so get ready to eat up. Bring the stretchy pants. The banchan was acceptable. Nothing blew me away by nothing was horrible. For some reason, our group was treated to fish patties and sauteed fish (with bones. Salt & pepper?) on the house. It was an unexpected treat. The bones didn't make me wanna dance with somebody but the fish patties were very good. I'd go back and order them without any hesitation.Being me, I over-ordered. I came hungry and didn't think the portion size would fill me up, so I ordered the stir-fried squid and the kimchi pork. This was a mistake. Order one or the other, but do not think you can take down both. You can't. I have a pregnant belly (hmm, why am I single?) and it was too much for me. But, the taste wasn't too much for me. Both dishes were fantastic. The squid was spicy hot, plentiful, perfectly cooked (no chewy tentacles here) and. when accompanied with the rice, was the start of the show. I am fairly certain that everyone at my table was pretty jealous of my meal... and that's just how I like things to be. All eyes on me, bee-yatches! The kimchi pork was a little different than I expected. It was served as a HOT soup with kimchi broth and pork pieces. The broth was (surprisingly) under-seasoned. The pork was well-cooked and seemed to have soaked up all the seasoning of the kimchi. As a result, I concentrated on eating the protein and left the soup be. But, it could be because I was stuffed and my palate was wrecked from the squid. Nah. It was a seasoning issue. I think. In any case, I'd order it again, if that tells you anything -- but it would be on a chilly day and without an order of squid in my belly. Barley tea was the drink of choice (necessity?) that day and it did the job. I am a tea guy but barley tea is an acquired taste. I thought it nicely complimented the food and my glass (yes, glass. No cups) never went down by more than half. The proprietors were friendly and very accommodating to our, sometimes, boisterous crew and that was greatly appreciated.Fall is coming. Take a trip to North Park and spend the day delighting your tastebuds and warming your spirits.

12.description: i'm very confused by this place, which only heightens my general befuddlement with korean cuisine. i love the stuff, but judging by the number of times i've had a waitress come to me and tell me i should be using the spoon and not the chopsticks to eat my particular dish, i have a lot to learn.i've been here a few times. in addition to always being the only person in the place, they always seem to be out of whatever it is i order. i usually just let the super-nice lady that runs the joint to suggest (through her english which is only marginally better than my non-existant korean) whatever is good that day. she brought me beef bone soup the other day, which sounded much worse than what i got, a lovely beef shank and daikon soup with a nice assortment of panchan, and warming barley tea.incredibly cheap, but if you're going to go here it probably helps to know korean, bring a korean friend, or just be feeling adventurous.

5.description: I came here with a group of Yelpers a week or so ago. I live within walking distance, but had never thought to come here before, so the Yelp get together seemed like a great opportunity to give it a try.I enjoyed my meal (stir fried octopus), but the octopus was very very tough. I spent an excessive amount of time chewing and finally gave up on it and just ate the veggies. It was a shame because I love octopus and the flavor was great, but I happened to get a seriously tough octopus. Oh well.The banchan was very good and much to my surprise I found the barley tea fairly palatable. I am not a tea drinker by nature.The staff seemed friendly, but I think language communications could be problematic. All and all, a nice little place.

11.description: "Came here with my Dad after his doc appt. We had a great beef kimchi stew and octopus stirfry. The staff is friendly. Quiet place and clean. Check this place out for some fresh korean food!!"

8.description: So there are four, maybe five (one place has no English on it and I'm thinking it's a bar) Korean restaurants on Bryn Mawr. This is the one I always pick to go to. When I can't get Naengmyeon (cold noodle soup), I go with either Dol Sot Bi Bim Bop or stir fried octopus and vegetables. My husband will get some sort of soup or the mackerel. All are very good and you get a nice array of ban chan also. The waitress has also surprised us with pieces of fish or a Korean pancake. During colder months, you are also served Barley or Corn tea. Almost every time I've gone to eat there, it has been either totally empty or there is one other table occupied. This is really too bad, because I think this restaurant is pretty good! The waitstaff are always very nice and polite. Because I'm not Korean, I am always asked if spicy is ok, which I appreciate. While I do like spicy, my sister doesn't but really likes the rice cake dishes which are supposed to be spicy. They accommodate the spiciness to her tastes. If you are in the area, this restaurant is worth checking out. It may not be as "fun" and San Soo Gap San, but it's tasty, quiet, and overall good! Oh! And there is always good street parking either on Bryn Mawr or one of the side streets!

0.description: I've been feeling under the weather so I was craving some seolleongtang (ox bone soup with noodles and meat) and this was the PERFECT place to go. I'm feeling refreshed and slightly better! Bring a korean speaking friend- this place is very authentic. Their signs and menus on the wall are all in korean. The barley tea that they provide is very good, and they will bring you a pitcher for refills. They also give kimchi and pickled garlic along with pickled daikon for appetizers. The seollongtang is delicious. You can add some salt to enhance the flavor, and they have some hot pepper paste as well. You can also add in green onions. It comes with noodles and meat that is very tender. For two bowls of soup, we paid $27 after tip and tax. Overall, money well spent! Would highly recommend this restaurant.

7.description: Come one, come all.  This little mom and pop joint needs some much deserved business!  Just as many of the places I try out, I drove by this place and saw "Korean Noodle Shop".  Interested, I plugged the name into my Blackberry for easy referencing later.  *later happened and I looked up the place on Yelp to see what it was all about.....only 3 reviews, but all were moderate to great reviews.  Pricing sounded reasonable, so I put this place at the top of my short (okay LONG) listThe next day I went in.  Windy/tornado watch day, and the place was deserted.  The owners/wait staff greeted me very merrily and I chose my own seat in their very spacious clean dining area.Per my gal Stella's review, I ordered the stir fry octopus with veggies...ohhhh MY gosh....TO DIE FOR!!!!  Heaven on a plate.  Use every single positive foodie adjective you can think of to describe it.  It had a great amount of kick and heat.  The octopus was still remained the star component in this stir fry, as most often, they throw a few chunks of whatever protein it is and save the $ by just making it a veggie dish.  Not so with this dish.  Tons of this seafood in there.  Even better was the fact that it still tasted wonderful reheated the next day for lunch....my favorite thing.  I also ordered an order of the chop chae, which is the Korean cousin of the Phillippine's pancit.  Ie....thin noodle dish mixed in with tiny pieces of beef and veggies.  Veggie were super fresh and noodles were al dente...then. While the veggies stayed fresh the next day, they the noodles stuck together after a reheat....booo.  Keep that mind if you wanna pack this as a leftover dish.  The owner/waitress was kind enough to give me more than just your regular ban chan.  She gave me a slice of fish *on the house* that was fried and seasoned nicely.  She also gave me a piece of an egg omelette which was nice and fluffy.  After talking with her, I learned her name was Mrs. Oh and their business had been there for 14 years and I never knew!!!! She is a delightful little woman who doesn't speak very much English, but her gestures are sincere and warm.  I really wish I could give it more than 5 stars. The food is wonderfully fresh and reasonably priced.  Correction.  Economically priced!   Favorite new spot for me!!!!!

36.description: While I'd prefer to shop Family Fruit Market or Whole Foods, sometime necessity and/or convenience leads me to the Foster-Pulaski Jewel.  This is the lesser of evil of all da Jewels in my estimation.  The employees are always helpful and the store has always been exceptionally clean in my experience.  Recently they made my daughter's birthday cake.  They did it right to order and it tasted great.  Whipped cream frosting is so much better than buttercreamThe self checkout lines are always monitored by someone and they are quick to help if you need something.  The only minus about the store is a line has more than 3 people in it, it totally blocks the main front of store aisle.  Not sure if this is a floor plan flaw or what, I've rarely seen it anywhere else.

29.description: Not only is this the best of all the Jewels in Chicagoland (which isn't saying much), this is one of the best grocery stores around.  Wide variety of foods include various  ethnicities and natural.  After work the lines aren't too bad, but on the weekend it's nuts.

42.description: This good-sized Jewel-Osco is not far from my house. They have some good sales here, like dollar items and "buy one-get one free" specials. If the items are not on sale, then they can be fairly expensive.

23.description: Good international and organic section. Specifically, British foods including treacle, spotted dick, hp sauce, and brown sauce. Minus a star for slow check out service and lack of baggers.

31.description: This is my favorite Jewel in Chicago.  It is clean, layed out perfectly, can move a long line quickly into a short one, always has some sort of cocktail being sampled in the liquor department, has photo center staff that actually know how to use the equipment, has amazingly knowledgeable and helpful pharmacy staff, samples food and is in a strip mall with a Subway, dry cleaners (Signature), Pizza Hut, Blockbuster, SCH Pediatrics office, H and R Block and a great chinese restaurant.  What more could you ask for?

34.description: This Jewel gets four stars just because they have FREAKIN JELLY BELLIES aka THE BEST JELLY BEAN IN THE WORLD by the pound!!!If this were my regular Jewel I would be a hell of a lot fatter than I already am :p.

16.description: The main reason I'm writing about this one, is that it's only one of *2 Jewels I can think of, along with Montrose/Lincoln, that were smart enough to put the Redbox machine inside the store. It doesn't hurt to mention this, especially with winter coming. Wish Jewel had done the same as these 2 locations at all stores, especially considering Dominick's had the sense to put all their DVDPlay machines inside. Fourth star, since as far as Jewel goes(and which isn't my first choice of grocery to shop at if possible), it's my second favorite location of theirs within the city, and only behind Ashland/Wellington.*- acknowledging that these 2 Jewel locations probably aren't the only ones in the minority of doing this w/Redbox.

11.description: I'm done with this place!  Got in line at the register this morning at 9:29 and didn't get out of the store until 10:00.....3 of 11 lines were open on a busy Saturday morning.  Ridiculous.  The reason I came on a Saturday was because I thought the under staffing at this store might be limited to Sunday mornings.Tony's here I come.

39.description: Only buy items you find in the sales ad, otherwise you are getting ripped off. They also are pretty slow in the checkouts, but they did recently add the self-checkout lines which are nice. This place is just too expensive... otherwise nice.

37.description: I'm pretty much in the middle between this Jewel and the one on Lincoln and Montrose, so I have to question why I keep going here. I'm usually pretty good about buying Jewel brand stuff and using my savings card, but what kills me is how terrible their product is most of the time.Perhaps it's because I go on the weekends, but I swear the peppers (green, red, yellow) are always rotten. The applies will be bruised, and whatever berries they have are mushy. I know, I know...why don't I go to a fruit market, or perhaps Whole Foods? The answer is because I'm lazy, like most people. I don't feel like driving around all day to buy groceries.

0.description: Beth on the overnight is the only reason why this Jewel Osco gets a four star rating instead of 3 star rating. The low rating is mainly because after midnight or so, they force the customers to pry open an exit door that's not meant to be opened before dashing off to grab Ben and Jerry's and nutter-butter bars. Why bother being open 24 hours if you're not going to give the nighttime customers the same accommodations as a daytime customers? Why make the night-time customers go through a different door like they're doing something wrong and need to be watched? Why not just close your store during the night time and everybody will be much happier... Except Beth who maybe loves the overnight shift... Idk.

38.description: Just moved here from Minneapolis and am just mortified with how bad this grocery store is (unfortunately it's the closest and most convenient for me).  High prices, disorganized produce area with rather poor quality and absolutely the worst meat selection I have ever seen.  Seriously, how can the highest available cut of meat be Select?  "Filet Mignon"  for $5.99/lb?  Um..no thanks!The checkout lines have been painfully long and S-L-O-W every time I've been in there.  And there is no room for all the lines that seem to be a constant.I will not be back.

27.description: This store NEVER has enough registers open and abuses the elderly and disabled people that work there.  I am happy to see that they employ these vulneralbe people but they way they work them as baggers is sickening.  They also cram the tiny aisles with giant crates of food to be stocked during rush hours.  Can't a giant store like that stock the shelves during less busy times.  Also, every time I've made a complaint to the management all they do is shrug their shoulders.

32.description: Alright, I'm going to give them another star because of a few reasons.It's easy to find these super awesome cinammon rolls (prepared by Culinary Circle) they carry (once a week) in the bakery aisle.  Chicken wings; you must get them from the case not the self serve counter.  Self serve counter is blah, those are kept warm with a boiler and bright lights which cause it to become plastic.  Ask a counter person for help and get it straight from their case, honey wings and fried chicken freshly prepared are awesome. Pastry shells, pastry wrapper and pastry sheets are easy to find in the frozen aisle.  During the holidays someone always asks me to get'em and it's not easy to find in every grocery store.  Jewelsgot'em, since in store items differ from store to store.. please note.

13.description: Why do this to myself? Procrastinating grocery shopping until the weekend... It is a poor lack of planning, a masochistic action. I don't think anyone looks anyplace where all the kids screaming their lungs out and thinks "awesome, can't wait to go!" Yes, at Jewel on a Sunday morning. I laughed at the obnoxious brat who looks like 12 tantruming and cursing because he can't buy wine cooler without an ID (dumb kid, suppose he had to learn sometime $1 Daily's is really bad sh!t) He provided much eyerolling and laughter to patrons and employees. This, I deduce, is the reason why there is a lovely server offering free shots of wine or liquor on entry... They can't boot the high-volume munchkins, they can only make the experience tolerable for those with wallets and valid ID. IKEA, Target- do this, get on it.  I digress, back to my review. I like that there seemed to be helpful staff in every aisle, multiple brands to select on bright, clean display... you have to love a store where you can buy just about everything at once: shampoo, laundry detergent, bread, eggs, produce, Vogue and get a free alcoholic shot to help tolerate bad parenting and profoundly worse children.Do yourself a favor, think of those children and plan ahead to shop at times when they are less likely to be present.

24.description: I am so happy this store revamped it produce section to include many organic selections. Also the store is very shopper friendly with bigger more organized sections.

7.description: Just left there on a Tuesday evening. Waited almost 45 minutes in line. There were a total of 5 cashiers. 2 of which were express lanes. The line got to be about 30 deep by the time I got out of there. Many frustrated customers, not enough employees. I have yet to be there when the lines are not a problem.

40.description: I went here today and their seasonal stuff was right out in front, like always. Usually, I just walk right by that stuff, but today it really came in handy. My friends were making corned beef and cabbage and they had everything right in the front of the store, complete with a recipe card. That definitely came in handy.This Jewel is where I go to get things that I can't get from Aldi's, HarvesTime or the other stores I frequent. I find all Jewels kind of ho-hum, but this one is probably my favorite. It always seems to be clean and in the pharmacy section they have some crazy merchandise that can be fun to look at.It's a nice Jewel, but I only go here as the last stop in my grocery excursions.

30.description: This is my favorite Jewel in the city as well. I used to go to the one at 6 corners for YEARS, and once they renovated it - it was no longer the one I "knew", so I started coming here. I find that this one is generally a lot less of a circus getting in and out, and when it is busy I can usually get out quickly in the self-checkout. I like the layout and it's always clean. What more can you ask for?

1.description: This place only has three cashiers working, no matter how busy it is or what time of day it is. It takes you longer to check out than it does gathering your groceries.Wonder when this place will be going out of business?

9.description: Avoid at all costs. I'd rather shop at a gas station for my groceries than here. Thank the mayor for switching to reusable bags that are in short supply. These people are so stingy with their bags it's really sad and pathetic.

26.description: The main reason I'm writing about this one, is that it's only one of *2 Jewels I can think of, along with Montrose/Lincoln, that were smart enough to put the Redbox machine inside the store. It doesn't hurt to mention this, especially with winter coming. Wish Jewel had done the same as these 2 locations at all stores, especially considering Dominick's had the sense to put all their DVDPlay machines inside. Fourth star, since as far as Jewel goes(and which isn't my first choice of grocery to shop at if possible), it's my second favorite location of theirs within the city, and only behind Ashland/Wellington.*- acknowledging that these 2 Jewel locations probably aren't the only ones in the minority of doing this w/Redbox.

25.description: This thing is Albertson's in disguise. Albertson's is a crappy grocery store. However, Jewel seems to have quite a bit more "classy" items that my old Albertson's lacked. Which is nice. Just, don't go at night because it's a madhouse. One lane open and like a 20 minute wait for the self checkout, which I decided to use only because a customer was throwing an absolute hissy fit with the poor cashier. Seriously, this man was raging when I started standing in line and was still raging when we left.Points because that cashier was handling it very smoothly. You know those people don't get paid enough to put up with people like that. Also, the other person running between the self checkouts adding money, filling receipt paper rolls, and clearing ID checks was a total trooper. Not looking stressed but totally working with a sense of urgency.

12.description: OVER CHARGED AND SHORT CHANGED WITHIN 15 MINUTES OF CHECK OUT!!!Can you imagine being BOTH over charged AND short changed in just one transaction?  Read on.11/1/2014  about 7:00 p.m.Scallops were advertised at $12.99 a pound.  They rang up at the register at $17.99 a pound.  After checkout, i went back to check the price.  Yep, the advertised price was $5.00 less per pound than what I was charged at the register.When I went to the customer service desk to ask for the refund, I was subsequently short changed 50 cents--representing about 10% of the refund.  "Oh, did you not get all of your quarters???," said the customer service manager.I will NEVER shop at this store again. The last time I shopped at this store, they cheated me out of 10 percent of the cost of a box of Jello.  Granted, it was only about 30 cents, but over millions of customers, that adds up.  Check your receipts!  BEWARE!

21.description: The produce is usually rotten or on the verge of mold.

17.description: Apparently this Jewel store doesn't do meat mark downs like the others, there was a lot of meat at or past the sell by date. Watch for that when buying meats here.

10.description: On the surface, this looks like a decent Jewel--roomy, relatively clean, well stocked with an acceptable range of products--until you finish your shopping and find that there are NO SELF-CHECKOUT terminals.  I can't believe it.  This is a sizable store, so floor space is not an issue.  Even the cramped, eternally shitty Andersonville Jewel has self-checkout.What gives, North Park Jewel?

5.description: I usually shop here but one bad experience can ruin a persons outlook, in this case my opinion of this store. I'm a firm believer in the power of organics yet I myself don't bother with them however I went to pick up some apples for sick grandmother. To my dismay after cutting each apple in half, literally all of them were spoiled. Organic Granny Smith. CAVEAT EMPTOR.

35.description: OK, I'm a regular at this Jewel and it is one of the nicer Jewels that I have been to in the city. However, I just came back from this location this afternoon and our bill was over $170 and we bought 3 canvas bags full of groceries. My fiance checked over our receipt and we were charged for 61 red peppers  costing $60. Um, WTF!? I know it's human error but it's a very large inconvenience to go back to the store and get this adjusted.When you shop here, please watch the checker and triple check your receipt for any errors. You never know when you will get charged for something that you didn't purchase.

19.description: I use to work here. You can't please everybody. Not enough cashiers?? Budget cuts people!! ok!! Calm down they will get to you. Sorry that the person in front of you has 7 WIC items. But I'm pretty sure that your organic tomatoes can wait while the customer needs to feed his or her KID!!! Relax!! A mad rush of customers is never ever easy. Like I said you can't please everybody. But I do have to agree the self checkout is a pain.

28.description: In most ways, this Jewel is really great -- clean, large, exceptionally well-stocked.  They carry many items you won't find at other Jewels, including fresh veggie and avocado rolls in the sushi department, many flavors of Kashi crackers, and Kosher specialty foods such as frozen gefilte fish.  (Yes, it tastes great, and is nothing like the gefilte fish blobs you've seen in jars.)The only issue I've had here is with service.  I'm not saying the service is bad; it's usually polite and normal, when you can get it.  But if you shop late in the evening, you might not get any service at all.  When I shop here after 10 pm, there often isn't a single cashier on duty, and only the self-checkout lane is open.I find this frankly insulting to customers.  Jewel is not cheap -- their produce often costs twice as much as local groceries charge.  In effect, Jewel charges a premium for their brand, which means things like cleanliness, quality, and long hours.  When I go there, I effectively pay a higher price for the convenience of shopping after 10 pm, when I'm on my way home from work.  And since I am paying full price, I expect FULL service.  If I've just put in a long day at my job, I shouldn't have to also do the cashier's job of looking up produce codes when I'm dead-tired.  Plus the self-service machine always, always gives you errors because it doesn't think you've put something in the bag.  Of course, using the self-checkout lane is a minor inconvenience in the grand scheme of things.  But the lack of cashiers on the late shift sends a bad message to customers.  To me, it says "We're doing you a favor just keeping the doors open; you can fend for yourself at the register."

3.description: It is really funny to update some of these reviews because I'm like, "Mind blown...how my life has changed." I'm no longer a vegetarian and I totally forgot about that delicious tilapia.So, this is still a great location but has become more of my "last minute stop" on the way to or from work.I would like to give a shout out to the floral department -I have made many a stop for either flowers or balloons for coworkers birthdays. Yes, they are a little more expensive than, say, a Party City...but the balloons last for weeks! I think they are way better quality than Party City, which can sometimes deflate overnight!Great location, never have had a problem here -always find what I need and get in and out in about 20 minutes!

33.description: This Jewel is pretty clean by Jewel standards and pretty friendly by human standards. It's also not packed at night like other Jewel's. My gripes:1) Very small organic/Boca/Morningstar section2) The smell in there during the holidays is unbearable. It makes me so nauseous to enter the store and then get hit with some weird "holiday spice" scent ..yuk3)They dont really like the whole "bring in your own bag" situation. They usually throw a few things in your bags and then throw the rest in plastic..wtf I know they can fit more than a loaf of bread in each bag. Come on. I feel like they think it's easier to use plastic. I just don't get it.Other than that, it's a pretty decent Jewel and that's why I keep coming back.

43.description: Not a fan of their produce, not bad, just rather go to a produce store. I like it because its a comfortable place to shop. My preference it to go to places that are a bit worn in. This place isn't run down, just hasn't been updated in about twenty years, which is fine by me. I do not like shopping at the antiseptic places which are rehabbed ever two years like many Dominicks are. This Jewel is located with an Osco, so its pretty much one stop shopping. Huge parking lot, located in a strip mall. Can get a bit nuts on Saturday afternoons though. The one thing I like about this Jewel, is that they have the manual checkout. Nice when you're in a hurry. Most don't use the four manual registers, and thats fine by me.

2.description: Usually I don't shop @ Jewel/Osco because of the high prices, but they have some great deals on select items.  Salmon fillets for $5.99/lb, pork baby back ribs buy 1 get 2 free @ $7.99/lb divided by 3.  This breaks down to $2.66/lb.  Maybe I'll marinade them with a dry rub let them sit overnight & slow cook.  Or maybe precook them in water to tenderize them and then I'll fire up the grill and Bbque them.Salmon fillets with fresh garlic, ginger, soy sauce sesame  oil & some cayenne peppers or jalapeños for some heat.  Jab the salmon full of holes on the meat side and let these marinate overnight in the refrigerator to let the marinate soak into the salmon meat.  Next day take out of the refrigerator, Salt & pepper the skin side and put them under the broiler flame to blacken the skin, flip them over and cook internally (delicious)Boneless skinless chicken breasts for $1.88/lb

18.description: Alright, I'm going to give them another star because of a few reasons.It's easy to find these super awesome cinammon rolls (prepared by Culinary Circle) they carry (once a week) in the bakery aisle.  Chicken wings; you must get them from the case not the self serve counter.  Self serve counter is blah, those are kept warm with a boiler and bright lights which cause it to become plastic.  Ask a counter person for help and get it straight from their case, honey wings and fried chicken freshly prepared are awesome. Pastry shells, pastry wrapper and pastry sheets are easy to find in the frozen aisle.  During the holidays someone always asks me to get'em and it's not easy to find in every grocery store.  Jewelsgot'em, since in store items differ from store to store.. please note.

41.description: My local Jewel is better than some, with an expanded ethnic selection and self-serivece checkout.  In general, I am not a fan of either of the big chains in Chicago.  It may be politically incorrect for me as a liberal democrat to say this, but unfortunately the heavily unionized work force leads to overpricing.  Why for example would I want to buy bananas at an average of .69 per pound when I can get them in a produce market at an averge of  .49 per pound?  The Osco section of this store does have some nice clearance prices in seasonal merchandise, by the way.

4.description: I really want this Jewel to be my main grocery store.  I like just about everything about it but the lines!   PLEASE bring back self check out.   I can't tell you how many times I limited my shopping so I could go in the 15 or less isle.   I seriously waited 25 minutes last week when I had to go through a regular line.   It breaks my heart to see elderly people forced to stand for long waits.  I've never had to wait in lines like this at any other store.  Target is like a 1 to 5 minutes wait.   I'll gladly give you 5 starts if you reduce your wait time!

6.description: The stores early morning FRESH squeezed $4 qt OJ gives this Jewel and extra star. It is awesome, and the addiction that gets me out of bed and to the store early.  The over use and dependence of self check-out lines takes away a star.  I HATE the self check-outs.   One of the reasons I often go to Whole Foods. Clean store, good selection, good fresh veggies section. Kind, helpful staff overall.

22.description: I see that this store has not been reviewed this year. As a cashier at this store, I am going to be as honest as a customer.Last summer our store has undergone quite a big remodel. New flooring, new lighting, new furniture, bigger organic and produce and sushi selection, more baked goods, a little more of everything. The only downside was that most of the products had to be rearranged and the regular customers are dissatisfied now that the aisle that they turn to to get a specific item is in a different area.When I first started as a bagger, I did everything in my job list and more. It was not required but I'm that type of person to make customers happy. The baggers that use to work there didn't perform that well. They either quit or got fired. Those that remained and those that got hired recently are the best I've seen so far. We not only bag your groceries according to your needs, but we also help you put it on the conveyor belt to be rung up, and would have no problem with double bagging and helping you to your car. We have no problems with using your own bags, as a matter of fact we encourage you! My old supervisor told me that we, along with all of the Jewel stores, lose thousands of dollars just on plastic bags each month. And when we lose money, we lose working hours. Because of this as well as stolen and broken items, our hours are recently cut done 50%. Perhaps this is one of the reasons why we don't have a lot of baggers as we use to during the busy hours.The best time to shop is early mornings and nights, or at least before 11am and after 5pm. It can get really busy! I'm sorry that lines are long, and that you can't buy liquor before 11am on Sundays. I've gotten yelled at by customers because of this and I almost cried. They can be very discriminating against my young appearance and race. I've gotten customers who wouldn't listen to me and kept going against my words, and when I had my boss to come over and explain the same exact thing, they stopped complaining. I stand correctly. If I am unsure of some things, I tell you straight up of my uncertainties and would gladly have either my supervisors or boss to help you instead.  One time a customer yelled at me because he grabbed a medicine that was placed in the wrong area. When I told him that this is the wrong medicine, he became furious and demanded a cheaper value. I was very patient with him, didn't give him an attitude, and nicely told him that he took the wrong one and yet he yelled that it was for his son [who was apparently waiting in the car alone]. I'm sorry but wouldn't you buy it for your loved one even if it was a dollar more? This customer left and called me a b*tch. That was definitely uncalled for. This is probably the only bad experience I had with a customer.The comments about how expensive our products is, don't listen to them. They're just buying the items that are either not on sale or of brand-name. And when they are on sale, they're definitely a bargain. When I go shopping, I always buy the groceries that are on sale and wait for the ones that I want to go on sale next time. Aren't all grocery stores like this?I'm the only short asian girl cashier who looks like 18 but I have the liquor licence to override liquor. The best part about this is not waiting for someone older to ring up the liquor; and if I'm waiting, the customer will too. I'm faster than the cash registers, no joke; and when I'm working at the self-check-out lanes, I speedwalk/run to you, not walk. I don't know why I always do this. I just feel the need to service customers like a superwoman. I'm always smiling, express my greetings and farewells, playing and making your babies and kids laugh, curious about how you are and how's your day going, very fast productive, and idk what else to show off besides my face being in one of the employee-of-the-month wall ;)But if you have a problem, don't leave without us helping you. This is where most of our bad ratings come from. Customers walk out the store unhappy about something that we are unaware of. Sometimes we can't tell if you're really mad inside while you're expressing yourself oppositely. And sometimes we don' t know how you want us to bag your groceries according to your individual needs, and you let us continue because you don't say anything. So if you let us know your thoughts and opinions, we will do our best to deliver and make right.I give this store and all other Jewels a 4-star. We need new cash registers, or at least faster ones.

15.description: Great customer service and great products! This store is always super busy but the employees are very courteous and nice. I'm glad that I live close to this store because they have the products I always look for whether its a want or need.

20.description: Not impressed not enough selection!!

8.description: This Jewel is pretty good.  It's two blocks from my house, prices are average, and it has a good range of products.  Staff members always also try to be helpful.

14.description: is good for a lot of things . is a one stop strore for all needs . friendly staff .

1.description: I'm realizing I read Melissa's review so long ago and tagged it with useful votes thinking I would eventually dine here.So this was 2 months or so ago.  I have been back and forth on whether to post because I haven't any love to give nor ability to give a report on the experience.  Let me explain.  Two guys, both Asian and hungry, not that that detail should matter.  Walked in on a Saturday night the door was open and a sign was lit indicating that they were.  Walked over to the waitress to make sure the kitchen was open.  A few booths were filled with only Korean people speaking Korean and drinking up a storm.  We got a few awkward looks from the other patrons, I know that fucking look well.  A play I haven't seen in the last decade or so with the explosion of the Internet, review sites and more Americans willing to try these hidden ethnic spots opening them up to a new community of wealth.  Hidden, in the sense that they are geared (more) towards their own.  The waitress assured us we could order and gave us menus, directed us towards a booth.  I had a Korean menu and quickly scanned it, a few really awesome dishes I knew we would order fo'sho.  Before we could sit down a manager or owner came out hurriedly and shooed us off.  Seriously, with her hands shooing like she's sending a cat away from the couch.  She said they were closed and we had to leave.  I know this drill but had to ask.Me: "Your waitress said the kitchen is open"  Owner: "No it's closed, she wrong"  Me:  "There are customers sitting here and eating and drinking"Owner: "no, no, closed, time to go."My Mongolian compadre " Fuck it, lets bounce"..  As we are about to leave I hear the lady mutter something like.. "Oh private party" all matter of fact.  I turn around and reply "Sure" one guy sitting at a booth looks me dead in the eyes and has a smirk on his face.This area of the North side, when bars or restaurants of this type are rented for private parties they usually lock the front door and shutoff all open signage.  Patrons of the party enter and exit from the rear, so they don't bring attention to what's happening inside.  If the front door is used, it's usually manned.  I know from personal experience.

0.description: This restaurant seems relatively new. When my boyfriend and I went there a few weeks ago they hadn't printed their menus yet. They gave me a menu in handwritten Korean and were surprise when I was able to read some of it and order. My boyfriend got dolsot bibimbop (his favorite Korean dish) and I got spicy tofu soup. I ordered mandu (the best I have ever had), but I didn't need to because of all the "half-meal" food they gave us before the meal. They gave us floury, eggy pancakes with hot peppers in the middle of them, a bunch of dough balls (I don't know the names of any of these), I think 2 different kinds of kimchi, and of course cold tea that is on the house (my boyfriend asked for some water later, hehe). We were so full after the meal. There was a group of Koreans there, I think they were having a sort of grand opening at the time, and they were eating, drinking, and soon singing karaoke. That's right! This restaurant has a karaoke machine behind the bar! They were so nice and I sang a few songs on their machines. I don't think any of their songs go past 2001 or so, but that's okay. I sang a few classic Korean pop songs (from around '98, '99 or so) and they were again impressed. We were the only people there at about 1am and they were so happy to have us that they gave us free Miller Lite!Now for the good stuff. As I said we were stuffed and couldn't eat anymore.  I accidentally didn't let my boyfriend know that kalbi was on the menu, but that's okay, we ate well (it's a Korean restaurant that has pits at every table, but kalbi is not their only thing, it's a well rounded place). But the best part is their prices. Seriously, we had "half-meal," mandu, dolsot bibimbap, spicy tofu soup, and 2 free Miller lites. All this came to grand total of $19!!! That's right we spent less than $10 a person! We almost never do that, especially at a Korean place! I can't wait to go back!Best Korean restaurant in the city now, hands down.-----------------Second Visit: Still the best! We ordered bulgogi which of course came with lots of banchan. I forgot to correct my boyfriend again and he got bibimbap instead of his favorite dolsot bibimbap. He still liked it. We ordered our beer this time (I'm actually not a big fan of beer). I didn't order anything for myself and we didn't get a separate appetizer but I was still full at the end of the meal! I pretty much put my share of bulgogi in the provided soup, along with a bunch of kimchi (3 kinds), mushrooms, other vegetables, rice, and dried fish.The woman who served us was really nice and spoke fine English. They now have printed menus. The first few pages are in Korean but the last page is in English. It includes all the favorites (kalbi, bulgogi, some soups, etc.) but it still helps to read Korean for the things not included on this one page. You can always ask if you don't know what to order. As usual, you have to buy 2 orders of kalbi or bulgogi to cook at the table but the prices are reasonable to do so.This time KBC was playing on the TV. KBC is the local Korean TV staion and features a lot of subtitles shows. This place stays open late (we haven't even been there before midnight). It may not be 24 hours but I would take this over San Soo Gab San any day (or night).[Note: The restaurant's name is wrong. The photo is correct. I'm not sure about the address and phone number but they should be correct. I will make corrections soon.

1.description: This thy place to take your lady and enjoy the music.. Delicious food and great customer service and more. They have belly dancing weekends, friendly people beautiful Lebanese cuisine and party place.

2.description: We came here last month on a weeknight for dinner and won't be back.  This restaurant/lounge/dance club has a very specific customer base, and I feel like we were not it.  There was a large family of approximately 10-15 people in the back corner that occupied about two full tables, and the rest of the restaurant was empty.  Ethnic music was blaring on bad speakers, and disco lights were flashing from the small stage against one wall of the restaurant.  We were seated next to this loud, empty stage.  Our waiter was a young guy who was really friendly, but our food took a really long time to arrive - so long that we had finished our other entrees before asking the waiter if the kitchen forgot or if they started making it yet because we didn't want it anymore.  They ended up giving it to us for free, and we just had it doggybagged.

0.description: This place is beyond amazing! The food is delicious and it's always fresh. The owners of the restaurant are very sweet and very friendly, they make you feel like family every time you come in. Saturday Nights are beyond amazing and fun. The entertainment on Saturdays are always fun and the singers they bring are beyond amazing and beautiful voices. They always bring a different singer from out of state or country every Saturday so there's always someone new to listen to! I must also say the customer service is great and always helpful when your in need. Out of all the restaurants and lounges I have been to I must admit ROZANA is the best and most exciting by far! It's not expensive and it's always a great time every day and every Saturday. The family and the employees are the most sweetest and generous people I have yet to meet. If your looking for a great night out, an amazing weekend, and delicious food, you must go to Rozana! I give this place more than 5 stars if I could. They also reserve special events for baptisms, engagements, birthdays and more. If you want to have a great time Rozana is the place to go to!!!

Not a bad place. It's family owned, and cannot really compete with CVS or Walgreens. It's really a neighborhood drug store. Consider that there are isn't another drugstore in about a 4 or 5 mile radius, this may be the place to pick something up. If you like to support family owned shops, then this is the place to come.. Personally, I would rather pay less :-).

3.description: 10 minute pedicure, complete with sloppy polish job? No thank you!There are better places in the neighborhood.My toes look like my 10 yr old niece polished them.

1.description: If Kim isn't there do not allow anyone else to do a full set for you!! My nails look a week old and it's only been a day! The nail tech I believe her name is Maya did not fully paint my nails and looking at my nails some are VERY uneven and bulky like ew!I also realized when I got home my right eyebrow has a small chunk missing and my brows are not EVEN as the lady said she would do for me. I have to fill my brows in until they grow back.I expect to leave a nail shop feeling good and not still needing to keep up with certain maintenance of my brows and nails for another 2 weeks! Not in this case, I won't be back and I also left a tip which I very well wish I could take back.

2.description: Horrible they're very nice but I spent $50 on a pedi and a no chip the day of they began to chip. So we called and they told us to come in. I noticed how see through all my other nails were and told them I wanted them redone. My aunt runs her own salon and is a pro so when I showed them to her she told me how them soak them off and redone. I asked and told them over and over and over again it's like I was talking to a stubborn brick wall they literally didn't listen to a word I said.so they said they would do another coat and fix the nail that chipped but refused to redo them they even sent almost every person in the salon to look at my nails and tell me how nice they look nice and see through that's the last time they get my business  if I could give 0 stars I would

0.description: Very glad I found this place! It's tiny, but everyone there is so nice! Reasonably priced and less than 5 minutes from my place. Can't ask for anything more!

4.description: Absolutely HORRIBLE. I wanted to try out a new place and NEVER again! I paid for a full set, manicure and pedicure. Instead I received..... A full set that is super thick and looks gaudy, horrible paint job. The woman who did my nails had to use THREE cutters to clean my cuticles and it looked horrible. She than decided that she was going to help someone else.... And told me someone else will do my pedicure because her "customer" was here for her. (What the heck was I?). Some young kid began my pedicure.... And took a huge piece of skin when cutting my cuticles than decided not to cut the rest! And paint job was horrible. Soooooo upset with experience! I had to pay to get my nails fixed at another salon the next day because they looked so bad!

29.description: I have always been intrigued with this place, so I finally picked up steak tortas & steak tacos for our meal.  The prices are not inexpensive & the portions are quite small, but MAN THE FLAVORS ARE OUT OF THIS WORLD!Taquerias are usually a place for me to fill up on the cheap.  This place had so much flavor in its meat that I savored every last bite.  It was really, really good. If there is anything to critique, it would be the little bits of gristle & tendons that I found in the meat.  Given the fact that it was late night, I'll let it slide....this time.  Not enough to lower my star rating.

42.description: Sergio's will always have a place in my heart because while drinking at the Hollywood I often get drunk-munchies for either pizza or tacos. Well gosh, a little hole in the wall that's open late and serves pizza and tacos! Excellent.The food here is pretty cheap. You're definitely not paying any extra for ambiance, but that really doesn't matter. The food comes quickly and everyone that works there is pretty polite. The tacos are good, the rice and beans are awesome. The pizza is your average pizza-by-the-slice style. Before I started making this a late night destination I used to come by here on half days in high school (which for me was right down the block) and my whole crew could afford to eat great and watch a ball game on tv. It's just old school, but fun. I do give them an extra star for pretty fine tortas.

23.description: One of our family favorites. We started coming here because it's a short 1/2 a block away from our house. After years of being regular customers, the staff at Sergio's is practically family to us. I've got to admit, we don't often stray from our order of the Carne Asada burrito dinner so I can't comment too much on the menu. However, what I can tell you is that we're never disappointed with our regular order (we literally order Carne Asada burritos on weekly basis... sometimes more often). The service is friendly... you can tell these people are very family oriented. I love that about them!!! This is a clean establishment with plenty of seating. Though we always take to-go (because it's so close to home), I wouldn't hesitate to dine in.

8.description: A random stop the other afternoon hoping to grab a slice of fresh za.  Unfortunately it was day old stuff and though I knew better, I still purchased.  Just in case, I decided to order up two tacos as well.  Lengue & Milanesa, tacos are $1.99 each.  It took almost twenty minutes, mostly due to them making the tacos fresh.  The tab was just over $7 dollars.  (I've included photos for your pleasure.)I always thought it was a carry out joint.  Actually its two storefronts linked and the second area is solely for dining.  Pretty nice space actually but best suited for a quick meal kind of like a diner.  Sergio's offers your typical Mexican fare like tacos, tortas, burritos, mariscos (seafood), Mexican dinners, but they aren't limited to just Mexican food.  They also offer salads, pasta platters, burgers, sandwiches and a variety of pizzas and appetizers.  So yeah, just like your common diner, trying to serve it all to capture that business.  The plus is that it tastes pretty good and the pricing is affordable.  i.e a quarter pound burger with fries is as low as $5 dollars.  I can't attest to the flavors of the pizza since my slice was pretty old.  However, the beef tongue taco was tasty and the beef was perfect.  I've had bad lengue (elsewhere) where some of the pieces still had the feelers intact and the meat too chewy.  Gnarly.  This was good.  I could see coming back for tacos or trying other Mexican or American favorites in the future.

31.description: I recently stopped into Sergio's for the first time and got a couple of Tacos Asada.  For a place that bills itself as a pizza shop, I wasn't expecting all that great of Tacos-- but I was very pleasantly surprised to get two delicious tacos.  Soft, fresh corn tortillas.  Juicy, flavorful meat.  And a crisp, crunchy blend of lettuce, cilantro and cabbage on top.  Some of the better Tacos I've had in a long time.The service was very friendly and though the dining room didn't have a lot of ambiance, it was clean and comfortable enough.  I will be returning.

34.description: Well today was a big commit a home neatness day, so I was not up for cooking anything or going anywhere.This place is in my neighborhood and I have never ordered from here, so I thought I would give it a try.. My order was fairly large because it was going to have to cover lunch for mom and I and supper for mom, Christopher and I. For lunch mom had a torta (ground beef) and a baked potato. Thumbs up on both of them. She does not like beans and rice so was great to have an alternative. I ordered a small Tex-Mex Pizza #1, which is thin crust and has sausage, fresh tomato and jalapeno on it. I really liked it. In my post menopausal dotage, I find my craving for hot food is escalating!!! For dinner I got 2 orders of spaghetti with meat sauce and a small chef's salad. The salad was very nice, lots of cheese and pepperoni in it. When I first looked at the spaghetti, I thought they were being a little chintzy on the amount, but DANG, the sauce was so meaty and rich that the 3 of us split one order and the salad. It was pretty darn good, better than a lot of the sit-down Italian restaurants in the area that I have eaten at. All in all everything I ordered ranged from solidly good to really good. AND, the best part, I still have a full order of spaghetti and most of my pizza left. The order was well packaged, all the little side things like spaghetti cheese and salad dressing and good bread were included. Delivery was prompt and we are blissfully stuffed.

16.description: Pizza like school cafeteria...mexican food not much better.

13.description: Mmm, love the veggie tacos here! Also, the chips & guacamole were pretty good too. I ordered from here because I heard they deliver to the NEIU library and I needed a break from cramming for finals. Honestly, pizza + mexican food + will deliver to my school library so I don't have to put any effort into having a decent meal = pretty awesome in my book. The prices are pretty budget friendly as well!

11.description: great tacos and a everyday lunch spot for me and my wifethey r friendly and the staff r very polite and courteous.i very much appreciate a favor they done for me a month back or so holding a ring i loss there for me,thank u very much
