But the service is super fast, the food is always hot, and they frequently throw in freebies like extra egg rolls and fried rice, even when we don't order the amount GrubHub says you have to in order to get a free fried rice or sweet and sour chicken.It took a few orders, but we figured out what we liked and what we didn't and haven't messed with it since then.Like I said, the food is always hot when it gets here (usually about 20 minutes earlier than GrubHub says they will). The chicken dishes we've gotten are all decent and they really pack it into those containers. Don't get larges unless you want leftovers. Sesame chicken is my favorite from them. The sweet and sour is always overflowing with crispy chicken and the sauce, which comes in a separate container so the chicken stays crispy, is way more sweet than sour, but bf really likes it. We've also enjoyed their egg rolls, lo mein, orange chicken, and wonton soup. The almond cookies are hit and miss, sometimes they have a weird taste and other times they're delicious and soft. I'd never had a soft almond cookie from a Chinese place before See Thru. I steer clear of their beef and pork dishes. The mongolian beef in particular is really disappointing. It doesn't taste anything like what I know mongolian beef to be and the container is at least 50% filled with onions. Ah well.We're moving soon, and we'll definitely miss See Thru. Even if we find a place that has good mongolian beef. If you're more of a chicken person than a beef or pork person, I recommend it.

5.description: I've been coming here for awhile now and it's so hard to give a positive or a negative review. The place is so unsanitary but the food is just amazing you forget what kind of kitchen it comes from. So...I lose my appetite once I go in to observe the kitchen as im paying for my food. But I go home and eat my Mongolian beef special and I think to myself.... Just wow. They give you more than enough and the food stays HOT for over 30 min... This is just a perfect place to take-out or get food delivered. You initially wouldn't want to eat in there because of how unappealing it looks but the food does it justice. Thank da Lawd.

25.description: We ordered from this place the other night. Some of it was "ok" and some of it mediocre. The pork fried rice was ok, as were the rib and beef appetizers. The egg rolls were lousy, chewy and lacking in flavor and the Mongolian beef was greasy and over loaded with onions. I have no desire for a repeat performance. There are much better alternatives.

12.description: The woman who works at the front is the sweetest. The delivery is fast. & the food is cheap, enough to fill me up for 3 days, and delish. (:

21.description: This place is so great - we're so glad to have found it!!  The food is always SUPER fresh, arrives really fast and hot (granted we're less than a mile away).  The portions are enormous...one entree is easily enough for 2-3 meals, even though we eat a lot!  The prices are unbelievable for what you get, and the selection is huge.  Order from here, you won't be disappointed.

16.description: Free delivery!Buffet food arrives quickly.Toilet night endless...(ya i know the form is supposed be Japanese but it's not like what I ate was all that Chinese so sue me)

17.description: Absolutely putrid. This really should be a one-star review but I reserve those for places that make me want to punch one or more employees in the groin.I ordered orange chicken. Wife ordered pepper steak. Typical standard American-Chinese take-out fare. Both of us deemed our dishes inedible. The minute I opened my orange chicken and was beset by an acrid cloud that nearly choked me, I knew I was in for a special evening. Meanwhile, my wife's pepper steak smelled like fish. Neither of us could finish our respective entrees, and even though we only ate a small portion we both ended up spending a lot of quality time in the Oval Office.Never. Ever. Again.Ugh -- back to the bathroom. :(

10.description: Lots of food for a great price. Check out the dinner special. Had enough food for dinner and lunch the next day. Easy to order online and pick up. Only complaint was that the lady at the window was a little chatty with the cooks before she brought me my order which was sitting on the counter and ready.

11.description: My roommates and I love this place, because it's a great option for when we are low on cash but don't want to/don't have time to cook.  The Chinese food isn't fabulous (ok, well the crab rangoons are, fo real), but it's good.  And the most important thing is, it's like, half the price of wok cuisine and other places nearby.  So, ultimately, it's not the most delicious and best chinese food ever, but it's a great value and a convenient place.  Oh! And they deliver quite quickly.

26.description: I will not be ordering from them again. I had the shrimp with lobster sauce, and it was so dark with soy sauce and saltythat I just threw it away, along with the chewy eggrolls. They had decent shrimp fried rice, but the veggie and tofu dish is just tofu and broccoli (it should be mixed veggies). The egg drop soup was okay, but again, too salty. Crab rangoon was pretty standard, but a little on the sweet side, and the fried shrimp were delish. The beef teryaki was just so-so. It was a little chewy for my taste.  Also, delivery took over an hour at 3 p.m. on a Tuesday.Guess I learned my lesson! When Tom Lee's Chop Suey is closed on Tuesdays, just cook at home!

27.description: I stopped by here to pick up some Chinese fast food.  I ordered crab rangoon and Mongolian beef.  The beef was pretty good, and I'm glad it didn't have the usual deep-fried rice noodles underneath (most places give you stale noodles, anyway).  It did have some mushrooms and baby corn in it, which was fine.  The crab rangoon were ok.  The filling was a bit sweet, but not bad overall.  When I got home, I noticed that they gave me a free egg roll, which was a nice surprise.  Overall, See Thru is your basic Chinese fast-food restaurant.  It's cheap, fast, and the food was ok.  They have lunch and dinner specials, which I'll probably try next time.  1/9:  I'm a sucker for bad Chinese food sometimes.  I had their garlic beef lunch special (order it spicy), which comes with fried rice, an egg roll, and a can of pop for $5.  Ashamed, but satisfied.

0.description: See Thru has portion and quality for the buck. Don't expect the best food on earth but you get the value for your buck. Good joint for hangouts for young adults and teens.

20.description: We were REALLY impressed with the quality (and quantity) of food that came! They delivered it exactly as we asked (we asked for no egg given allergies). They didn't scrimp on meat/veggies, didn't use MSG, or use too much corn starch in their sauces like other chinese delivery restaurants. Really great tasting food and good value (we got the singapore rice noodles and mongolian beef combo).

19.description: We were REALLY impressed with the quality (and quantity) of food that came! They delivered it exactly as we asked (we asked for no egg given allergies). They didn't scrimp on meat/veggies, didn't use MSG, or use too much corn starch in their sauces like other chinese delivery restaurants. Really great tasting food and good value (we got the singapore rice noodles and mongolian beef combo).

2.description: I really don't understand how the reviews are so low on this place. It's a real secret gem! If you're a big chinese fiend like I am, you'll probably notice that more and more places are trying to implement the whole 7.00 for lunch/dinner special with egg roll and a free pop. I have tried several places and 0 can top this place. Their 7.00 special is literally all day from lunch-dinner where most places end at lunch, I find. Their chicken fried rice is the best I've ever had and their egg roll is so good. You won't be disappointed. I recommend the sweet and sour chicken or empress chicken. You get so much food it's a good meal for about 2 days max. 1 if you're not into leftovers.

18.description: This is a great Chinese take out option in my neighborhood, speedy delivery and consistently great tasting food. Great fried rice, which is an easy thing to do wrong but these guys make it right!

13.description: Oh man, just had this over the weekend and I am sad to see it has such low reviews. I thought this place was delicious! My goodness the portions were great, the dishes all came with A LOT of meat. I hade the General Taos' Chicken, Beef Lo Mein, Chicken Fried Rice and Chicken with Veggies, and let me tell you I was in heaven!Good job See Thru Kitchen, I will be ordering from you soon!

4.description: I've been a fan of Mayflower nearby, but when a co-worker offered to buy carry-out from this place in return for a favor, I wanted to try it. My benchmark dish for a Chinese place has always been General Tso's chicken, so that is what I ordered.I arrived to pick up the order, which was ready right on time. This is primarily a carry-out business, squeezed into a corner of the strip mall across from Aldi on Pulaski. A few day laborers standing around looked on. I think they saw my bag of food and got a whiff of it.I brought it in and opened it up. I have to admit this place does not skimp. The entire clamshell container was packed to the top with chicken and fried rice. The chicken... it was OK. They say it is hot and spicy on the menu, but to me it was barely distinguishable from orange chicken, perhaps a bit soggy. They did not pass my General Tso chicken test. I added hot pepper flakes to enhance the meal, something I would not need to do at Mayflower. However, their fried rice was better than I've had anywhere in a long time. Little bits of chicken mixed in throughout gave it excellent flavor too. Egg roll was decent, but not superb.I ate about one-third of the package before I was full. In the end, I had 2 more leftover meals from that package. For the money, it's a great value and it was crisper when I reheated it in my broiler.To sum it up, See Thru is an OK place.  I was not disappointed either. I'd be willing to try more dishes to get the bigger picture. But for now, Mayflower remains my preferred Chinese joint in the area.

24.description: Albany Park Chinese delivery powered by GrubHub.Crab Rangoon Appetizer $6.00 - I must have accidentally ordered 10 crab rangoon but at 60 cents a clip I can't complain. Big and crispy, the taste and texture do the job right.Shrimp Toast $4.35 - 8 pieces of shrimp toast, but the shrimp toast is cut into diagonally triangles so is more like half the size of regular shrimp toast but there are 8 pieces to compensate. Tastes like condensed milk or coconut butter under the ground shrimp so it's a tasty treat!General Tso's Chicken special $5.25 - Blech! 2 stars the breading is very poor and it doesn't taste right. Shrimp fried rice has big pieces of shrimp in it but the rice is a bit overcooked. This chicken is not very good! :(Overall speedy delivery and reasonable pricing. Big portions so the dollar for dollar value is there versus almost every other type of food. Ace appetizers, but tastes like General Tso lost the battle :(

6.description: Not sure why the reviews are so low. This is 5 stars. So much food for cheap and it's so good! Best chinese since I've moved here. I ordered delivery and it go here within a half hour and I love the ability to order via yelp. Definitely a new favorite!

22.description: Ugh! What a MAJOR disappointment! we ordered delivery from this place. They did get it here fast but that is where the good ended and the terror began.I ordered a fried shrimp/crab rangoon combo which came with shrimp fried rice. I did not receive shrimp fried rice I received pork fried rice and it was way too greasy and clumpy and was not that good. The fried shrimp was more of a shrimp flavored ball of dough. the crab rangoons were slightly over done. Our cans of soda expired early this year! I will give them credit. The wonton soup was good and fully loaded. i wold have to say that it was more loaded with wontons than any other soup that I have had.The wonton soup and the fast delivery could not make up for all of the other issues that we had with our dinner. I am hoping that these guys just had a bad day. If there was not not 100's of Chinese restaurants to try in the city, I may consider giving these guys a second chance. With the choices available to me, this place lost me for good.

15.description: OMG I love this place, order from there all the time, Orange chicken is my go to, I love the egg rolls too! The Delivery Guy is a trip lol

7.description: We ordered from here through GrubHub last Saturday.  They had a good deal on the Family Dinner for Two that was under $20. Delivery took a little more than a hour to arrive. The dinner included chicken wings, egg rolls, crab rangoon, wonton soup, sweet and sour chicken, fried rice, and beef kow. The fried rice and beef kow were both very good. Good flavors and you can tell it was freshly cooked. The fried items were probably in old grease or fried too long.  The egg rolls and the sweet and sour chicken had a greasy, oily flavor.  One thing stood out - the chicken wing. It was very juicy and flavorful. My fiance, however, was not a fan and said it was not his thing.

8.description: Best Chinese Place in the City! If you're craving some real Chinese you should come here! They're fried rice and satay beef are the best in Chicago if you ask me!

3.description: In the past I've found gems inside of dumps, so I keep looking and looking, hoping to find more... gems.  I didn't find one here.  When I had the take-out in the car on the ride home, there was a smell of sweet emanating from something.  It's reminiscent of Chinese-buffet-grade sweet and sour sauce.(Or maybe it's cheap Hoisin?)  That smell is not appetizing to me and I instantly thought, "this shit ain't gonna be good."Suffice it to say, it wasn't.  I felt bloated and cheated afterwards.  If I was a starving student, I still wouldn't eat here.  Rather, I'd run over to Jewel and buy a salad.Chinese take-out spot in a tiny strip mall next to a fast food joint.  The inside is dirty and with a name like "see thru Chinese Kitchen", there isn't much to see goin' on in that damn kitchen.  This place could use a good moppin', or better yet, an industrial grade steamer to steam the fuck out of the place.  It's cheap, affordable and they give you a decent portion of food.

14.description: We ordered from this place the other night. Some of it was "ok" and some of it mediocre. The pork fried rice was ok, as were the rib and beef appetizers. The egg rolls were lousy, chewy and lacking in flavor and the Mongolian beef was greasy and over loaded with onions. I have no desire for a repeat performance. There are much better alternatives.

1.description: I don't own a restaurant, but my friend does and so I jumped at the chance to run an errand for him to see what goes down on the inside. Well, imagine a food-only Costco with massive steel dollies and about anything your little culinary heart could desire. It's like a wonderland of what you need to get your restaurant up and running for the day. You do have to pay for the stuff, but it's wholesale pricing since you buy in extreme bulk. I haven't been to any other stores like this, but I will say it's laid out in an idiot proof fashion and although the lines get extremely long at check out, they work magic to keep 'em moving in an orderly fashion. Not sure what the membership dues are, but if you can grab a friends card and need to purchase a jar of pickles the size the Bean Restaurant Depot is where it's at.

9.description: I hate this place. The management is horrible and treat their staff poorly. It is it organized very well and ownership does not really invest into the store. Indiana there isn't one thing I hate about my job more than the requirement that I come here twice per week

23.description: As a restaurant owner, we shop there twice weekly for produce, etc., and you can't beat the freshness.  I love going into the super size refrigerated rooms in the summer for fresh vegies  and it's a great place for meat and poultry.   Of course, you need a food and/or liquor business license to even go thru the door, but it basically has every supply you would ever need for the food industry.  The check out lines can be long and tedious and it never ceases to amaze me how surly those check-out girls can be.  There are new ones all the time...I guess it's hard to find good help in the area.  And, oh yeah, they need a better staff in small wares.

12.description: love this place for the selection and prices!

21.description: this place is AMAZING!  Went here for the first time yesterday.  Luckily, we were with a regular shopper who was able to show us around.  I could have spent all day in here, really.  Where else can you buy a 150lb wheel of cheese or an ENTIRE frozen lamb?? yeahWish they had a little more variety in the bulk molasses and liquid smoke.  The liquid smoke I picked out, "Castella Hickory Smoke," around $5 for a gallon, turned out to be absolutely DISGUSTING!  Anything you'll ever need for your restaurant/bar is here.  Went at 5pm on a Wednesday, the place was pretty empty and NO LINES!

16.description: Beware of people in a hurry with big carts.I could spend hours in here just wandering around and thinking about things to do with a 50 lb bag of chili peppers and a vat of mustard.  Now so will you.I found a big box of Andouille that was cheap-o and not half bad.Other words of advice:  -don't go on a holiday weekend -keep your food geekery in check and don't gawk (yes, that is a WHOLE goat) -don't block the aislesGet yourself an industry hook-up and go!

17.description: Until I got my membership to this place, I thought Costco was the King of the super size.  not even close.Want a 25 lb. solid block of chocolate?  Sure... milk or dark?  Want a box of assorted plastic flatware...1500 pieces?  Sure...white or black?  Medium or heavy weight?  The list goes on.  It's membership for people in the industry only, but tag along with a friend.  That 25 lb block of chocolate is gonna be my gag gift for a few this coming holiday season.  :-)

10.description: This place is great for business owners.  An amazing selection of everything.  When we went here, they had a bunch of samples right when you walked in.  Give yourself a lot of time your first time here..... you'll need it!  Also, grab some ice packs for your cold goods on the way out, a lifesaver when it hits 100 degrees!

5.description: I love it here, I love it here, oh yes I do, I love it here.  Not really anything else much to say at the moment.  It's heaven for me.  I also appreciate how NICE they are to me all the time.  Because they are.

11.description: Looking to snag yourself a sexy Chicago chef??  Then come here on a weekday around noon-ish, when this place is full of local chefs buying everything from #5 containers of mascarpone, whole fish, live lobsters, and ginormous rolls of plastic wrap.  Their prices are very good.  $2.50 for a quart of cream!   A pint at the grocery store costs more than that.  The store is huge and you will get lost.  So ask the nearest hunky chef to help you out and be sure to get the name of the restaurant he works at.

22.description: Looking to snag yourself a sexy Chicago chef??  Then come here on a weekday around noon-ish, when this place is full of local chefs buying everything from #5 containers of mascarpone, whole fish, live lobsters, and ginormous rolls of plastic wrap.  Their prices are very good.  $2.50 for a quart of cream!   A pint at the grocery store costs more than that.  The store is huge and you will get lost.  So ask the nearest hunky chef to help you out and be sure to get the name of the restaurant he works at.

0.description: If you work in the restaurant industry in the Chicago area, then it's likely that you'll have hit up Restaurant Depot AKA Jetro. This is a true warehouse that offers fresh, frozen, meats, fruits, veggies, beverages, containers, etc. - all in bulk.This is not Costco, so don't come looking for a TV or a mattress. If you're a serious restauranteur, then this is where anybody that works the kitchen goes. Need a 100 lb bag of rice? Check. How about a box of 9,000 napkins? Good. How about an entire box of chicken breast? OK, let's roll.If you're still on board with all this, some words of advice... pull the cart. Don't push it.

20.description: Dude. It's like the Disneyland of all things wholesale food and booze... A complete redefining of the happiest place on Earth. Fabulously expansive, ridiculously cheap, amazingly stocked. Love, Love, Love. I could spend hours here.... and I have!! Where else can you seek out a 70lb wheel of Grana Padano calling your name (loudly) at a mere $4.00 p/lb, an actual block of Plugra European butter for just a buck, a whole box of Andouille sausage for $7... the list goes on. They have fresh produce up the ying yang, an array of proteins, utensils, breads, pastries, catering mumbo jumbo, beer, liquor, condiments, canned goods, super high end frozen seafood, Eli's cheesecakes, drums of hot sauce, chocolate sauce, weak sauce - kidding - and all of the above at an absolute fraction of the price of it's closest competitor, Costco. So why just 4 stars? Because it's a private wholesale establishment accessible to restaurant owners and caterers ONLY. If you don't have the special 'get into the depot' provided card, then you ain't gettin' in Sucka! I'm not lucky enough to have said card, but fortunately, I have a great friend that does and hooks me up on occasion generously. Do yourself a favor and find a friend like this STAT!!! If you do get in, take note: people here will literally run you over and not think twice - they're looking to get in, get out, and get back to their restaurant with their newly acquired awesome goods. While you may be all wide-eyed and bushy-tailed at the splendor that is the depot, the regulars don't take kindly to rubberneckers. Look the part... Walk fast, stay to your side of an aisle and stock up on the Boucheron Goat Cheese sitting behind you for pennies on the dollar.

19.description: this place is AMAZING!  Went here for the first time yesterday.  Luckily, we were with a regular shopper who was able to show us around.  I could have spent all day in here, really.  Where else can you buy a 150lb wheel of cheese or an ENTIRE frozen lamb?? yeahWish they had a little more variety in the bulk molasses and liquid smoke.  The liquid smoke I picked out, "Castella Hickory Smoke," around $5 for a gallon, turned out to be absolutely DISGUSTING!  Anything you'll ever need for your restaurant/bar is here.  Went at 5pm on a Wednesday, the place was pretty empty and NO LINES!

2.description: When I was 3, my cousin Jutta came to visit from East Germany. She applied for a tourist visa with her husband but they refused to let him travel with her because they feared they wouldn't return.The Berlin Wall was still up in 1988 and times were tough. If you complained about meat being overcooked, my grandpa, who fought in WWII would say, "It's tougher where there isn't any!" Well, as a satellite state of the Soviet Union, there really wasn't jack shit in the GDR. They were supposedly a Demokratische Republik but communism had them in an iron curtain chokehold.It was abundantly apparent how cut off they were from the rest of the civilized world if you took a tour of their grocery stores. Shortages of what we'd consider easily accessible goods were the norm and there was little to no variety because of the government's refusal to import. After standing in long lines, you pretty much had to take what you could get, and that was assuming there was anything left to be given.While my cousin was in town, my aunt showed her around. A regular grocery store wasn't on the list of American attractions to familiarize her with, but it's one place they happened to stop and she wept when she saw all the choices. My mom joked it was a good thing she hadn't taken her to Byerly's because she probably would have completely lost it in an upscale supermarket that boasts live lobsters and carpeted floors.I'm here to say that it's a far better thing we didn't have an "in" with Restaurant Depot / Jetro Cash & Carry at the time because Jutta most definitely would have had a "Moscow on the Hudson" style breakdown of epic proportions (myspace.com/youremembert…).Granted, there might not be as many brands as you'd find in conventional shops, but just about everything is sold in bulk and the place is packed with row after row of top to bottom shelving stocked with candies, canned goods, whole animals, jugs of cooking oils and spices, giant containers of condiments, and perhaps the epitome of capitalism, Coca-Cola by the case. This is pretty much where savvy restaurateurs in the Chicagoland area come to get almost all of their cooking needs met.This is a giant wholesale warehouse and you can only get in if you're associated with the restaurant/catering/foodservice industry and have their membership card. It's meant to be a place away from the public eye where owners and employees can come to purchase items they use in their places of business.  It puts Sam's Club and Costco to shame in the food department. Tell me where else you can get a dressed lamb for $80 or a laundry hamper sized bag of green peppers for a couple bucks. My most memorable purchase was a 10lb slab of beef Ribeye for about $40.By no stretch of the imagination is this store pretty, but it is practical. Items are relatively easy to locate, but the checkout line can be a hassle. The cashiers ring everything up and often times there's some type of pricing error that needs to be fixed and/or they make you wait for a security person to count out the items individually. The time it takes is annoying mostly because many of the products are perishable and waiting around in line doesn't do them any good. Luckily they have pretty good business hours of operation, so you can sometimes plan to do your shopping during quieter times.

18.description: Might be a great place for cheap pricing, but if you are a current customer I suggest you check you bank account .. the company data records were hacked last month and RD is now just sending out letters informing customers that their personal bank accounts may have been compromised.  kmov.com/news/just-poste…restaurantdepot.com/Cust…

13.description: Two lies I have told myself: A) I loathe exclusivity. Actually, I like it when it includes me. B) I dislike mega-stores-they raise my blood pressure. Restaurant Depot makes me a liar on both counts. It is restricted to those in the food business, but every visit is for me a trip to Disneyland. This place is SO huge, it's Costco on steroids. And of course, it has BIG portions of just about everything (but you can still buy a small can of beans, too.) You have to take a large trailer type thing if you are going to buy more than you can carry. There are no mini-carts because many customers are buying for hundreds and shopping for a restaurant week. There are wheels of cheese so large I could use them as spare tires for my Scion. And the biggest jars of pickles and olives you have ever seen.  The inner square of the place is surrounded with 30' sheets of thick plastic curtain, because it is one humungous refrigerator room that you can walk around in. Like you're an ant and you wandered into your own fridge. Very freaky!Needless to say, the prices are great. Some items are 25% of what you might pay in a grocery store. Some are not, But it almost makes it worth jumping through all the hoops you need to to become a caterer or a small food biz, so you can take little day trips to this culinary Disneyland. They allow you to bring friends and family, and they are friendlier and more helpful than Mickey and Goofy and Snow White combined.I take back everything negative thing I've said about big box stores. I LOVE this place!!!  And having that special card which lets me in.

4.description: I walk by the front of this place twice a day in the amount of garbage in front of their parking lot disgusts me. Take care of your property. The inside is also messy and unorganized

24.description: A warehouse store that does require a membership, this location specializes in foods for restaurants and stores. We've come here with my husband's card from work and gotten some deals on pop, meat (froze a ton) and syrup for making Lattes. Fun to shop once, if you can get in.

6.description: Thank the Lord for RD. It's not often in life (at least, it's not for me) that one has need of 50000 gallons of lemonade, 34956078 plates, 338 lbs of popcorn, numerous assorted other items, and more napkins than you can shake a stick (or a forest; oh, the irony) at. But, I found myself there. And, I was near to lose my mind. Seriously.Since I had not yet met Panda to represent for me (I am in love; youtube.com/watch?v=X21m…), I had the next best thing: a friend with a membership, room in his car and time to spare. If you come here, come ready. Come ready to work out (the carts are big, the produce is big and the bulk is heavy), come ready to deal with temps (large amount of cold and frozen goods = wear covered shoes and long sleeves), come with a purpose (this place is too big and too packed with people to dawdle; stay focused and committed to your mission), and come with good credit (even though everything is priced at cost, when you're buying q959w34rt number of items, you need a lot of cash or, in the alternative, a freakum dress and hooker heels).All in a days work, people. Let's keep it moving.

15.description: Dude. It's like the Disneyland of all things wholesale food and booze... A complete redefining of the happiest place on Earth. Fabulously expansive, ridiculously cheap, amazingly stocked. Love, Love, Love. I could spend hours here.... and I have!! Where else can you seek out a 70lb wheel of Grana Padano calling your name (loudly) at a mere $4.00 p/lb, an actual block of Plugra European butter for just a buck, a whole box of Andouille sausage for $7... the list goes on. They have fresh produce up the ying yang, an array of proteins, utensils, breads, pastries, catering mumbo jumbo, beer, liquor, condiments, canned goods, super high end frozen seafood, Eli's cheesecakes, drums of hot sauce, chocolate sauce, weak sauce - kidding - and all of the above at an absolute fraction of the price of it's closest competitor, Costco. So why just 4 stars? Because it's a private wholesale establishment accessible to restaurant owners and caterers ONLY. If you don't have the special 'get into the depot' provided card, then you ain't gettin' in Sucka! I'm not lucky enough to have said card, but fortunately, I have a great friend that does and hooks me up on occasion generously. Do yourself a favor and find a friend like this STAT!!! If you do get in, take note: people here will literally run you over and not think twice - they're looking to get in, get out, and get back to their restaurant with their newly acquired awesome goods. While you may be all wide-eyed and bushy-tailed at the splendor that is the depot, the regulars don't take kindly to rubberneckers. Look the part... Walk fast, stay to your side of an aisle and stock up on the Boucheron Goat Cheese sitting behind you for pennies on the dollar.

7.description: If you own a restaurant or nightclub, Restaurant Depot has the same euphoria as that Costco has to their members.Upon entering, you will need to swipe your membership card, then you can proceed to shop.  This warehouse has it all.... liquor, meats, canned foods, fresh vegetables, flowers, and any type of cooking wares you may need or want.The warehouse is very well thought out and planned.  The aisles are wide.  The prices seem to be very reasonable for the quantity that you may be required to purchase.  The carts are a little hard to maneuver but manageable.It's a cool place to go to if you have a chance.

8.description: The pacific romaine lettuce ( pink package) is disgusting. The packages are full with flies, and I mean not small fruit flies. Large disgusting flies! Does someone have to get seriously sick before they discontinue selling it? These flies cary parasites and some of them were still alive when I opened the package. Its unbelievable! Do NOT ever buy lettuce from there is my advice!

3.description: Is it possible to fall madly in love with a store??  It has to be, I'm in love with Restaurant Depot.  My main squeeze WAS Costco, but sadly, Costco and I may have to cool it because I can feel that I will be spending more and more time with my new main squeeze Restaurant Depot.I was literally dizzy when I went in here, so much to see, so much I wanted - all in one location.  Baking supplies, baking ingredients, tons of cheeses, frozen products section to die for, candy in bulk (not just typical stuff, but some candy I didn't even know they sold in bulk - anywhere)!  Great selection of containers (which come in handy during the holidays - family can take leftovers home in "to-go" containers, not my Tupperware.I loved that although most stuff is sold in large bulk - there were many items that could be purchased individually... like the loaf of Gonnella bread, and the bottle of Chili Lime Cholula.  But for other stuff that is sold in large quantities - it's a great opportunity to pitch in with family an share the bounty.I am lucky that I know someone with a membership - so I can tag along while they get their stuff...this place is the BOMB!

14.description: I have a love/hate relationship with Depot.  I love it when I want to go there and look for lots of awesome stuff to make my life easier or to help a friend or to assist a client in all their event planning needs.  I hate it when I have to go there because someone forgot to order one or two of the things that are essential to operating a kitchen or executing an event.Open to the trade only, it is the Mecca of the small business owner/restauranteur/caterer.  Prices often less than the big bully on the playground Sysco and frequent sales that make me wish I had a freezer the size of a football field.  Need disposable tongs? A chafing dish? 5 to 1 Vienna beef hot dogs? A goat? BSBs (that's boneless, skinless breasts of chicken to you folks)  Yeah this is the place.  50 pounds of onions, carrots or Japanese Panko?  Yep, its here.In a hurry? Don't bother, as it can be a time consuming process. One should always remember to wear appropriate jacket if you plan on spending any amount of time in the refrigerated section and you have breasts.  Just saying, although for some reason, the guys are extremely helpful when I forget.   Bring cash, and make sure everything has a bar code otherwise you will be shocked by the cashier screaming "I NEED A NUMBER!"

3.description: The service is worse than the post office. I would put zero stars or negative if I could. WORST customer service ever. The employees make rude remarks about the customers in front of other customers. They find every excuse not to help you make a return even with a receipt for unworn shoes purchased one week ago.

1.description: Take it from these pass reviews, customer service, there is no customer service. We came in wanting to buy some house slippers, I needed to use the wash room; "OH OUR RESTROOM IS BROKEN" come on, that's pure bull$Hia, either way, the way the guy with the braids acted was as if we were a bother to him, didn't really want to help or reach out. I've been going here since I was a kid, never again. Don't limit yourself or sell yourself short by going to a place with NO CUSTOMER service, they treat you like Sh5. trust me.

2.description: This place sucks when it comes to returning or exchanging. The workers don't want to deal with you because they are lazy and make up a sorry about how they don't have the shoe your trying to exchange. This location has let me down twice. Won't come back here again.

9.description: Eh 3 stars cause I went in here once and the selection of shoes is not that great.

10.description: I HATE SHOE SHOPPING!  Hate, hate, hate, hate it!!  It has nothing to do with the stores that sell the shoes, it is, well to be honest, it is my feet.  I do not like them & shoe shopping makes me look at them.  I have the flattest feet in the known world (I challenge anyone to a flat foot contest--bring it!).  There is no part of my foot that does not touch the floor--so finding shoes is a challenge.  Not to mention, I also have wide feet and they are frigging size 10--yep--I am BOZO the clown in the feet category.  Well, all that said, I will say that I have had some decent (not stellar) shoe shopping experiences at this particular store.  Yes, I know it is a chain, but hey--sometimes you need to do a little chain shopping.  Normally I think they are little expensive for what they offer and let's be honest, they are just a step above Payless.  I was on a mission on this trek into shoe shopping, I needed to find a pair of shoes that would compliment my 70's retro vibe for the Spring Fling event at Catalyst Ranch (so fun by the way!!).  I was feeling the pressure because it was the day before said event and I had not had any success on my previous excursions.  The stress was mounting as I entered the store--I needed to find something and Payless had already let me down.  So, I wandered around the store.  Sales associated greeted me nicely and then left me alone.  This is good, because I hate when they follow you around and make you feel like a criminal and Famous Footwear has a bad habit of doing that--they bug the crap out of me with that.  One turn around the store & my heart sank; I saw nothing that would fit my 70's garb.  I took at gander at their clearance stuff; they have a decent selection over there, but yet nothing.  I was about to despair, when I decided--"let me take another, slower look" and then BAM, I turned the corner into the 1st aisle and there they were: beautiful pair of black cork platform shoes, with gold trim and you want to know the kicker--they were on sale for $15.  It could not be true, had I found the shoes?!?!?!  I went over and grabbed a pair of size 10's thinking--they are not going to fit or they were going to be uncomfortable.  I am happy to report that I was wrong on both counts--boo to the YEAH!  I walked up to the counter, the sales person smiled at me, finished my purchase and I was on my merry way.  Famous you did me right this time and I thank you!  So, the moral of the story kids is this, even though you might like doing something, you can be rewarded for doing it and be very happy with the result.

4.description: I have bought a pair of shoes a week ago from this store. I wore the shoe twice to work and realized that the left shoe was defective. Took it back to the store to get a replacement, the manager said: "All of those shoes are like that, since you wore them we can not take it back". Manager acknowledging that the shoes are defective, yet refusing to do something about it, its just disappointing to see those store open.I recommend to all of you not to buy shoes from them as you will be wasting your money as I did.Remember no returns are not acceptable on the defective product because they can not sell them to anyone else!! Consumers be aware!!

6.description: I went in the store intending to buy three pairs of sandals for my boys but they didn't have a great selection at all. Just a few pairs to choose from but they didn't offer a variety of sizes. Although is was a very large store, there were only a couple of employees and they were busy helping other customers. My family and I waited a while to see if anyone offered help but it didn't happen. We ended up leaving and finding what we needed at the store in the mall, half a mile north of this location.

11.description: I am in Love with shoes and will have to satisfy my shoe love elsewhere.  Everytime I go in there, the associates are grouped in small masses in the front and giggling and gossiping. The cashier pays no attention to the customer at hand and converses on her cell phone or with another associate while she ignores her customer. I've asked for assistance in finding a shoe and have been met with tooth sucking, sighs, and directional head jerks to indicate what area of the store I should look in. I especially loved the day I was followed around the store the entire time as I watched a mother/daughter team load up a couple pair and waltz out. But hey, maybe they dont need my money....so I'll just go elsewhere.

12.description: I think the prices at Famous Footwear are actually comprable to Payless but the quality is way better. They have lots of trendy footwear here and the selection is great. You'll find lots of different shoes here -- from partywear to workwear.

5.description: Shoes bay-bey!When I originally wrote the quick tip above I was excited because I had heard of the on going boot sale...However, I was bummed because the selection available was disappointing...Not much to pick from...nothing to catch my eye boot or not...Won't be back, sorry Famous!

7.description: I just went to the grand opening in Heber City Utah today August 4, 2012.  The store had people handing out fliers at the local fair and were telling us about a promotion that could be combined.  When I got to the store, an employee behind the counter confirmed that the promotion was correct and could be combined.When I tried to check out, the store manager told me that the offers could not be combined and that she had told the employees to stop telling customers that it could.  I was in shock at how poor of customer service this store has and would never shop there again.  The store manager handled the situation very poorly and was rude to me and my kids.  Also beware that Famous Footwear will trick you with their buy one get one half off sale.  You think that if you buy two pairs of shoes for $80 that the second pair would be $40, but it is not if you purchase more items than 2, they apply the discount to the cheapest item you buy.  This would have cost me over $50 if I had not noticed and make separate purchases.This store is a real looser!  Do not shop at Famous Footwear.  Bad customer service and bad ethics!

8.description: Famous Footwear is a miniature DSW. That being said, the selection is so-so. The prices are about the same. I've rarely found great deals at DSW. Famous Footwear has the occasional Buy One, Get One 50% and 20% Off Item/Total Purchase. Famous Footwear has a unique, wonderful service that no other shoe store offers... HOME DELIVERY.If you can't find your size or style in the store, Famous Footwear will find it online (at the nearest store) and ship it to your home ...... FOR FREE.That's right. FREE. It's wonderful.Too many times have I found a pair of shoes that I love, but my size (representin' 9.5M/N. Woot woot!) is out of stock. I hate it, hate it, HATE IT when that happens!Sometimes I cheat by shopping online at their website and going to a physical store to get free shipping. Shhhh! I just really hate paying for shipping (on top of Chicago's sale tax). So yeah, there's plenty of parking and enough shoes to browse and try on. Don't expect jaw-dropping prices for most shoes ($5 off a pair of $80 shoes isn't really a sale). Their home delivery service, while it takes a week to ship, is pretty cool.

0.description: Famous footwear at times has some decent prices on footwear, most of the time when a sale is going on.  Often times you can find many of their Madden shoes for men at a great price when it's on sale of course.The drawback is the store associates that often seem disheartened of their job or just never available.  I'm boxing my shoes, checking shelves, sizing, and more etc.  Seldom do I get any assistance or store associates that care enough to ask.

1.description: This place is unbelievable.  I used to walk by the "Everything for $3" sign and be very wary, but now my girlfriend and I have been in at least three or four times and every time we end up buying something!The inventory changes every week, and the owner can only be described as fabulous!   He is extremely nice, helpful and zero pressure, which is always appreciated.Most importantly, it is actually $3 for everything (including dresses, suit jackets, pants, shoes, you name it!).They have been closed for remodeling for a couple of months now, and I can't wait until they reopen!  It's the kind of local business you want to support, and with such great service and prices, it's hard not to.

2.description: Stumbled across Liquidation Direct today on my way to check out the Brown Elephant Resale store, the first thing that caught my eyes were the $3 EVERYTHING!! MON-SUN 10-7PM signs! $3 for every item? Seriously?  I gotta check this out!The cashier (sorry I missed your name!) was super nice, explained on the specials going on today (Men's tee:  3 for $3... for real?!?) and offered to store my heavy bags from Brown Elephant behind the counter!  Brownie Points for excellent service, checked!The store was neatly arranged, with Women's Clothing on the left and Men's on the right. Note that Liquidations Direct is actually a resale store, combined with some factory outflow clothing, so you will see a mix of Old & New items.   But even the 2nd hand clothing were in great condition! There were 2 racks of new DVDs, everything from "The Blue Collar Comedy" to "Blood Diamond" to "songs from Sex & The City," Relatively new titles (2003+) so definitely better selections than your Jewels' Walmart stores. Overall, Women's Clothing had a great variety of casual / office wear. The sizes leaned on S-M sizes, and some clothing did appear more outdated in terms of style / cutting. They had a great collection of office shirts / blouses though, and at $3 for Banana Republic tops, you can't beat the price!   There were some great shoes / heels as well, back to the basics and definitely staples for the wardrobe. Shoes were typically Sz 7+ , so I didn't find any that fit my small feet =(  The dress section was definitely lacking.... outdated dresses with styles / patterns from my mom's generation, may be good for a costume party?On the Men's side, there was a GREAT selection of long-sleeve shirts and pants. Found a lot of great brands (Armani, Dockers) and the $3 price tag is cheaper than most Men's pants I've seen, even at Salvation Army Stores!!   The t-shirts were lacking, definitely worn out and mostly event-based logo tees, didn't find any known brands on the rack at all.   One thing to note for the guy's section, you can find neat suspenders and wacky ties here!  I saw some new leather shoes with minimal scuffing too, definitely a bargain!Liquidations Direct seem to have better selection for men than women. You will find great steals for Hawaiian-themed parties or the Rolling Twenties, here!  Ultimately, you can't beat the $3 price tag + amazing service!!

0.description: AWESOME!!I've been to this store only once and always referred to it as 'The $3 Everything store', I never realized it did have a name.  It was a little over a year ago and it seemed small but nevertheless, this place was stuffed with as many clothes as your local Goodwill store.  I was expecting average, obsolete clothes but I came across some amazing vintage designer ties, cufflinks, jackets and pants.  The t-shirts were mostly sponsored event tee's although sweaters were great, I grabbed an amazing simple ralph lauren cashmere sweater that can fit for any event.  This place also has some zany articles of clothing and accessories you could use to spark up your outfit or use for great halloween costumes, theme parties, etc.  The women's side of the store had a lot of everything! So many shoes although I wasn't really paying attention to brand or size while looking for anything.  Being a guy, I was admiring all the fabrics of different kind.  The man working the store is extremely nice.  I have not one thing to say bad about this second-hand store, definitely the best in the city by far that I've come across in any neighborhood.  I have no clue as to why I've not gone back.  Honestly probably due to the fact I'm extremely lethargic.

58.description: 1 WORD- GROSS!!!!!!!!!!!!! ribs over cooked and tough, greasy egg rolls, pork slop mixture, desert; yuk!!  stomach doesnt feel so gud right now:(

56.description: It's cheap. There's a lot of it. However, is this amazing Filipino food? No. The crispy pata is my favorite only because that is the only thing that I remember.  Save your heart, pass on this mediocre food.

29.description: I wanted so badly to like this place, I really did.  First of all, it was my Philippine-born parents' idea to come here.  I thought, "Homecooked Filipino meals are so much better than a restaurant."  But of course, I gave in because I am, after all, a child that respects her elders.Unfortunately, for me, my elders are not discerning enough when it comes to food.  Or maybe they are just forgiving of their countrymen.  Being first generation Filipino-American, I have grown up with authentic Philippine cuisine made with love by my mother and grandmother.  To me, my family's cooking is the ultimate comfort food.Sadly, Little Quiapo does not come anywhere close to comfort.  Read Gladies H.'s review and she hits the nail on the head.  What more can I say, but...MOM, COOK ME SOME PORK ADOBO!!!If only my Aunt Ruby would listen to me and open up a restaurant.  Then maybe the rest of you could taste what I'm talking about!

42.description: I ate on a Friday night. I don't know the names of any dishes, so bear with me!Most of the foods were not too interesting to me, and some items weren't so fresh. The garlic fried rice and chicken adobo were good but not my favorites (I've never had the adobo anywhere else). The filipino style spaghetti was good, but I can't handle sweet too much and only had a few bites.The following dishes were my favorite. 1. Fried fish - salty, chewy, YUM. 2. Fried prawns. Delicious. I dipped this in the vinegar sauce and sweet n sour sauce. We filled up the steel bowl on the table with shrimp shells.3. Mussels 4. Vegetable dish with eggplants and bitter melon.  OMG bitter melon, paired with my other favorite veg. I felt like I won the lottery.5. Rice balls were amazing. They're kind of fermented and sweet and similar to a Chinese dish I love.The fried squid was good, too, but lately I've been kind of scared of squid and octopus in its entire form.Many of the desserts were very purple and coconut or taro based.The cassava cake was delicious. You'll love it if you like sweet condensed milk.I enjoyed it, but at $13, I'd rather go to my favorite Chinese buffet.

23.description: I don't trust cheap buffets and Filipino's should know that our food isn't exactly "cheap" to make considering ingredients and labor... especially in bulk! My parents buttered me up and told me "you should try this place! It has good Filipino food!" Boy, was I a sucker. We came in and got sat by a LOUD LOUD LOUD annoying LOUD speaker in the back room playing REALLY LOUD Filipino music. You don't have a server. Just some dude who goes around (rarely) pouring water into your glass. When you want to order something you have to drink you have to flag him down. I know, FIRST WORLD PROBLEMS, right? But man it don't need to be THAT difficult to order a can of coke. The place smells of old frying oil. That's never a good thing. The food - I don't think I saw anything with vegetables except the sinigang. This place is definitely not for people who love their vegetables. You won't find much. Everything is meat. Pork, mostly. The food didn't taste great. It was "okay" in the lowest grade that "okay" could be graded. I saw some kids playing around grabbing their own food and fruit and sneezing on things so I kind of stayed away from all of that. I came home after trying ALL their dishes (I at least tried to find something I liked) and I felt really gross. I couldn't look at anything fried pork related for about a week. I still think back about my experience and I get grossed out and gag a little thinking about it. So two stars from me. So my final thoughts.Don't come here if you have heart problems or are diabetic.You may not enjoy this if you like your own Filipino food and think this was a waste of your time. If you're a broke college kid who hasn't had mom's home cooking in the longest time you just might love this place. Don't trust buffets that are cheap.

47.description: Worst place ever the food just sucked!!

8.description: I love this place! Makes me feel like I'm with my family. The lumpia is almost as good as mine but it definitely is still very good. All of the food was great and it wasn't very packed so we had choice of great seating. We went right when they opened so the food was very fresh and full!

31.description: The buffet is served on a custom-made jeepney (the transport of choice in the urban areas of the Philippines).  Instead of seating 20 patrons on their way to work uncomfortably, it holds all the Filipino food staples one needs to satiate his/her needs on a Sunday morning after church.  And...as if that were not enough, there are four more stations of food!  Here's what your stomach is up against an an average Sunday:The Jeepney:- Steamed and fried rice- Chicken adobo and bbq chicken- Bistek (beef and onions)- Pancit bihon and pancit palabok- Kare-kare (slow cooked beef in peanut sauce with veggies)- Dinuguan (with puto)- Arroz caldo (rice porridge)- Pinakbet (Mixed veggies with shrimp paste)The steaming soup station:- Sinigang (sour tamarind soup)- Clam soup (clam broth with ginger)- Tinola (chicken broth with ginger)The fried food station:- Veggie and beef lumpia egg rolls- Fried fish and shrimp- Calamari- Fried chicken skin- AND, the full array of possible sauces...The pigout station:- Crispy pata (pork knuckles)- Lechon (whole roasted pig, chopped into bite size peices)The dessert station:- Maja blanca- Leche flan- Sapin-sapin- Casava cake- Binignit (which I know is called other things for other regions, but this is basically coconut milk warmed with sugar and bits of fruit and sweet potatoes.  Delicious!)Ultimately, it's a bit more on the quantity than quality side of the equation, but no matter who are you are with, someone will find something they love in the buffet (save vegetarians!)Don't be put off by the plastic tablecloths and strange display thing at the entrance of the dining room.  Stuffed gorillas and Santa dolls dressed in fishing gear overlooking bubble bath waterfalls are part of the Filipino allure (I guess).  Bathrooms need a serious upgrade...But heck!  You are here for the food and the colorful company, no?  Just eat!

34.description: I hate to update my review because I do enjoy the food.  However, my last experience made me change my mind to "A-OK".  I came in with my family and we were stared at the entire time! so uncomfortable & uncalled.  I have to assume it's  because we are not Filipino. I can't think of any other reason considering there were plenty of other people in the restaurant, but all eyes were on us. It seemed even more apparent when the table next to us were given little mints on a tray when their bill came, and we were just given the bill... it's the little things. I don't think I will be coming back here.

16.description: The buffet is served on a custom-made jeepney (the transport of choice in the urban areas of the Philippines).  Instead of seating 20 patrons on their way to work uncomfortably, it holds all the Filipino food staples one needs to satiate his/her needs on a Sunday morning after church.  And...as if that were not enough, there are four more stations of food!  Here's what your stomach is up against an an average Sunday:The Jeepney:- Steamed and fried rice- Chicken adobo and bbq chicken- Bistek (beef and onions)- Pancit bihon and pancit palabok- Kare-kare (slow cooked beef in peanut sauce with veggies)- Dinuguan (with puto)- Arroz caldo (rice porridge)- Pinakbet (Mixed veggies with shrimp paste)The steaming soup station:- Sinigang (sour tamarind soup)- Clam soup (clam broth with ginger)- Tinola (chicken broth with ginger)The fried food station:- Veggie and beef lumpia egg rolls- Fried fish and shrimp- Calamari- Fried chicken skin- AND, the full array of possible sauces...The pigout station:- Crispy pata (pork knuckles)- Lechon (whole roasted pig, chopped into bite size peices)The dessert station:- Maja blanca- Leche flan- Sapin-sapin- Casava cake- Binignit (which I know is called other things for other regions, but this is basically coconut milk warmed with sugar and bits of fruit and sweet potatoes.  Delicious!)Ultimately, it's a bit more on the quantity than quality side of the equation, but no matter who are you are with, someone will find something they love in the buffet (save vegetarians!)Don't be put off by the plastic tablecloths and strange display thing at the entrance of the dining room.  Stuffed gorillas and Santa dolls dressed in fishing gear overlooking bubble bath waterfalls are part of the Filipino allure (I guess).  Bathrooms need a serious upgrade...But heck!  You are here for the food and the colorful company, no?  Just eat!

13.description: This review is based off of service and cleanliness: Our recent visit was on a Sunday afternoon, right before the lunch rush. The place was already jammed packed and had a line waiting out the door for large parties. Our group of 3 adults and two infants were escorted to a corner right in front of a window. It was drafty in that area. The table was not wiped down. The floor was sticky and dirty. The high chairs they provided us had dried up chunks of food caked on there.  It took forever for someone to bring out ice waters and silverware for us.  And plate clearing? Forget about it. Our plates were stacked at our tables with no one to buss it.

11.description: Was here yesterday for lunch with mom, my cousin, and two sets of aunts and uncles.  There was plenty of room, but the place was not empty for a Wednesday.  The buffet was good and reminded me of being at a typical filipino party.  Sooo much good food!  The service was good too.  Very attentive. The only let down was the dessert table.  Some of the items were kind of dry.  So we ended up ordering the halo halo which made up everything.  Yes, it was that good.

39.description: This is not exactly my bread and butter.  I stick to Japanese or Thai when it comes to Asian foods.  That said, I've been through enough buffet style Asian joints that I know what is/isn't good.  The food here is ok, that's about the best word I could use...though my Filipino friends seemed to thoroughly enjoy it.  Hmm..  Lost in translation perhaps.  Not much in the way of service given the buffet style, but they did keep our drinks full and did an adequate job of keeping the food filled.  Favorite: pork yakitori.  Had a bunch of those, very good.

37.description: Went here on a Sunday afternoon with my boyfriend's family who are Filipino. We all really enjoyed this place. What I liked:-Garlic fried rice -Beef steak-Crispy pata..and the soy sauce onion dipping sauce was delicious-Lumpia-Filipino spaghetti (although a bit too sweet for me)-Fried fish-Sago (it is a sweet drink) had it other places and never really liked it, but I did enjoy it here-I loved the ginataan(warm soupy thing with the fruit). It was pretty funny seeing all the Filipinos flock over to the pot everytime the workers went to pour some more. What I didn't like:Kare kare - it was tripe and it just didn't taste the same without the ox tailsLechon - I felt like it wasn't flavorful at all and I much preferred the crispy pataTenola - It was very blandPancit - Too soggy and not enough flavorAll in all, if you are looking for some fast Filipino food and are craving multiple things this is the place to go. However, if you are craving a specific dish it is best to go to a Filipino restaurant or have someone cook it for you. Although there were some dishes I didn't like I was still satisfied.

0.description: Decent food. Some items taste bland. A moderate amount of food choices to pick from. Everything looks fresh.

38.description: I used to have many Filipino co-workers, and so I developed a taste for the wonderful dishes that they'd bring to office potlucks. Lumpia, pancit, chicken adobo... delicious! My hubby and I were going to a White Sox game with a colleague of his and his wife, and she, being Filipina, thought it'd be nice if we ate at Little Quiapo. Boy, oh boy, were we in for something! I'd never been surrounded by such an abundance of pork and starches in my whole life, and it was great! The BBQ skewers, pancit, lumpia, and lechon were great (some of it on the greasy side, though)! I dared myself to try some of the purple yam desserts and was delighted by them. I had to take a point off of this rating, though, because the pig head by the lechon table creeped the H-E- double hockey sticks out of me. I don't need to stare back at my lunch like that!

51.description: My friend said she had a taste for Filipino food and heard about this place. This place looks like it is stuck in the middle of a parking lot. Walked in and was seated right away and the waitress came over to take our drink orders. A few moments they arrived at our table along with the silverware. Two great cardinal sins were broken in my eyes, soda served in a can and no frigging knife. Like someone else wrote it is the buffet or nothing else, at no time was a menu spoken of. Like most Chinese buffets have some sort of American food on the buffet table, this place does not. It is Filipino food or nothing else. I did spot a few things that I have tasted before, so I felt a little safe. BBQ pork on a stick, without a knife to cut it off the stick, it was a task to eat due to fact it was hard to bite into. They has some plain Beef strips, that were just shy of becoming beef jerky. There was some big pieces, had to use my fingers to eat, it reminded me one of those Medieval Knight places. The lechon (pig) was too fatty and without that magical knife, had to swallow whole. Our server never visited the table after serving the drinks, we had to flag her down to get our check.  Two dinners and two cans of soda, $30.

27.description: The selection of foods is rather limited. Most dishes are like in typical Chinese places, such as fish and meats. The buffet is on expensive side. Their desserts are great. They are made of coconut. The place is populated with Filipinos. I would say between this restaurant and any Chinese buffet, simply choose Chinese. You will save more money and will taste a great variety of foods at the same time!

32.description: I really wanted to like this place but as a Filipino craving good ole Filipino cooking, this place failed miserably. Yes the space is a lot nicer than their previous location and the Jeepney buffet is cute but the food just isn't good. I had the lunch buffet here on a Monday afternoon and the food was not fresh. The Lechon was stale and not crispy, lumpia was flavorless, greasy and the oil that everything was fried in was tasted rancid. Hey LITTLE QUIAPO change the cooking oil regularly! In fact everything seemed to be overly greasy and tasted like it was prepared a week ago, refrigerated , and then reheated. This place needs a kitchen do over. Not good.

54.description: This place upgraded from the first spot they use to own! I like how they took the once old DIVERSIONS and turned it into one of the biggest Filipino restaurants in Chicago, the setting is beautiful one you walk in you immediately notice the buffet setting and the huge party room...I decided to throw my son's party here and I wasn't content with the service they forgot to give my guests drinks so that was a major downfall! other then that I'm still a fan of the bistek, lumpia, leche flan, and other stuff this is the place any PINOY or PINAY would go to if they want to eat home cooking but are lazy to cook lol like after Sunday Mass head on down to Little Quiapo and experience some soul pinoy food..NOTHING BEATS MY DAD AND MOM'S HOME COOKING THOUGH!

48.description: Dishes tend to be a little on the greasy side, but LQ's great when I'm in a pinch for some lumpia shanghai.  A small tray can easily cover 10-15 people and same day orders are no problemo.  I still get a knee jerk reaction to wear my hats straight forward or straight back from when this place used to be Diversions arcade.  Man, that's old school...

44.description: The Filipino food buffet here is subpar. The kare kare barely had any oxtail and the tripe was super chewy.  The one piece of oxtail I had was hard with barely any meat in it.  The lechon was forgettable and not tender at all with no seasoning.  The only main dishes that were decent were the fried squid (calamari is hard to screw up) and the pancit palabok (even though nothing could ever beat my mom's palabok).  The desserts however were decent and I'd probably only eat that if I could.  Basically, if you're looking to try Filipino food or you're craving good Filipino food, DO NOT GO HERE.

24.description: I came by here on a hot summer day and had high hopes. High hopes that was quickly shot down upon entry. There was no AC and we were seated off to the side, directly under metal heated ceiling lamps. Jokingly we attributed the heat to the recreation of the "authentic Philippine experience." We overlooked this minor discomfort in hopes that the food would be worth it. Sadly, it was not. The food was creatively housed in a old makeshift jeepney with the plates stacked up on top of the "engine". Much of the food was dripping with grease and flavorless. None of the food stood out to satisfied my taste buds. Everything I ate would be rated along the scale of "eh... to ...ew". I will however hand it to them for making an awesome avocado shake. The service was subpar. The waiters/waitresses quickly walked right out as quickly as they walked in to refill our glasses. Probably due to the uncomfortable heat. We had to make overt gestures or directly walk to the staff to get anything. Quite a disappointment. I would have to say that I would never recommend this place for a non-Filipino who wants to try Filipino food. This would be a horrible first impression and a poor reflection of what Filipinos have to offer in terms of food.

7.description: I went here a couple of times for the buffet this week. Staff are pleasant.  The food was great. I especially enjoyed the adobo chicken and spaghetti.  My favorite dessert is the mung bean porridge. Similar to a Mexican atole. The prices are reasonable. My only suggestion is a good dusting of the place, especially the chandeliers.

49.description: I talked my friend into going to Little Quiapo for a buffet dinner. I visited Manila last year, and I had a hankering for some of the Filipino dishes I had tried there. Almost all of the diners were Filipino, so I guess that is a good sign about the quality of the food. They have a regular menu too (including the gigantic halo halo sundae-like dessert), but there were plenty of items on the buffet to satisfy my appetite. Surprisingly the spaghetti-like dish was one of the tastier ones, with a sweet and tangy sauce. There is a lot of pork to go around, and they proudly display the pig's head to get that point across. Typical Filipino items include lumpia, pancit, chicken adobo, kare kare, lechon, crispy pata, and the coconut and green jello dessert called buko pandan. The most interesting item I tried was the warm dessert soup called ginatang bilo bilo, sort of a purplish soup supposedly with coconut milk, fruit, tapioca and glutinous rice balls. It looks bizarre, but it was very tasty. They also sell some miscellaneous Filipino goods at Little Quiapo if you want to take the flavors home with you.

40.description: Can't beat a Filipino buffet

53.description: Ok where do I start? I have mixed feelings about this place i , because the setting and wait staff does the food no justice... First of I am not Filipino but my boyfriend is and he cooks for me about 3 times a week so most of the foods there i have ate before, I am Hispanic so I recognize most ingredients used. We like to go out to restaurants on Fridays, especially places the other has not been to. So of course he picked this place. He said he has always gone here with his family and they used to be at another location. He gave it great reviews.. so I was excited to go and eat Filipino food which i love.. When we first walked in I was surprised to see that it was extremely quiet for a Friday evening. we basically seated ourselves because the waitstaff that consisted of 3 men were busy with other things (reading a newspaper). It seems to only be staffed by a grandfather, father and son. I didn't pay much attention to that cause I got a homey feeling to the place. I started to absorb my surroundings and noticed that it looked kind of tacky inside for example they had Christmas lights up, plastic table covers, fake flowers on the tables. So I asked my bf where was the menu he stated we were going to do the buffet and i asked "so do we just go up there or do we wait for a waiter?" all this dyi atmosphere was kind of awkward cause the staff would just glance our way. He said "yeah lets just go get our plates and eat." It would've been nice to at least be told by a waiter that we had the option to a menu or buffet then at least point us in the direction to the buffet. When we got to the buffet it was pretty stocked everything was full which i thought OK thats good but when i got closer i noticed that some food looked like it was sitting there a while due to the coagulation of the sauces. after I helped myself to 3 different kinds of pork dishes, and some plain rice and a veggie roll, I sat to eat. The menudo dish was excellent the rest of the food was good kind of warm not hot enough the rice was OK. the veggie roll was great i got another one the second time i went up to get my lechon..The lechon was cold and the pork skewers were ice cold. During the meal we didn't get refills of water, we didn't get waited on at all and the limited staff was doing a bad job of keeping up with people that were starting to fill in for dinner. I told my bf that the food was good but the staff sucked and the ambiance was cold like the lechon, I didn't feel welcomed at all. Maybe they should hire some friendly women who actually smile. When we asked for our check they guy who brought it stood there until we handed it back! And he stood there staring at the ceiling, i think it was very rude he could've at least given us a chance to look at the total and let my bf get his wallet, he felt so rushed he just put a large bill and handed it right back. I thought maybe I just had high expectations but my bf also was getting frustrated with the staff and cold food. I think from now on I'll stick to homemade Filipino food...I almost forgot we got some halo-halo to go and that was really good.  we ate it in the car listening to the radio away from stares

30.description: For us Filipinos who craves for authentic filipino food, you would think that this place would be meeting those needs.. All it had since it was a buffet, is commercialized taste where they think that to save money is add more water to the food..Their soups? Bland... Entrees that was served in the jeepney was blaah.. Pancit palabok? Soaked with coloring? Dried up bistek? Over cooked veggies in Pinakbet... And dried Puto..Not to start with their desert table...  Nobody even tried to refill it.. Previous customers decided to get their serving in a sloppy way, which made the dish look inedible.. The only thing i liked about it was the fried chicken skin and their barbecue...sago't gulaman? Is a diabetics paradise.. Freakin sweet!!! (TOO SWEET!!) We had to refill it with water 3 times to settle the sweetness.. And off course... Servers.. We had the one who looked pissed the whole entirety that we were there.. Not welcoming which is unlikely to us Filipinos... Never bothered to check on us if we don't call her.. (She thinks we don't give tips?) she didn't  deserve it!! I asked for a lid for my take out cup for my sago't gulaman since my bladder felt sooo full from refilling it.. We saw that she dropped it and STILL gave it to us where she blatantly denied that she did... I'm sorry, you don't do  a 5 second rule on me... Not coming back for sure... Not worth wasting my gas and the 45 minute drive that we have to go thru just to have an Authentic Filipino food experience... This is a good description of QUANTITY VS.  QUALITY...

46.description: Isla Pillipina is still my fave restaurant in the city. But, for buffet, I think Little Quiapo brings out all the classics... lechon, kare kare, lumpia, halo halo, pancit... for a decent price of $13 on weekends. I carried out in a take out box and charged me the same price, but I would go back to cram my face with the occasional breathing breaks. Maybe throw in a bathroom break as well to create some space.I just hope they don't have bathrooms like I experienced at Manila airport 15 years ago. There were no toilet seats and had to buy my own tee-pee.

1.description: Everything here tastes the same.  We came on a sunday morning and I was hoping that they would have longanisa or tocino or at least some type of breakfast food but they didnt.  The buffet itself is small.  Either you get Sinigang or Tinola for soup.  They have a roasting station and a fry station but I kinda wished they had more selection for entrees.

55.description: Warm cans of soda served with a glass of ice ? We went on a Tuesday about 2:30 PM. The buffet had very few choices and the food seemed like it had been sitting for quite a while. There are better Filipino restaurants in Chicago.

9.description: Came here for the first time. We're from Peoria. My wife, two kids and I enjoyed the food but be warned: Filipino food is among the unhealthiest in the world. Perfect recipe for heart failure, cancer or diabetes. I personally don't eat 95% of the cuisine on a regular basis. So we came only because we were craving for food from the old country. So the food was ok but my wife and I made this observation: when we got there, the lechon (roasted pig) was almost gone except for the fattiest parts. I struggled to find anything left that was lean. The staff saw me doing this. I concluded they weren't replenishing what was there for me and the mostly (99%) Filipino guests that night. Well, here come 6 guests, 5 of whom are WHITE. The staff immediately brought a fresh supply of lechon. Amazing. Common Filipino reverse racism. Treat your fellow countrymen like crap but treat others, especially white folks, like deity. My wife and I agreed we will steer clear of this place.

26.description: I wish this place would do its share of uplifting filipino cuisine and using it as a means of cultural sharing.  Alas, it is not.  It is a restaurant where they insist on talking to you in Filipino.... when you can't understand/speak it.  The place is loud and noisy and everyone (customers), once in it, starts to act like they are in a town fiesta, the usual compatriot's over-familiarity.... they look and stare at what you have put on your plate, they shout across tables with one another... so on the whole, it is a bit of a cultural shock. But I am told this is their way.  The food is ok but not exactly aesthetically pleasing or appetizing.  They could probably do with better positioning and lighting (yellow lights!?) of the buffet table -- it seems crowded onto a corner and looks very cramped.  Just the facts.

25.description: Delicious Buffet with traditional Filipino dishes. Since it is a buffet, it is mass made, so adjust your expectations accordingly. There is a pig that is roasted everyday and lays out.Never go wrong with the Sinaigang soup.Worth a try!

12.description: This review is only on the buffet and I hope the quality is better when ordering off the regular menu but everything in the buffet was greasy and heavy and next to flavorless. The dinuguan, the kare kare and the pinakbit might as well have all been in the same sauce colored differently for all that you could taste the differences. The soups were all mostly salted water with some meat and veggies. The BBQ chicken was good as was the buko pandan but overall it was a disappointing experience.

59.description: As I am writing this my insides are splitting in half after having suffering from an OD of pork poisoning (if there was such a thing). I'm not sick or anything, but I feel like whatever I ate there last night is not digesting and also not leaving my system - Hence it has destroyed my appetite to eat anything for the past 24 hours. Well I suppose I could be kinder with the review, given that is is a buffet. However as a result of this joint, it will be my first and last time ever eating Filipino food. You know, sometimes you see in a movie, that a guy is so traumatized from a bad experience with a girl - he just gives up girls all together and decides to play for the other team? Well that is me right now - this food had destroyed my confidence in Filipino food and I'm now converting over to any cuisine EXCEPT Filipino food. Now onto why I'm raging here. I don't remember exactly what it was called - but it was some orange/yellow goop with super fatty pork skin on there. One bite and I had to spit it out. Then I tried a little bit of the other items as well - some soy sauce beef (super greasy and fatty), some tamarind soup (super fatty/greasy pork), pulled pork (you guessed it, pork), pork skewers, and what have you. Basically it was just a mad pork house. No vegetables to be found in there except a batch of slop that looked like peapods. But everything was so greasy and the pork tasted/smelled like straight up swine, dirty swine. I'm a fan of dirty good food, but damn this was just dirty. The staff was nice, but however inattentive. The whole evening I did not get my glass of water refilled once - but that's aside the point. The food - which is still in my system now post 24 hours. If I do not post another review on Yelp, then you guys would know what happened. The greasy swine has terminated me.

21.description: This review is based off of service and cleanliness: Our recent visit was on a Sunday afternoon, right before the lunch rush. The place was already jammed packed and had a line waiting out the door for large parties. Our group of 3 adults and two infants were escorted to a corner right in front of a window. It was drafty in that area. The table was not wiped down. The floor was sticky and dirty. The high chairs they provided us had dried up chunks of food caked on there.  It took forever for someone to bring out ice waters and silverware for us.  And plate clearing? Forget about it. Our plates were stacked at our tables with no one to buss it.

17.description: i love this place, it reminds me of the philippines and the food was great! (except the kare kare, but im a total kare kare snob)check this place out my fellow filipinos!

10.description: We arrived just before lunch on a Sunday most of the trays still had food but look warm.Place was full but seemed disorganized and dirty.The only chicken I could find was in soup and one beef dish. Parking was full.
