34.description: We're so happy that we finally have such a great place for genuine Vietnamese food in our neighborhood. Not a big fan of the Argyle area even if the food is very good there. The spring rolls with tofu and the Pho are to die for. Recommend the place 100%.

16.description: After driving past this place hundreds of times, I finally caved & decided to try it. Went here with 3 other people yesterday for dinner. We were starving after shopping for hours. The first thing I noticed when I walked in was the smell of incense in the air. I kinda liked it :)We ordered banh xeo & special pho & bun bo hue. I actually had high expectations for this place since a few of my friends have recommended it to me.The banh xeo had to be the best I've ever had. Thin, crispy pancake & fresh veggies. Everyone thought it could have used some more shrimp & pork. I didn't care. I've tried so many banh xeo at other restaurants & this is my favorite one. The pho had tons of meat & meatballs. The broth had a strong fragrance from all the spices they used. 3 people ordered this & they all agreed that it was delicious. I didn't have this, but I did try the broth & meatballs. It was really good. I had the bun bo hue. I asked if it would have blood when I ordered it & the server said they didn't have any. I was a little disappointed, but I understood. Sometimes the store doesn't sell it. I've experienced it before too. Anyway, I couldn't get extra blood like i usually do, but I was still very happy with it. Tons of meat, beef, pork, & Vietnamese sausage, super fresh noodles, & savory broth. I will def be going back whenever I'm in the area. It's a little closer than Argyle & tastier too. I think I found my new favorite Vietnamese place :)

13.description: This is a friend of mine and my favorite "post 5K" spot. I had actually been here with her a while back but forgot to review it. We came again recently and they had remodeled so it really added to the ambiance. This last time I ordered a big bowl of soup with big beef chunks in it. I don't remember what it was called. It was good.The service is good and the food comes out quickly. Overall, I rememeber both experiences being good here.

11.description: I came here for lunch on a day I was feeling a little sick, and their pho hit the spot! It was pretty quiet inside, but I was having an early lunch. I got the pho with meatballs and rare beef. Comes with a bunch of traditional garnishes on the side, but definitely try the broth alone first as it's delicious. The staff is always polite and friendly. I came back again to enjoy the same dish on a wintry day and, once again, the pho was just what I needed. During both visits, I took half the pho home as the portions are very large. Definitely hit this spot up if you're in the neighborhood and want some delicious pho!!

39.description: Really good pho! My first time trying it ever and I wasn't disappointed. Wanted to be safe so we got rare beef pho. Beer had a weird taste but the broth itself was really good. Plus you feel good after eating it. Will be back

37.description: My cousins and I were super hungry so we decided to come to this place. It had pretty good ratings on Yelp and it was opened until 11pm on a Saturday so why not? As soon as we walked in, we were greeted and seated promptly. Because we were so hungry, we ordered right away. We all ordered the Pho Hoanh Long Special #23! It came out in about fifteen minutes and the portion size to price was a nice ratio. It had very flavorful broth and the beef brisket was very tender. Lots of noodles too! I do wish that the broth was a bit warmer. The smoothies were good but they were $4 which is more expensive than other places. The server was mildly friendly and she did what she needed to do. Nothing more or extra, just met expectations. Overall, excellent pho and average service!

0.description: Hoanh Long is one of my favorite restaurants. This place has made pho one of my favorite foods. If you're in the area or looking for some good pho, I definitely recommend this place, and suggest getting their pho tai. The pho tai is very simple, with just beef slices and noodles (bean sprouts, basil, jalapeños slices on the side). There are no strange looking meats or overpowering flavors.Lastly, their avocado bubble tea is seriously the best avocado bubble tea I've ever had.... The thick, creamy, and sweet avocado taste is amazing. It definitely tastes better than it might sound. If you like avocado flavors, I really recommend it.FYI: Closed on Mondays!

38.description: Yo! Wintertime got you cold and bummin'? Dey got dat Pho fo ya. Not a huge fan of the other dishes. But the Pho is very good. Avg / ambiance / service but the bone broth soup is worth a stop in on a cold winters day.

51.description: I am SO GLAD I don't have to put up with the annoying drive to Argyle St. (or put up with the smelly red line) ever again for my fix of Vietnamese food.I have been wanting to try this place for a while but usually just default to Argyle for convenience because I didn't know where "North Park" was. Derp. Turns out it is literally the easiest drive away from me, and I've gone past here so many times without noticing.Walking in and seeing tons of non-Asian diners (unlike on Argyle St. where there are actual Vietnamese people eating in those restaurants) made me a little skeptical. But we stuck with pho and banh xeo, tacked on a random squid dish and took our chances.And it was good! Their pho was a lot sweeter than I am used to, but it's so balanced that if you just slurp the unaltered soup you can truly detect every flavoring agent in its appropriate proportion in the broth.  Another huge plus is that the meat here actually tasted good! I always get the combination pho anywhere, and most times a lot of the meats just don't taste very good (due to either cooking or quality, I guess)and I eat around them for the soup and noodles and onions, but not this time! I also like the chili oil they serve on the side, as an alternative to sriracha. Banh xeo... very good. Something about it is just a bit more aromatic and flavorful, and it was thin and crispy just the way it should be (ahem... other restaurants.) By the time we shared banh xeo and pho, neither of us had any room for the squid.  The bites we tried were a little salty, but tastes good if a bit generic. It's like salt and pepper squid (as in battered and fried) with an extra spicy/sweet sauce on top. Kinda ruins the crispiness but oh well.as good as, if not tons better than argyle + convenient location. Super win.

27.description: This restaurant has become my most favorite Vietnamese restaurant. Forget Argyle. They have variety of dishes and they taste good. My friends and I ordered:-Papaya salad with beef: the best. The marinated beef is so good. So flavorful. The papaya salad is a bit salty, but still good.-Vietnamese crepe (banh xeo): Crispy and tasty.

32.description: The BEST vietnamese food I've ever tasted, EVER.

54.description: Best pho I have ever had. And that's seriously high praise given that I love pho, and am from the SF Bay Area. Great portion, delicious soup, and THE BEEF. I didn't even know there were so many different edible parts of the cow. I wish I could give different ratings for different dishes. The spring rolls were mediocre, and my boyfriend's beef & egg noodle dish had way too much sauce.But the pho. *dying* I have to give this 5 stars just for the pho.

48.description: "Not worth the money" is the way I would describe this restaurant. My family and I went to Hoanh Long to have some pho since many Yelp reviewers praised how great the pho is at this place. I was getting excited since I was getting tired of dealing with the Argyle drive and this place was closer to me. Boy was I wrong.We ordered 3 #23. It was a Hoanh Long special pho with price tag of $8.95 per dish, so I won't say that this place is cheap. It's rather on the expensive side for what I got. When the pho came out, it was lukewarm and lacked the deep flavor. To add on, the portion was small for the price I paid, and the broth tasted as if they mixed in those pho flavored powders that they sell at stores. I wasn't expecting much service from the servers since some Yelpers mentioned that. Unfortunately that came out to be true. Bill came out around $28 after tax. I wasn't happy at all with this place and don't plan on coming back anytime soon. If you are looking for expensive and low quality pho with below average service, this is the place for you.

44.description: I have tried many Pho places, in New York City and San Francisco and Hoanh Long is THE best without a doubt. We tried the combo Pho soup with was great. The broth was so tasty. The spring roll was amazing, including the sauce. We also tried the beef salad which was just out of this world tasty and delicious. I won't order Pho from anywhere else in Chicago!

24.description: Pho tai & shrimp spring roll were the best I've had in the city. Sorry, Tank Noodle, I'm staying local and ordering more from this little gem. I only gave 4 stars because of the service... but still worth it!

7.description: Had lunch here the other day with a buddy who just had to check out Devon Ave after seeing it in AA magazine. I'm not a fan of Indian food but I do like Vietnamese & Thai which is what I'd consider this place to be. We both had different stir fry chicken, mine with cashews, yum. My buddy had it with curry which he thought was great. We also had the spring rolls which were huge & delicious. The service was good and the place was casual but modern & clean. Give them a try!

49.description: I never had any problem with delivery service until today. I called to place an order and they said they only deliver up to 2 miles. I was 3 miles, it's too far for them. (Wtf)?! I told them you guys deliver to my place before. Why is 1 extra mile a problem?! They still said no. Okay then, you lost yourself a good paying customer. I ended up calling Saigon Bistro and even though they were much further away, they were willing to deliver to my place. Bye-bye Hoang Long! Never will I eat at your place again. What good came out of this.. I found myself a better pho spot.

40.description: #26 for life. If you are new to Vietnamese food or Pho, please take the time to introduce yourself to this restaurant and all it offers for such a small price. If you didn't know, pho is a "celebration" of soup, based with simmered beef or chicken broth, basil, bean sprouts, and various other ingredients, depending on the order. It can be sweet and savory, that's exactly how I like it, and that is how they make it here at Hoanh Long. The portions are large (not as big as Tank Soup's) but the flavor quality is great. The customer service is good. The woman who took my call also sat me and a group of 11 more down with reservations and split our checks. Our food was brought out as quick as they could make it, and the food just tasted so fresh. I would come here again if I was in the area.

53.description: I can't believe that after searching for years for the best VietnameseFood that I finally discovered it. I agree, this is the best pho and papayaBeef salad and their food beats out all of the argyle restaurants.I highly recommend this restaurant with no reservations, and I haveTravelled to Vietnam Nam over five times in the past few years.

30.description: I have been coming here for years. Best food,  best, warmest,  and most friendly service. Always consistent.  I love their appetizers. Their pho is from heaven. Best in chicago. I'm in love with their charcoal beef

46.description: I hardly ever come through the Rogers Park neighborhood, but we were hungry after a day of work and watching friends create a new sidewalk. We ordered banh xeo (looked good, huge appetizer), papaya salad with grilled beef (confused it with Thai spicy papaya salad, but it was still tasty. I've never had it with meat before) and pho with rare beef and tripe (a sweet broth, but still very flavorful. The bean sprouts were fresh). If you're ordering pho with rare beef, please remember to submerge meat underneath the noodles so it can cook in the broth. No one is trying to serve you raw meat unless it's meant to be a tartare. Standout place! Very happy to have stumbled upon this restaurant. They even serve Vietnamese hot pot!

1.description: My husband picked up take out for us..He had the orange chicken and riceI had the papaya salad..Unfortunately I got really bad food poisoning from the salad..Won't be eating here again

55.description: I think my first experience at Hoanh Long dates back farther than my first experience with Yelp, however for whichever reason I'd just forgotten to write a review.  In the beginning my run ins at this restaurant were not by choice initially.  At the time I hadn't much experience with Vietnamese food or pho in general.  Always ordering items and entrees hoping for Chinese when the food is usually, pretty different.  But after weekends of long nights partying and dancing till 5 am, this is where my friends would be.  This is where we came for that magical pho that kicked our arses into high gear enabling the ready we needed for the week ahead.  While most people headed out for greasy fast foods to help cope with bellies full of booze, we were "oontzing" it back to the crib.  It was the following morning or rather afternoon, after church I'd find myself with the same crew from the Saturday night before communing over a bowl of pho.My friends would often place the order for the type, sometimes my bowl would be full of bean sprouts, basil and all kinds of pieces of meat or seafood.  My friends would tell me to squeeze that bottle of rooster sauce till my heart was content.  Content would usually come when the strength of spice in that bowl paired with the piping hot of the broth would cause sweat to bead down our necks and backs and cause the sinuses to run mucus free.Have you ever sat down to a bowl of noodles with a bunch of Asians? It's a fuckin' race dude.  Granted, I'm American and I can take as damn long as I cared too but when eating with these dudes, I naturally felt like speed eating.  Quickest way to learn to use your chop sticks and spoon properly.Well, that there is a glimpse into the past and fond reason why I keep going back, bowl after bowl.Cheers.

9.description: The pho was spot on.  Really enjoyed the homemade spicy sauce on the side.

26.description: After driving past this place hundreds of times, I finally caved & decided to try it. Went here with 3 other people yesterday for dinner. We were starving after shopping for hours. The first thing I noticed when I walked in was the smell of incense in the air. I kinda liked it :)We ordered banh xeo & special pho & bun bo hue. I actually had high expectations for this place since a few of my friends have recommended it to me.The banh xeo had to be the best I've ever had. Thin, crispy pancake & fresh veggies. Everyone thought it could have used some more shrimp & pork. I didn't care. I've tried so many banh xeo at other restaurants & this is my favorite one. The pho had tons of meat & meatballs. The broth had a strong fragrance from all the spices they used. 3 people ordered this & they all agreed that it was delicious. I didn't have this, but I did try the broth & meatballs. It was really good. I had the bun bo hue. I asked if it would have blood when I ordered it & the server said they didn't have any. I was a little disappointed, but I understood. Sometimes the store doesn't sell it. I've experienced it before too. Anyway, I couldn't get extra blood like i usually do, but I was still very happy with it. Tons of meat, beef, pork, & Vietnamese sausage, super fresh noodles, & savory broth. I will def be going back whenever I'm in the area. It's a little closer than Argyle & tastier too. I think I found my new favorite Vietnamese place :)

25.description: The pho broth at this joint is amazing. It is jam packed with beefy goodness. I am a person that could live off of pho daily and this is easily my favorite bowl in the Chicagoland area. I had to knock off one star because it's so FAR from me! It would make my life if they had a location close to a CTA stop.

12.description: My boyfriend and I had been here 3-4 times. We stopped going there few months ago because there was a poop in the soup last time we were there. Literally -- POOP! I wish one of us had taken a picture of it but it was too stinky so we didn't want to get any closer. We didn't want to have another bowl of pho so we didn't bring it up right away.We suspected that it was a mouse poop which was originally hiding somewhere in the pile of raw veggies for pho and got into my boyfriend's soup when he put the veggies in his bowl since it was pretty intact and didn't look like it was cooked in a soup for long.The food was okay -- at least we liked it. If you happen to dine here or are planning to...sincerely wish you the best...P.s if you don't believe what I wrote, click "more reviews"-- I saw someone else having similar experience before.

59.description: Portions are OK.  Very tasty pho - not greasy at all.  Awesome spring rolls.  Service and atmosphere was the best I've ever experienced out of any other Vietnamese joint I've been too.

21.description: This place was actually our back up option, for we wanted wings but then we were like "nah don't want get my hands dirty" and settled for this; so glad we did, cause this place had amazing pho. I was blown away with the delicious number 28 with extra noodles and extra meat. I agree it is quite pricy but man I didn't even care, I'm like a tourist here basically. Coming from New York, this pho definitely was much much better than what I have had in flushing! Nice service, and friendly atmosphere, sitting down you feel extremely comfortable. Only con I have that irked me quite much is the fact the waitress's were extremely ... passive ... They only came if we made eye contact for a good 10 minutes and they would discuss upon themselves before coming to serve us. Never the less if it wasn't extremely pricey it'd be a much better place to settle down for.

17.description: Awesome place.  ONLY downside about this place is that it is closed on Mondays.  Always in the mood for a great bowl of Pho after a crazy weekend.  Although it is paid street parking outside, I have never seen anyone walk around to actually check to see if cars have paid.Food:Awesome Pho.  Better then most pho places around Argyle.  Great beef flavor and the bowls are full.  They do not skimp on the meats.  $8 for a bowl, $8 for Chipotle, or $8 at Panda Express....pretty obvious choice.  The hot sauce they give you on the side is also amazing.  It does not seem like the "store bought" type of a sauce, and a little goes a long way.  Shrimp and chinese sausage spring rolls are a very good size and fresh.  The rice paper is never stale or hard like some other places.  Service:Great service.  Every time any employee walks out of the kitchen, they scan the room to make sure everyone is doing good.  This place can get pretty busy, but service is quick and efficient.  Also BYOB.  Quick in and out noodle place in under 20 minutes if needed.

10.description: Invited by friends who dine here a couple times a year, I wasn't even aware of this place although I've lived in Rogers Park much of my life. If you want authentic Vietnamese cuisine in a neighborhood that's outside of the hustle/bustle of many, this is a great choice. Easy street (metered) parking too. Not sure exactly what we had because friends ordered, but we started with some type of veggie wrap that you assemble yourself in a rice paper skin. It was delicious, despite our struggles to get it rolled up like the waitress demonstrated...lol! Spring rolls were fresh and tasty. We shared the stir fried chicken and grilled eggplant as entrees. My dining partners didn't much care for the eggplant, but I was pleased. I definitely plan on coming back to try the Pho that everybody raves about.

5.description: The pho was delicious.  The broth had really good flavor and the portions were huge.

3.description: I always come here for the veggie banh xeo, which is a super delish crepe filled with broccoli, snow peas, bean sprouts, and tofu and comes with a huge plate of fresh greens. I've also tried the grilled eggplant and fried rice, which were okay, but nowhere as good as the crepe. OH, and if you are vegetarian, make sure to let them know not to add in any fish sauce to the vegetarian dishes!!

35.description: I wasn't very familiar with Vietnamese cuisine, even though i was trying Pho in different places at times. This place i have to say, has the best Pho i had in a long time. Not too crazy about the service, but the food is amazing.

19.description: Love love love this place!  Best Vietnamese I ever had and reasonable prices. 5 of us ordered  #15 Vietnamese crepe, #20 rice cake rolls, #23 Crispy fried tofu for apps. We then ordered chicken pho, 2 orders of #56 shrimp sautéed with hoanh long special sauce (ordered mild but those that like more spicy added chili garlic sauce - beware), another order of #20 and #73 stir fried noodle with beef with extra noodles (fried noodles are awesome-must get extra). All just a tad over $95. So delicious!

28.description: I've eaten in the restaurant and had carry out and delivery from here over the past few months. When we dined in with friends, the lemongrass spicy shrimp was full of firey awesomeness! I loved it!  The spring rolls were great. and I really liked the dipping sauce. My friends really enjoyed their dishes as well, and the waitstaff was helpful and friendly, especially about keeping our drinks topped off. Another time, when I and the hubby were sick, we ordered some Pho and ginger chicken to be delivered. The portions were very generous. I think I got three meals out of the soup alone and there was plenty of noodles, sprouts and basil, as well as lime and jalepeno slices. The broth was extremely tasty, and came with a brown sauce and a chili sauce to add. (Non-fire-eaters might want to go easy on it tho, the chili sauce was pretty bold.) The ginger chicken was FULL of ginger, which is what I wanted, as I was battling a cold. It might be a bit obstreperous for people who aren't so much into spicy food, but I credit it and the pho with vanquishing my cold.This has made our short list of local places to go and I know we will be eating here again soon.

45.description: This is a friend of mine and my favorite "post 5K" spot. I had actually been here with her a while back but forgot to review it. We came again recently and they had remodeled so it really added to the ambiance. This last time I ordered a big bowl of soup with big beef chunks in it. I don't remember what it was called. It was good.The service is good and the food comes out quickly. Overall, I rememeber both experiences being good here.

33.description: Legit. Good food + crummy service = authentic Vietnamese.I'm from California and am of Southeast Asian descent so I have high standards for Asian food. I'm over Chicago's Asian mashup restaurants of mediocre Thai + sushi + Korean all in one place and was in search of some good Vietnamese---just Vietnamese food with no offshoot sushi menu.This place didn't disappoint. They have a vegetarian pho full of fresh veggies and a generous list of appetizers. The unfriendly but efficient service also filled me with relief and pangs of nostalgia.

43.description: Thank god for pho...the best cure for hangovers and thank god for this place that makes good pho

2.description: I am so glad that authentic Vietnamese cuisine has expanded outside of the Argygle/Uptown neighborhood.  Exciting news for an avid pho-eater.With the weather getting colder recently, I'm been ordering pho more often.  Whether I'm in the surburbs or in the city, I feel like I'm noticing Vietnamese joints popping up everywhere.  Either that or I'm looking out for it more, but my pho radar is constantly ON.  That being said, I was very satisified with the pho here.I came here on a Sunday evening with a relative from out of town.  As we were leaving and hopping back into the car, we asked each other what we would rate it - both of us saying "five stars" without hesitation.Kid-friendly, open spaces, attentive service.  This is definitely a family spot, with a good mix of neighborhood residents (I presume), and reflected the diversity of North Park.  Our server came by our table mulitple times, ensuring that our water glasses were filled.  A sheet of specials was taped to the wall by our table, specifying items not currently on the menu......tempting, but our mission did not waver.  We both ordered the #26 pho: hoanh long special beef noodle soup (a mix of all their meats, including meatball, tendon, tripe etc.).  It was delicious and hit the spot.  Their garnish was fresh, and had plenty of jalapenos.  I happily soaked these into the broth, which was aromatic, rich and full-bodied, exactly as it should be, and full of chopped green onion.  I also liked how they sprinkled black pepper on the pho right before serving it.  A bonus for presentation and extra flavor.This is a great spot if you live in the northern suburbs (Hey Yelp Northshore! This place is awesome!) and don't want to head all to way to Uptown for some authentic pho.  The closest spot for pho used to be Joy Yee's in Evanston, but now Hoanh Long in North Park will be my next go-to whenever I'm back in the Skokie/Evanston area.

18.description: I hardly ever come through the Rogers Park neighborhood, but we were hungry after a day of work and watching friends create a new sidewalk. We ordered banh xeo (looked good, huge appetizer), papaya salad with grilled beef (confused it with Thai spicy papaya salad, but it was still tasty. I've never had it with meat before) and pho with rare beef and tripe (a sweet broth, but still very flavorful. The bean sprouts were fresh). If you're ordering pho with rare beef, please remember to submerge meat underneath the noodles so it can cook in the broth. No one is trying to serve you raw meat unless it's meant to be a tartare. Standout place! Very happy to have stumbled upon this restaurant. They even serve Vietnamese hot pot!

41.description: Good food a little high I think for some prices but overall enjoyed my visit.... everything seemed freshly made to order and had great flavor I'd say 4 stars but it cost me almost 30 bucks... =(

52.description: I'm pretty sure this may be my first Vietnamese rodeo, so I don't have anything to really stack up against Hoanh Long, other than the fact that I've been eating Japanese Ramen a bunch recently, and I can honestly say that the ramen I am eating has a lot more texture and flavors than I found with Vietnamese Pho. However, we are comparing apples to oranges here. The difference in Pho is that they use thinner glass noodles, and the broth had just a hint of sweetness, almost like a cinnamon/nutmeg/vanilla finish to it. The awesome thing at Hoanh Long is that they leave you a nice little side of hot chili paste/sauce. They also bring out a plate of sprouts and jalapenos, along with some leaves that I didn't know what they were and I didn't put them in my soup. But the sprouts and jalapenos were really nice to soak into the soap for extra crunch and heat. I had the rare beef and meatball Pho. The beef was really good, not really rare as advertised, more like Italian beef slices. The meatballs were just ok. I've read a lot of positive reviews about the beef tendon on Yelp, but was a little apprehensive about that description and opted for the meatball instead.   Also had the pork fried rice. Well, the rice didn't seem too fried and was a bit on the white colored side. Also, the pork came out in chops, bone on. So, it was a bit tedious to have to cut and work around the bone. But, it tasted pretty good so no complaints.I'd love to come back here sometime with a larger group and share some more items. Until then, 3 stars but as far as I can tell, this place is about an authentic Vietnamese as you can get.

50.description: The food is ok very inconsistent.  I won't go here because the staff is rude and indifferent.  I gave the several chances but every time they ignore you they never bring both meals at the same time so you always eat at different times.  Forget about getting appetizers before your meal.  They bring you food when they want no matter what you ask.They suck and I would never spend a nickel here again.  Take the extra time and go to Argyle st. Where not only have better food and service. But they are also very appreciative!

4.description: I don't know what's happened but this place has really gone down since we were last in. Our favorites were just "meh". Tonight we got the spring rolls, seafood hot pot and spicy calamari. The spring rolls are tiny but priced the same as other places so it's less bang for your buck. The calamari wasn't nearly as good as it used to be. The hot pot was really bland. Plus, the staff hovered over us the whole time and due to their insistence that we turn the hot pit higher, everything was overcooked and chewy. It was just an overall bad experience and I wish we had picked elsewhere for dinner tonight. I will not be back.

6.description: My cousins and I were super hungry so we decided to come to this place. It had pretty good ratings on Yelp and it was opened until 11pm on a Saturday so why not? As soon as we walked in, we were greeted and seated promptly. Because we were so hungry, we ordered right away. We all ordered the Pho Hoanh Long Special #23! It came out in about fifteen minutes and the portion size to price was a nice ratio. It had very flavorful broth and the beef brisket was very tender. Lots of noodles too! I do wish that the broth was a bit warmer. The smoothies were good but they were $4 which is more expensive than other places. The server was mildly friendly and she did what she needed to do. Nothing more or extra, just met expectations. Overall, excellent pho and average service!

22.description: Finally a decent pho place in Chicago! Ordered the shrimp spring rolls, yummy. The pho was very tasty, it was a very huge  portion too! The broth was beefy and delicious, not that sweet weird broth that I've noticed at other Vietnamese restaurants .. Quick and attentive staff too.

15.description: I love Pho. A big bowl of Pho is so comforting and a great way to warm up during cold weather.  I had HL bookmarked for a while and finally figured out a day when I could visit. The space is comfortable, clean, roomy and family friendly. Their menu is huge--everything just sounds so delicious.  I went with my usual Goi Cuon (fresh springrolls with shrimp) and the Pho Tai Gan (Pho with beef and tendon). Service was fine and food prep was timely. I loved the springrolls--they were smaller than what I normally see but still made well. The peanut sauce served on the side was delicious and had a tad of spice--the spice being something a little different from what I've found elsewhere, but a nice touch. The Pho was good and really warmed me up, the broth fragrant and a little on the sweet side.  I was pleasantly surprised that the beef had a lot of flavor too--something I don't always find when I order Pho. The noodles were plentiful although a little too al dente for my taste. Looking around and spying on other diners, it seemed like the papaya salad with beef was one of the most popular dishes and I definitely plan on trying that next time.  The menu, being as large as it is, has a lot to offer folks.

57.description: This is one of the best Vietnamese restaurants in Chicago. The people are kind of assholes sometimes though.

20.description: Good food. I liked the unique spicy sauce they had. Noodles just barely over done. Place clean and service satisfactory.

36.description: Killer pho and bun thit nuong.They need to re-stuff their uneven booth seats and gain that fifth star HAH

14.description: I've eaten in the restaurant and had carry out and delivery from here over the past few months. When we dined in with friends, the lemongrass spicy shrimp was full of firey awesomeness! I loved it!  The spring rolls were great. and I really liked the dipping sauce. My friends really enjoyed their dishes as well, and the waitstaff was helpful and friendly, especially about keeping our drinks topped off. Another time, when I and the hubby were sick, we ordered some Pho and ginger chicken to be delivered. The portions were very generous. I think I got three meals out of the soup alone and there was plenty of noodles, sprouts and basil, as well as lime and jalepeno slices. The broth was extremely tasty, and came with a brown sauce and a chili sauce to add. (Non-fire-eaters might want to go easy on it tho, the chili sauce was pretty bold.) The ginger chicken was FULL of ginger, which is what I wanted, as I was battling a cold. It might be a bit obstreperous for people who aren't so much into spicy food, but I credit it and the pho with vanquishing my cold.This has made our short list of local places to go and I know we will be eating here again soon.

1.description: I always feel like a horrible person writing less than stellar reviews for nice little local shops. Unfortunately, Simple Delights simply did not delight me or my dining companion. We decided to stop in one night to pick up some Filipino treats. I love tocilog...I could eat tocino morning, noon & night. It's so friggin delicious so when I saw that was on the menu I ordered it right up. We were the only people in the little cafe on a Friday night and it took about 20 minutes to cook up our meals. We took them to go and upon arriving home we found everything was insanely overcooked. The meat in both our meals was so dry from being cooked way too long, we couldn't cut it at all and could barely bite into it. It was a huge put off and sadly the flavor didn't make up for the messed up meat. Neither of us enjoyed our meals at all from Simple Delights.On a positive note, they carry ice cream from the Village Creamery in small tubs. Love their ube ice cream!

9.description: Being half Filipino and from California, I found their palabok to be delightfully comparable to the Filipino restaurants back home. Their fresh lumpia was pretty spot on too. The shanghai lumpia while in a generous portion tasted off/a little sour but it was freshly fried so I just doused it in Mae Ploy and called it a day. I will def be back for the palabok and fresh lumpia! Maybe I'll even try the pan de sal...!

23.description: So...I'm kind of going through a Filipino empanada withdrawal and it isn't pretty. You know the symptoms: slight shaking, excessive drooling, partiality to carbohydrates stuffed with meat and veggies... Just kidding...sort of. ::pokes at lunchtime pasta with slight disappointment::I came across Simple Delights because it's across from the oh-so-awesome Filipino restaurant, Little Quiapo. Realizing that I wasn't that hungry, and persuading my family that they weren't either, we tried Simple Delights.Okay...DON'T GET THE FILIPINO BREAKFAST OR ANY OTHER ENTREE. AND...if you ask for water, they'll charge you for a bottle of water. So beware. End of that discussion.DO GET THE EMPANADAS: Each is $1.50 and you can get chicken, pork or beef. I bought two chicken ones and they made for a great breakfast the next morning. Melanie V. described them well: semi-sweet doughy crust,  potatoes, egg, raisins, peas. I'd also like to add that they're about the size of a closed fist but not as fat as your fist (or maybe my hands are just fat. Meh).I'm coming back for more empanadas and to try the other baked goods: ube cake (purple yam cake), sapin sapin (gluttonous rice cake), braso de mercedes (fluffy white meringue stuffed with custard roll cake). They also have non-Filipino baked goods like ruggulah and croissants.

12.description: Reaction after SKOKIE BAKERY was closed: "NOOOOOOOOO!!!" Like...Darth Vader realizing he had just killed Padme kind in "Star Wars Episode 3: Revenge of the Sith". Like...no joke I was pretty depressed on Sunday mornings after church when I would usually hit the place up.Reaction after SIMPLE DELIGHTS was opened? "Okay...I see what you're saying...now show me what you got!"Not gonna lie, their empanadas are the...for the lack of a better word..."the shiznit." They simply are pretty darn amazing. Melanie V. had it right on the spot as far as her description: "Semi-sweet doughy crust, beef, potatoes, egg and raisins!" The last 2 times I've been there, they had just made them so they were perfect. Even if the $1.50 price is a bit much for a half-fist portion, it wouldn't stop me from hitting that craving...especially since it's so nearby and always fresh!As far as their pan de sal (Filipino roll)...not as good as Skokie Bakery. They're pretty hard actually, which takes away from the "freshly baked" claim. Like day-old bread kind. Although, I do enjoy the sweet kick to them and so far haven't found any other Filipino place nearby to satisfy my nostalgic cravings for them, so they will have to do for the meantime. Maybe my timing is wrong. Maybe I just gotta figure out when they bake them and come when they're fresh out of the oven. Maybe...Haven't really tried anything else yet because I prefer to see the food before I order them when it comes to Filipino food.Pan De Sal pickups? Check. Empanadas of Perfection with a capital 'P'? Double check with whipped cream and a cherry on top!

21.description: I stopped in here after dropping off a package at the UPS store. I am not very familiar with Filipino food, so I have no standard to judge it against. I ordered their daily lunch box special. Basically it was a big pile of white rice and i got to select 2 types of meat to go with it. I chose the chicken adobo and pork steak. It was not very appetizing to look at, but tasted ok. Felt more like what one would imagine being served in a soup kitchen or something. I ended up taking most of it home and picked at it for supper. I also got a beef enpanada. The crust tasted like a type of corn bread and was rather sweet. I liked that a little better. Also bought some bread rolls I have yet to try. The place is very clean and the lady behind the counter was friendly. I wish I could say I am eager to try it again, but I think it will be a while before I return. I need to educate myself more on the cuisine.P.S. just got an update from my mom. She had one of the rolls. She loved it. Said there was a slight sweetness to it, but was very good.

16.description: BEST PLACE TO ENJOY AUTHENTIC FILIPINO FOOD. From their Arroz Caldo (GOTO, LUGAW) to their Lumpiang Sariwa, and a lot more.YOGAD ORIGINAL

17.description: Why doesn't the menu have prices? It annoyed me. I prefer not to ask how much each item cost  and when I did asked they had to confirm with someone else which bothered me also. Ensaymadas  - missing something...my bread was flat (not fluffy) and tasted just like a bread with sugar. Chicken empanadas - I guess because it's baked it tasted like that. Flavor was okay but dough was not to my liking.  I've had better. Pork BBQ stick (sister tried)- meat was hard....overcooked?. Nonetheless, maybe they should pick a different cut of meat with some fat to make it softer. I'll give it another try for actual Filipino cooking since I am in the area. I hope for the best.

10.description: I find myself here 1-2 times a week. The food is good and pretty cheap. I recommend the Filipino breakfast (friend rice, egg, and meat combo).I recommend calling in your order if you stop by for lunch because the food can take awhile too cook.I also suggest buying their fresh baked Filipino breads especially the pandesal. My white hubby loves using them for his sandwiches because they're so soft and yummy :)

5.description: If you all like burnt food and gnawing on tree bark...this is your place to be! Tocino was leftovers that they try to mask by re-frying it. Tapsilog...same! I felt like I was a dinosaur chewing on tree bark. They don't even bring food to you. They just whisper the order and your food can sit on counter until you figure it out! Horrible place. Not all Filipino establishments are like this so I'm very disappointed in this horrible horrible place.

11.description: I WILL NEVER GO BACK TO THIS PLACE AGAIN!i had one of the WORST experiences here that i've had in a long time! i was really wanting some tocilog and didn't want to drive far so i decided to give simple delights a try.  i live about 10 minutes away and thought hey why not.upon arriving there, no one greats you and there's only ONE person at the register who also is the server.  it was on a sunday that i went so i guess they had a "buffet", yeah some buffet, the cashier/server goes over to the buffet station, asks you what you want and she then pours the food into the bowls for you (probably cause filipinos are cheap and didn't want people over filling their plates with food) about after 10 minutes of waiting only to order my food, it took another 15 minutes for them to make my food.the cook in the back yelled out my order and left it on the counter in which i waited another 5-7 minutes for the only cashier/server to get back to the counter to get my order together.when i got home and opened my box of food i was surprised to see that the food in the box was not what i had ordered. by this time i was already cranking and hungry cause it took so long to order and get my food,  i called simple delights to let them know that i got they gave me the wrong order only for that same cashier/server to say to me "oh, you got the wrong order? i'm sorry" *click* meaning she hung up on me!! she didnt even offer my money back or offer for me to come back and get the correct food!! at this point i was very upset and drove back over there!!i got there and again another 10 minute wait until she acknowledged what the box of food sitting on the counter was.  i then said it's the food that i am returning because you gave me the wrong order.  she then says "sorry, we gave your order to that man sitting down over there" she then looks at me and says we'll make u a new one; which of course i waited another 15 minutes for them to make!!after getting back home a 2nd time i went to eat my food in which was supposed to be garlic rice, which was pretty much regular white rice and fatty tocinolike i said i will NEVER go back here ever again and i will NOT recommend this place to anyone!!! i should have just gone to ruby's fast food to begin with even if it was a further drive.

22.description: Ensaymada is okay. Monay very good. I miss Valero, Red Ribbon and Goldilock's. I think I should move to California. The pastillas also good, but not for $4.00 for 10 little ones. Monay is very soft and tasty, so I would go back for that, not ensaymada which was kind of hard, who knows how long it was sitting there for. They said everything was fresh from that morning, but it isn't very busy, so I imagine they have a lot of left overs from the day before...Empanada chicken was also pretty good.I suggest bringing cash her because they do not know how to work their credit card machine. I waited 20 minutes for them to figure it out and got my credit card statement and found out they charged me twice! I called to see if they would reverse it and now I have to drive back to the store and show them my statement. It isn't actually down the street from me.

0.description: How glad I was that I looked at Yelp before I made my food choices- I was hungry enough that I almost gave into the hot dog stand across the street at Home Depot (which actually makes a decent dog) but I held out because Melanie got me with the idea of breakfast. I didn't get breakfast however- I met MUNGGO!!!!!! How have I lived past forty with out experiencing this delicious smoosh of mung beans and whatever else goes in it?? It's like black eyed peas from Asia. I'm hooked.GO try it.And who doesn't need a chicken soup called "Mami"? WHY doen't all cultures call their chicken soup Mami? This stuff is not as good as the best Mexican Caldo I've ever had, or  the best Matzo, but it's up there. Great noodles. Good broth, fresh veg accoutremonts. And cheap, yes sir.I'll be back.

20.description: Reaction after SKOKIE BAKERY was closed: "NOOOOOOOOO!!!" Like...Darth Vader realizing he had just killed Padme kind in "Star Wars Episode 3: Revenge of the Sith". Like...no joke I was pretty depressed on Sunday mornings after church when I would usually hit the place up.Reaction after SIMPLE DELIGHTS was opened? "Okay...I see what you're saying...now show me what you got!"Not gonna lie, their empanadas are the...for the lack of a better word..."the shiznit." They simply are pretty darn amazing. Melanie V. had it right on the spot as far as her description: "Semi-sweet doughy crust, beef, potatoes, egg and raisins!" The last 2 times I've been there, they had just made them so they were perfect. Even if the $1.50 price is a bit much for a half-fist portion, it wouldn't stop me from hitting that craving...especially since it's so nearby and always fresh!As far as their pan de sal (Filipino roll)...not as good as Skokie Bakery. They're pretty hard actually, which takes away from the "freshly baked" claim. Like day-old bread kind. Although, I do enjoy the sweet kick to them and so far haven't found any other Filipino place nearby to satisfy my nostalgic cravings for them, so they will have to do for the meantime. Maybe my timing is wrong. Maybe I just gotta figure out when they bake them and come when they're fresh out of the oven. Maybe...Haven't really tried anything else yet because I prefer to see the food before I order them when it comes to Filipino food.Pan De Sal pickups? Check. Empanadas of Perfection with a capital 'P'? Double check with whipped cream and a cherry on top!

19.description: I wasn't able to try their prepared food, but I did pick up some pastillas, sio pao, and brazo de mercedes to go .  Pastillas are hand-rolled milk candy similar to fudge.  I tried both pastillas de leche (milk) and pastillas de ube (purple yam) and they were deliciously addictive.  Sio pao is the Filipino version of the Chinese bao (filled, steamed buns).  Just pop one in the microwave to warm them up.  They were a great snack.  Brazo de mercedes is a meringue roll filled with thick custard.  It's one of those hard-to-find Filipino desserts, so I was happy to see it there.

2.description: First off, their customer service is horrible. They're plain rude. As soon as I walked in, no one greeted me. I walked up to the counter and two of the people worked there were chatting with another customer. They never even acknowledged me when I got in front of the counter. They stared at me, and asked me what I wanted. I told them what I needed, and they went to get the pandesal. As they were getting it they were chit chatting with each other. Gossiping. I don't think they knew I could understand Tagalog... I was pissed cause they were more worried about talking among themselves instead of trying to get to know their customer. Then she also rung me up for an extra hopya. I never went back in there for money back cause I was so pissed with their service it was embarrasing.Anyway, I'm only giving them 2 stars, cause the pandesal and the yema were decent. I'm most likely not coming back there though. I rather drive far than to go back here again.

18.description: A friend of mine goes to the gym next  to this restaurant and knew I'd be up for a conceptual trip the Philippines.They had my favorite comfort dish as a lunch special that day - ginisang mongo. The healthy/unhealthy balance between succulent pork cracklings, mongo beans (similar to lentils), stewed tomatoes/ carrots/onions/spinach, and light broth over white rice should not be missed. My friend loved her Filipino breakfast plate with BBQ chicken skewers and sunnyside up egg. The skewer was great, but I typically think of Filipino breakfast as fried rice instead of white rice. We shared the lumpia as an appetizer and halo halo as desert - happy taste buds and tummies :-) Even after ordering, I did double, triple, quadruple takes in the bakery. I vetoed an order of the pan de sal, boy was that difficult, but could not resist my favorite desert, ensaymada.  Gigantic, doughy, sugary, optimum sprinkling of grated cheese - the ensaymada comes in packages of six, and I dare you to eat just one.I'm grateful that the restaurants by my gym are delis, burger joints, and sit down restaurants rather than inexpensive, satisfying Filipino food.

13.description: I spotted this joint when I went to Little Quiapo restaurant. What a great find!I keep coming back for the freshly baked pan de sal. So good, so scrumptious pan de sal.  This taste just like the ones back in the Philippines.  Everytime I go here, they always have a fresh batch just taken out of the oven.

4.description: I wish I can put zero star as my review.  The cashier not only she blames for not telling her I had a coconut juice as my drink because she forgot to charge me but also has a nasty attitude.  I can stand eating an any restaurant with not so good food but I can't when the people who works there do not know how to respect their customers. Today I decided to eat there for lunch I had a combo and a drink since I only have credit card n their min amt is $10 I decided to get something else to make my transaction over $10 so I went up to the counter n paid and as I about to go she said I didn't tell her I had drink n she didn't charge me so I said I only have a credit card and go ahead and charge my card the drink is about $2 or less and she started mumbling and I heard her say I didn't tell her that I had a drink.  And she made it seemed it was my fault.  Hello lady if you are not too busy watching tv you would have noticed I took drink from the fridge and it's not like I took off and didn't pay... This after this incident I'm not going back there again sayang Filipino business na gusto kong suportahan but how can you support some business if they don't know how to respect their customers... The food by the way isn't all that....

24.description: Once I heard that they served Filipino breakfast - I had to go.  I went with my girlfriend and ordered the tapa, eggs, and rice (my girlfriend ordered the tosino, eggs, and rice).I received my order - all I could think was "Where's the rest of the rice? Only one egg?".  Come on now, I'm Filipino.. give me a 'Filipino' serving of rice!  Also, my girlfriend was worried that her tosino wasn't cooked all the way.On the other hand, I didn't try any of their pre-made deserts.. They did look good.  Maybe I'll go back... maybe.

6.description: Apparently, there's not that many Filipino restaurants in Chicago and if you want any, you have to drive outside the city.Our aunt felt the need to feed us comfort food and I'm game.Ensaymada: This is Filipino brioche with smeared butter and sugar sprinkled on top. Pretty good. Plenty of butter and sugar on top. Tapsilog & Dasilog: Garlic rice is pretty good. They didn't mess up the eggs. The fish was not overly done (aka so dry it turned into jerky). For those of you who don't know what the heck I'm talking about...* TAPSILOG - TAPa or beef, SInangag or garlic rice, and itLOG which means egg.* DASILOG - DAing or milkfish, SInangag, and itLOG.Fried Vegetable/Spring Rolls: REALLY good.Calamansi juice: From concentrate. But really good. I've had some before where it was bland and watery.Mango juice: Really really good.Ice cream: Filipino ice cream!!! Yey!

15.description: I'm Filipino. I like Filipino food. I know what Filipino food should taste like and this place is decent. Actually, if it wasn't so close to my house I wouldn't eat here. The last time I went here they served me hard rice. Really?  They ran out of garlic fried rice and said they only had one order left. Fine. But the white rice was hard?  Freaking fry it and make it into garlic fried rice. Heat it with sine eater. But dont serve me hard rice!So far I've only had the Filipino breakfasts, lumpia, halo halo and pan de sal. The pan de sal was really good. The BBQ stick was good. The longanisa was my favorite of the breakfast meat. Don't go out of your way to eat here. It's not bad but it's really not that good.

7.description: Extremely POOR customer service and over charges you for items even when prices are posted directly on the menu! So Be Aware! Their food is so so. The garlic rice is always hard and old and was told they ran out of a menu item but when the woman behind me ordered the item that they supposedly "ran out" of they were happy to ring her up for it!...REALLY?! I will definitely NOT return to this place and also do not recommend this place to anyone. There are better Filipino restaurants in the area! As a Filipina, I am extremely disappointed in this place. Thumbs down!GO TO "RUBY'S"! BEST FILIPINO FOOD IN THE AREA! Less than 10 minutes away from Simple Delights - Located on  3740 W. Montrose Ave

8.description: (Refresher time!  Apparently, I forgot Simple Delights served Filipino breakfast even though I definitely talked about it in my initial review.  Oops!)Lookin' for Longsilog, Tocilog, Tapsilog?  Get it here for $6.25!It comes with your choice of meat (longanisa, tocino, tapa or even bbq), garlic fried rice and a sunny-side up (or over medium, maybe?) egg.  Yum!  Tip: If you're in a rush, you should probably call in the order as you end up waiting 10-15 min for the food to come out.

3.description: Not coming back and will never recommend it. I had emapanada and had to beg to warm it up. My whole family was disappointed from their customer service.

14.description: I stopped in here after dropping off a package at the UPS store. I am not very familiar with Filipino food, so I have no standard to judge it against. I ordered their daily lunch box special. Basically it was a big pile of white rice and i got to select 2 types of meat to go with it. I chose the chicken adobo and pork steak. It was not very appetizing to look at, but tasted ok. Felt more like what one would imagine being served in a soup kitchen or something. I ended up taking most of it home and picked at it for supper. I also got a beef enpanada. The crust tasted like a type of corn bread and was rather sweet. I liked that a little better. Also bought some bread rolls I have yet to try. The place is very clean and the lady behind the counter was friendly. I wish I could say I am eager to try it again, but I think it will be a while before I return. I need to educate myself more on the cuisine.P.S. just got an update from my mom. She had one of the rolls. She loved it. Said there was a slight sweetness to it, but was very good.

3.description: This cafe has some serious atmosphere. As others have mentioned, it's like walking into an art installation filled with psychedelic paintings, mismatched chairs, eerie found objects, and mystical wood sculptures. There is a "messy stoner" feel to Art Zone that separates it from coffee shops of the "quaint Western classist" variety. You can go here and do regular cafe things like drink, talk, read, etc. Or you can just sit and gaze at the art like the spacehead you know you secretly are.

1.description: I came here on a sunday evening with a friend for coffee/tea.  You have to walk into the back to order the drinks (yes interesting).  The place is owned by an older Korean couple, but they are very friendly.Costs: drinks are around $4 and ppatbingso is around $6+Plum tea - I enjoyed the korean plum tea.  It is a bit sweet so make sure you allow the ice to melt a little or a lot prior to drinking.Atmosphere - cute Korean traditional decor, but a little run down so it might not be as nice of a place to go to if you're on a date?  I think they have a outdoor patio too, but haven't checked it out yet.Parking - free street parking on weekends.

2.description: It's the hidden place on the opposite side of the street of Outdoor Cafe and Java n Mug. I was the only person there when I went and I think this place was great. It's a totally different atmosphere than Java or Outdoor as it was very quiet and not kitschy. Nice pieces of art are displayed on the wall.Had the mango bubble tea and a hot green tea and both were very good. I liked how the green tea was loose leaf and served in the special tea cup where it brews in the cup and you can remove the top part.I wish it was open later though...

5.description: Haven't found another place like this in the city. Best during the summer, this place is like an art installation you can eat in. Can't love this spot enough!

6.description: This is definitely a hidden gem. We just came across this wonderful place after trying to get a seat at a cafe across the street. No one else was there but us and I don't know why. They had all these beautiful Korean art on the walls and some were displayed inside the tables. We went outside the back and were pleasantly surprised by the cozy but beautiful seatings. Parts of the cafe seem a little disorganized but the "pat bingsoo" (red bean ice treat) was delicious especially because they used fresh fruit instead of the canned kind. This is definitely a good place to get cozy with your date (to impress them with the art and some amazing dessert). I wish it was more organized though.

0.description: Art Zone is a great place to hold a private party! A group of my friends rented Art Zone out one evening as our private noraebang (Korean karaoke room). The owners were phenomenal hosts. Not only were they friendly and accommodating, they actually joined in the fun!

4.description: This is my absolute favorite cafe! After work, my friend and I wanted to try something new and came across this place.  It's a hidden gem among other Korean cafés but I urge you, if you're in the area, make a stop and visit the ArtZone gallery and café. Every inch of this place is decked out with art, mostly of which were made by the owner himself. The owners of this place are very kind, welcoming, and genuine people. They even sang karaoke with us! They offer open karaoke, open stage, and delicious beverages and desserts. This review is based on my first visit but I can't rave enough about it!

3.description: This was a first for me too, Jason.I asked the girl at the counter to suggest our dinner Friday.  We took her suggestions:Pork with fried mashed potatoesandBeef StewWe also had a chicken & a steak taco so we could compare the flavor to the common South American neighbor...I agree - the food is too good for the place to be so empty.I smell an unofficial yelp event!

1.description: Tiny location.  Had the ceviche de camaron and platanos con queso. Ceviche was served with dry roasted corn and rice. Delicious!

2.description: Unfortunately, Delicias Crucita is CLOSED.I was eager to try their Ecuadorian food, but saw the paper-covered windows and the "For Rent" sign out front.  I also noticed several other places that were out of business in that area, which is quite sad.  It looks like the college students nearby are only partial to Subway, Jimmy John's, and Starbucks.  No, no, and NO.  Support your local businesses.

5.description: I'm not sure how many people frequent this neighborhood who are on Yelp other than those who attend NEIU and North Park (what say, you've never heard of those schools? 3 months ago, neither had I).But if you are ever in the neighborhood, and in the mind for something different, stop by here. The cheerful, BRIGHT, familial (I sensed that the Parents were working the counter, the grandma was cooking and the kids were hanging out doing their homework) serve out portions of latin food you've probably never seen.Ask them what's best, and they'll tell you. I got a huge dollop of fried pork pieces, some hardened corn, some corn that looked like it got blown up, and a fried plantain. But the kick was the 'hot sauce' (sort of a salsa) which I spread over all the aforementioned parts of the meal.Awesome. Friendly. Tasty.

6.description: i had never had ecuadorian cuisine before i found this place, so i wasn't sure what to expect. what i found out is that it's pretty tasty. i opted for the secos de carne, a beef and potato stew served over rice with an onion-y salsa on the side and a tomate de arbol juice. at first the prices seemed maybe a dollar or two too high given the portion size, but i came out full & satisfied, so who am i to complain? i've only been in here in the kind of mid-afternoon lull, and it was dead empty. i hope they're busier during the lunch & dinner rushes, the food is too good for nobody to eat it.

0.description: Doña Crucita is a gem, I luv my Ecuadorian food. It might be simple but it's delicious. Glad I found her again but now in Portage Park. Place is small for about 25 folk's. This Ecuadorian main plate is delish, fried pork(substitute for meat or chicken)hominy with onion salad, and potato paddies. The cheese empanada sprinkled with some sugar are yummmy.If you haven't tried Ecuadorian food yet, I'd give place a try. Good food made with a lot of luv

4.description: My family and Crucita (the chef/owner) go way back to when she would sell food out of her apartment on the northside. The move to her own restaurant really proves how much people enjoy the ecuadorian food she makes.It really is a great, family-run business and Crucita is one of the warmest people I generally know. As soon as she recognizes me when I walk in, she doesn't wait to send out some fritada (pork), mote (cooked corn), and tostada (a kind of fried/toasted corn). She's smart too because I can never taste some fritada without getting a full order.My family and my favorites dishes include the seco de chivo (beef stew), caldo de papas (potato soup), fritada (fried pork), and her humitas (similar to tamales).To drink, jugo de naranjilla (a juice made from a fruit found in the Andes) always hits the spot or a fruity Fioravanti pop.Otherwise, you should really stop by for some the holiday-specific food:Around November 2nd (Dia de los Defunctos) she makes a great colada morada (a warm, thick, tangy, berry drink) with typical ecuadorian bread. For Easter, stop by to try her Fanesca (a thick traditional soup made with 12 different grains for the 12 different apostles).If you can't already tell, I'm a big fan of Crucita and have been going to her and her restaurant for years.

58.description: Bari is an Italian grocery where you can find a wide range of products, but when I hear about this place all I can think about it's their sandwiches. They're a combination of traditional ingredients that charms you from the first bite. Every time my mother sends me here to buy sauces and fresh pastas I end up leaving the store with a huge prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich that's totally worth the effort. Sandwiches are affordable so everyone can try one every now and then. Proof that Bari's sandwiches are so famous is the line, but I don't mind waiting 15 minutes for my sandwich because I know that no other place can make it better. The grocery also features imported cookies, dried pastas and a butcher where you can find a wide range of home-made products such as sausages, rabbit or veal. If you happen to be in Chicago, you should take your time and enjoy the best sandwich you've ever eaten at Bari.

56.description: Bari's Deli has been a Chicago staple for over 35 years. Great sandwiches can be delicate, gut-busting, humble or flashy. What they have in common is that they're built with love and care and great quality ingredients. This is exactly what Bari's Deli has created for several decades. If you landed here, it means you are searching for a fantastic sub sandwich in Chicago. Yeah, yeah, bada-bing bada-boom-boom, you found it so look no further, because this joint is number one when it comes to subs. We love the made-to-order deli sandwiches. Picking just one of their masterpieces at this deli shop is no easy task, since every massive mound of bread, meat, and cheese here is nothing short of a Chicago treasure. Years ago, I tried the prosciutto, sopressata comprised of fresh mozzarella, sweet roasted peppers and olive oil -- simply memorable -- fresh, chewy bread melds perfectly with the cold cuts and cheese. The savory olive spread adds an extra kick to the whole she-bang. We were astounded by the carniv-orgasmic offerings at this place when we first  came here over 10 years ago!You can try ham, salami, turkey, roast beef, mortadella with American, Swiss or provolone cheese, lettuce, tomato, onions, hot peppers, mustard, mayo, oil and vinegar, all packed on a fresh, fluffy Italian bread. The bread is simply ethereal. There are lots of solid options to choose from at this joint, which prides itself on creating sandwiches to satisfy every palette. Thick Italian bread envelops plump pieces of their meatballs, all elegantly smothered in delectable fresh mozzarella, Romano cheese and piping hot tomato sauce. Afterward, you can nap for weeks, awake refreshed (and five pounds heavier). My favorite sandwich here is their Italian sub (or Italian hero). If you want to have the gastronomical experience of a sub sandwich life time hit this place up for lunch.There is only one thing you need to know about this joint. What dat? What dat? The Italian sub is the one you want. Don't think twice! Just order it and step back. Let the man work his magic, while you marvel at the quick dance of sandwich seduction happening before your eyes. First, a long loaf of Italian bread is sliced open and fresh cured meat after cured meat thinly shaved goes directly into the sandwich. At this point, your mouth is watering as cheeses, peppers, dressing, everything, added so deftly that if you blink you might miss a step. Second, hold your wrapped sandwich tightly in your hands and try not to quiver with excitement at first bite!This mom and pop operation has been serving fantastic Italian sausage, Sub sandwiches and Italian beef for decades. I wouldn't say they have "the best" Italian beef in the city, but it is definitely worth trying (even if it is only once). This is carry-out only, so get your sandwich and get the hell out.  Bada-Bing, Bada-Boom. You're done! ;DStreet parking = 3 stars (not super difficult to find a legal spot)Sandwiches   = 5 starsService = 4 starsBreads and Circuses = 4 stars

29.description: What a coincidence that another yelper mentioned that the folks at Bari always call him "Chuck Norris". Every time I waltz into Bari the guys by the meat slicing station refer to me as "The Octopus That Was in the Sky", so fitting! That's just the thing about the soldiers of the Bari good taste armada, they have an eye for detail. They call it like it is, they know you want a mean sandwich and they hand you a raging scorpion of flavor, wiggling in a paper wrapping that will be transparent by the time you make it home, you just can't contain the flavor juices infiltrating the polluted Chicago air. Id like to move away from this place just to get rid of my asthma. That reminds me, I actually have a bumper sticker on my car that says "I came to Chicago for the Bari, stayed for the Asthma!"

42.description: In my opinion, Bari unequivocally makes the best "Italian" sub in the city.  I've been coming here for years, and even though they may not know my real name, they call me "Chuck Norris" ( guess they think I look like the old boy ! ! ) Although making a sub sandwich isn't rocket science, a noteworthy version can only be the sum of the freshest and best quality ingredients.  My checklist would include the following.  The bread should have a thin, crispy crust and soft crumb.  The meats & cheeses , lettuce & tomato must be both flavorful and freshly sliced.  And last, but not least, the giardiniera needs just the right amount of crunchy & soft veggies, herbs, and olive oil.  Bari meets all these standards. ( In addition, Bari makes its own giardiniera, and sells it in jars too)   Its no wonder the small place is always packed with customers.  Service is always prompt, but at prime time, you might need to wait a few minutes.  Its a small  price to pay for a terrific sub.  From Chicago cops and office workers to Italians from Harlem/Belmont, Brideport, or Elmwood Park, Bari is what the Italian-American sub is all about. If you happen to be looking for Italian groceries, they carry an ample selection of oils, canned tomato products,pasta, canned fish, and homemade condiments.  They also have fresh meats , homemade sausages, cheeses , and a wide selection of deli meats/salads.  If you don't enjoy cooking, checkout their prepared pastas and sauces.  (Currently, there are a few parking spaces just 2-3 doors South which are for customers shopping at Bari)

23.description: Best Italian subs in town!! I've been going there since I was a little kid and the old neighberhood feeling never goes away.

47.description: The Italian subs here are really, really good. And, a super value. Very nice and friendly staff too. Can't wait to try their other subs.

8.description: This place is not a pretender. It's the real thing. The bread is excellent, meat slices thick, and the other toppings are fresh + the prices are decent.

31.description: I'm an Italian beef fanatic.   And a combo enthusiast to say the least.   So obviously I google the best Italian beef sandwiches in town and Bari pops up #1.  I had tried Mr.  Beef,  Boston,  Al's, and some damn place on south Pulaski that I don't remember the name.   So I says,  ok,  this is gonna be the love of my life, right?  As you can tell by my rating...WRONG.   the meat doesn't even look or taste like Italian beef.   Plus it's dry and has no bite, just pulls apart but not in a good way.   They put a crap load so that's good.   I say to myself, I must be wrong,  maybe it was a bad day or something so I go again.   Same thing,   at least they have consistency.   To be honest,  it's the second to last on my list.  The last is that south Pulaski place that tastes like plastic,  (rated #1 on WTTW Tony's Italian beef it's called)  I actually threw that one in the garbage after one bite.   And these placed come up highly rated,  I don't get it.   Want a damn good italian beef sandwich or combo.   Go to Portillo's. Your taste buds will literally explode.   It's a chain, I know,  but it is what it is,  the best Italian I've tasted till now.   Oh yeah,  Gene & Judes are not the best hot dogs around,  not by any means.   Don't trust the ratings!

34.description: We placed an order online today for a grand total of 13 subs. The instructions on the order were specific and very detailed. When I arrived back at my job, one sandwich was missing. The person whom it belonged to made a special trip to visit and her lunch was not there. Additionally, the gardiniera was missing. The instructions were that they were to be on the side for the all of the sandwiches. Instead, they were all missing. The French bread was also on the hard side so it kind of scrapped my mouth whenever I took a bite of the sandwich. Please fix this!

16.description: You just have to go here and check it out. Words can't do Bari justice. It's like being teleported back to a 1930s grocery store. The deli is amazing, get an Italian sandwich. It's huge and delicious!

13.description: Again in awe of their Italian beef and Italian sub - amazing house made  hot giardiniera - they just enough to meld with the flavors.  The market has everything I'm looking for in an Italian grocer.  The bread is from Damato's next door, the best canvas for a masterpiece.  I've tried other beef in good faith, but in the end I find myself racing to Bari to get a few bites (or more) to replace the taste lingering in my mouth.

11.description: Bari you broke my heart, you broke my heart! If this was the Godfather Bari would have to go. An utter dissapointment. After reading a columnist from Serious Eats claim that Bari's might be the best beef he ever had and Thrillist list it as its #6 beef, I just had to try it...I couldnt wait, even if it wasnt the best beef Ive ever had it would be damn close.My first bite chomp chomp, swallow a bit, roll the flavors around. What the.... Roast beefy...A step above Arby's but "possibly the best beef ive ever had" really guy from Serious Eats? Is he from California or something?! No flavors were popping in my mouth, nothing dancing...Mr. Beef, those flavors are like a sassy, hot Latina taking over the dance floor in my mouth. Bari's, a middle aged white man trying to jusr stay on his feet...Where is the Oregeno? The bread was pretty darn good...But what good is it if the beef sucks...Its like a cool take home box but if you put dog turds in their I really dont want the box now...Get my point!To be honest they seem to crank out sandwiches left and right and Ive heard great things about their cold cut subs so I probably will meander back in someday. Its an old school joint that seems to have good quality meat. Therefore I know they can do better, thats why two stars.... Just stay away from their Italian Beef!

39.description: I don't know how I'm going to get through the summer without eating Bari every weekend. Best neighborhood sub spot. Friendly atmosphere. Ridiculous prices.

37.description: I was taken here by my sous chef last Friday.  I have never had a sandwich as delicious as the footlong I had.  Ridiculously delicious, perfect bread, perfect ratio of oil and vinegar, mayo and dijon, absolutely delicious housemade giardinara, and the feel of the place was very old school Chicago so I felt very at ease.  My sous was telling me they do a very good business and I was not surprised at all - they also have a nice butcher shop but I was really there for that sub.  I will go back again and again.  Magnificent!

0.description: Love, love, love Bari's sandwiches!! It's in a small market where you can pick up the sandwiches at the deli. What's even better is the price! The sandwiches are such great quality and fresh ingredients with a low price. We got the Italian sub and prosciutto with mozzarella. I couldn't decide which sandwich I liked more and kept taking bites of both. The Italian had a good amount of meat and I loved the spicy peppers. The prosciutto with mozzarella was also delicious, although I wished it had as much filling as the Italian. Either way, yum.... Verdict: I want to go back and try all the sandwiches that are available. Grab a bag of chips and a drink in the market on your way out! You can also get one of their great sides.

38.description: This place has always had the best sub's in Chicago. My only fear is that the Major gentrification of this neighborhood will jack up the prices, or worse yet sell out to  developers. Yuppies ruin everything.

51.description: For $8 you can get a massive, tasty, Italian sub on tomato focaccia! One of the best deals around. This is a small Italian grocer with a deli counter in the back where you can get awesome made-to-order sandwiches. No area for eating in but no big deal. They accept credit cards which is convenient. If you do happen to have a few bucks on you though, stop in D'Amatos next door for some fantastic square pizza slices (they can warm them up if you're eating in) and arancini! Anywho, I highly recommend this sandwich at Bari!

27.description: I cannot stay away...they know me by name.  I fall more in love with the 12" turkey with extra hot giardeniera every day.  I don't care that they increased prices a bit.  Best sandwich in the city.  And really nice long-time employees make it even better.

32.description: A Grrreat sandwich. When your in the mood for a good sandwich you have to go to Bari, Cold and hot sandwiches and they are all great. Fresh Mozzarella taste great with the beef its awesome !!!!!!!!! Hats off to them all.

54.description: What is a better lunch than a REAL Italian sandwich? Seriously, I can't think of anything else. Bari has really great quality food for an unbelievable value. I have only been to the actual store a handful of times, and usually order for delivery. Delivery can take a while, but it is always worth the wait!

48.description: The Italian sub was a perfect blend of flavors with the hot giardiniera. My daughter was choking on her sandwich trying to eat it and say amazing at the same time!

44.description: One of the all-time great sandwich spots in the city.  The meatball sub with atomic giardiniera alone secures Bari's permanent perch in the top five best sandwiches of Chicago. This place gets wicked busy for lunch, with a line from the deli counter to the door. Or so I've heard: my experiences are always at off hours when I can peruse the fancy imported groceries and spend my well earned money.In particular, I like their selection of soda and sparkling water, their many kinds of angel wings and ornate Italian cookies, and the homemade pasta and olive salads. Delivery to my apartment in the neighborhood is always hot and fresh!

24.description: Found this through a blog and made the trip over to try it out. Great atmosphere and quick customer service. The meat was fresh and the Italian beef was served to perfection topped off with the homemade Giardiniera. Love this place and will be stopping by again.

7.description: I'll keep this nice and simple... Bari subs are a gem in Chicago and despite some recent price increases still an absolute bargain.You can get a delicious and authentic sub made from truly quality ingredients on freshly baked bread for the same general price as a junky chain like Jimmy John's... why would you even debate this choice?Walk to the back of the store to the butcher counter. There you will be greeted by a platoon of guys working diligently to make subs for what is often a sizeable line at lunchtime. Go for the traditional Italian first but also try to mix it up with a custom order using the Italian meats they have or try a house made sausage. Don't bother with generic stuff like turkey; Bari shines with the authentic Italian meats.When you are done stop by D'Amato's next door and grab some cookies... this is among the best lunches you can have in the city and it will cost you well under 10 bucks all in. you really can't beat it.

49.description: Mom and Pop shop, running at the speed of light. If you arrive at lunch/dinner, expect a line (it forms on the left aisle).This place makes & cans their own giardiniera. Just a warning, the hot really is hot. Best Italian Beef in Chicago? Check. Cops eat here? Check. The unapologetic staff corrects my attempt at Italian? Check.This is a great, local, neighborhood place, a true gem in the area.

40.description: Ordered food from Bari this afternoon for delivery through yelp.  After confirming my order and after an hour waiting, I got an email stating that they cancelled the order because they decided to close early.  Now how many yelp stars would you give a place that did this??  I've stopped in many times and while their subs are really good and affordable, the Sunday management team has a lot to learn about customer service....

53.description: Best Spicy Italian sub in Chicago.The extra spicy giardiniera is really spicy and really good.The pepper jack cheese actually has a pepper jack taste.You taste every part of the sandwich in every bite.So good.

30.description: They jacked up their prices last week when they got a new sign. They incorrectly charged me for a sub. It says on the menu- roast beef and cheese-$6.75. They proceeded to charge me an extra $.75 for cheese even though it's supposed to be included. I've been going here for 7 years, and I always thought it was good for the price.
