And coffee that can grow chest hairs on you for bitterness is not my idea of good. CLOSE DOWN and open up a Dunkin Donuts here, after all we are only students!

29.description: I bought 10 of my friends here on a Friday night and it was spectacular. We ate so much and everyone agreed the UN-marinated kalbi was amazing. The older Korean lady, who I suspect is the owner and is always overwork was SO friendly towards us after our 3 round of giant Korean beer and she came over to ensure we knew how to cook our food and how to serve it.She made a "Korean lettuce taco" for my friend Dianne and shoved it in her mouth which was SO HILARIOUS and endearing for the rest of us!I love coming here. Hope it never gets too busy like the other two popular places for my sake!

42.description: This place seems very authentic.  I mean, our food looked just like the pictures on wikipedia.  That means it's authentic right?  (Google Banchan and see for yourself.  You'll get a whole slew of those, whatever you order.  I think.)  I don't know.  I had a nice bowl of fish soup, chock full of bits and pieces and odds and ends of various unidentified ingredients.  It was fishy and half way through or so I even discovered a big old clam.  But it glared at me and muttered something under its breath, so I put it back.  Clams can be like that - very negative and unpleasant.  My companion (I LOVE YOU, HONEY) had the bibimbap.  I suggested it to her because it was fun to say.  Bibimbap.  (I now use this word regularly, often when I shower.  It makes my showers more korean.)  Google bibimbap.  You see those wikipedia pics?  Yeah, it looked just like that, but no raw egg yolk.  It was a cooked egg yolk. So anyhow, oddly, the dish is served cold.  I mean, it looks like something that would be served hot, right?  Nope.  Cold.  You mash it all up (the yolk makes for a sauce) and eat it up.  It seems kind of wrong in a way, like you're playing in the kitchen and trying to make the grossest thing possible to feed to a friend or loved one.  I mean, who goes out to eat in Chicago for something good?  Especially if you didn't grow up here.  You go out to find something fun!  SO GO HERE

23.description: There's quite a bit of difference in service at San Soo Gab San and Cho Sun Ok, in comparison to this place.  At those two Chicago staples, the older ladies have a language barrier mostly speaking Korean, and are so busy that some may confuse their lack of service as being rude.  No, lemme tell you about RUDE.  Karen, or Kara, or whatever her young smart ass, name is a Boo-il Galbi. The entire menu was written in Korean characters, with no pictures to point out to when ordering.  I prefaced we didn't' speak Korean, and didn't know how to correctly pronounce the names of certain dishes, and what do I get hit with?  1) rolling eyes2) smart ass, condescending comments3) smirksNow, I don't have any tolerance for BULLSHIT.  But, just for good measure, I let the first occurrence slide just in case I was being sensitive.  The second time, when she walked away, I asked my dinnermates their thoughts on her attitude.  Yep, these very laid back folks noticed it too.  However, being as laid back as they were, they still decided to stay, even when in fact, I wanted to LEAVE. "Fine," I said.  "but if she says anything else, I'm saying SOMETHING"Hence occurrence #3, which led to a verbal confrontation, and some threats of me leaving (you guys can stay, I'll holla).  Waitress apologized profusely, claiming she didn't even mean to come off that way, but C'MON! If you scoff at a customer for attempting to read the menu or ask a question, that's outright rude.  As I pointed out to her, I'd be glad to go and spend my money somewhere else for Korean bbq.  I have in fact, been on a Korean bbq tour, so it's not loss on my part. The kalbi was decent, their cha dul bae gi was bland and lackluster. But what I came here specifically upon another Yelper's suggestion, was the gaeran jim, the fluffy egg soufflé served at many Cali Korean bbq.  Their gaeran jim was quite disappointing, as it was very runny and tasted watery.  Their banchan wasn't plentiful like San Soo, or fresh like Cho Sun, so it was nothing to write home about.  All in all, everything was quite disappointing.  I'd go to one of the very many Korean restaurants in the area for better service and better food.

8.description: walked out before even ordering!What a rip off.  We went in and were about to order a few beef items for BBQ, but were informed that we needed to order 2 of each item we were selecting.  No- not at least 2 items, rather 2 OF EACH.  Thus...we left.

31.description: Okay all you, kimche loving, Korean bbqing, grease on you shirt loving people, THIS IS THE PLACE TO GO. They have traditional charcoal grills, this place has better homemade kimiches than San Soo Gab San in Lincoln Square. Things to get cold buck wheat noodles spicy mix ( in a red chili sauce) then main course with a group of 5 I suggest 4 servings of "cal bi" or in English marinated beef short rib meat, comes with steamed white rice and and *god like* amount of kimches. The food might be a tad bit salty, so drink lots of water and bring beano. Go after 5:00pm and not before 8:00pm.

34.description: Unmarinated galbi is where it's at here.  We came on a cold Sunday evening, and things were very quiet inside Boo-il.  It's in an interesting stretch of Koreatown, close to the two bingsoo cafes in town, the KBS studios, and a few other random little restaurants.Probably because we were only one of three tables in the restaurant, service was pretty hands-off, but that's typical of KBBQ - you're cooking the meat yourself, after all!Reasonable prices, low-key atmosphere... come hungry and leave happy!

16.description: "So bad!  What kind of restaurant makes you cook your own food?"  Although Bill Murray disapproves of this style of dining, I rather enjoyed it.  It was adventurous AND delicious, a combination that doesn't always appear together.  It was my first experience with Korean BBQ, and there was a bit of a language barrier, but it wasn't insurmountable to a hungry Joe B.  Actually, to this day, I'm not sure exactly what I ingested, but cooking meat over a charcoal grill is a talent innate to all men.  My qualms, besides the scant menu descriptors, are the prices and the decor.  A meal for two was about $80, and the restaurant had the visual appeal of an Arby's.  If you're into Korean BBQ, the food was delicious, and you really should stop by.

13.description: Went here with a Korean co-worker who did all of the ordering so I'm not sure exactly what we had, but it was pretty good- we started with some seafood pancake / omelette which was pretty tasty, then had rib meat cooked over an open grill, plus some kind of beef in a steamer cooker, with rice and Korean sides on the side. Very tasty and pretty reasonable. Off the beaten path though if you're staying downtown.

11.description: First of all, don't come here if you don't have anyone knows how to speak Korean in your party.  My husband and I came here on a Thursday night, the woman at first was friendly, sat us down. Then somehow she discovered I'm not Korean, and she started giving us the attitude--from not smiling, to asking if we needed the menu to begin with. Hellooo, who doesn't need menus at a restaurant?!  We ordered some marinated kalbi and kimchi jjigae. They started off with some steamed eggs, really really yummy and much needed on a cold day. Pan chan was good, not the best, but given her attitude, I was expecting way less, so i was pleasantly surprised.  The meat was nicely marinated, the kimchi jjigae was one of better ones I've had in Chicago, but other places aren't that far off.All in all, not bad, but not worth the drive in my mind. And given the typical Korean attitude, I don't think I'd be back.

39.description: I call myself as an expert in Korean food and this place has the best unmarinated gal bi! So many of my Korean friends told me about this place and I had my doubt before I went there since I went to many Korean restaurant and they were good and bad.  This place blew my mind.. !! This place is very authentic which means it's not a fancy dressy restaurant. It's more like old school Korean restaurant and food tastes awesome. I wish I live close to this place so I can go every week. When you see a lot of Korean people in the Korean restaurant, it's always a goooood sign!

37.description: My girlfriend and I went here for Valentine's Day and surprisingly the restaurant was almost empty, a rare sight for a Korean BBQ place. The atmosphere was not the best but at least there was no wait for food and the place was quiet. The lady who brought us our food was helpful and friendly although she looked very overworked :(We had the unmarinated kalbi which was tasty. My only complaint about the food is that you have to put in two orders of the same meat. If you're going to make someone put in two orders of meat, at least let them try different meat. The banchan was great although there was not as much variety as at some other places. I guess you don't really need 25 different kinds of banchan. The kim chi was especially delicious and not as tangy as I've had before (which is a good thing for me). My biggest complaint is the fact that cooking the meat is a smoky affair. The vent blows the smoke around rather than suck it up. And it gets very cold at the table when the vent is on. Overall, I'd give 5 stars for the food and about 3 stars for everything else.

0.description: This place is amazing! I've been looking for an authentic Korean restaurant since I moved here and I've found it. (I hate saying authentic cause I feel like I'm coming off as a snob :/ but I just want something that reminds me of my mom's cooking when I'm away from home) The kalbi was marinated perfectly, everything tasted fresh and the ban chan was delicious. I'll definitely go back :)Disclaimer: Koreans do not have a focus on customer service, so don't go in expecting tons of smiles and attention. That's not how it works; go for the food.

38.description: first we went to San Soo Gab San but the wait was a hr...so i hopped on my yelp app (gawd i love it) and looked for another place and Boo-il came up...so i gave them a call and found out there was no wait..and since i was starving like a hostage we made the decision to leave the crowd at san soo. the place was def not packed only two other tables there who promptly turned and looked at the two black chicks walking in and began to chatter in korean. but we're a lively duo and just said hello and waved..lol..the place is def not fancy and decorated for your viewing pleasure so don't go in expecting exquisite decorations. the waitress came over and gave us menus and said need any help and explained that we had to order 2 of the same items as a minimum and that was pretty much the extent of what she said to us at first. we put in our order and then she went to the back where i'm assuming she had a shot of her "make me awesome" juice back there because when she came back she was super nice and really being nice and talking to us. the banchan was sooo good, there was not a single thing on the table that i didn't like. i love spicy food so i really like the jalapeno and onion one and the kimchi was great. then came out the meat and she gave us tips on cooking the bones and with throwing some meat on the grill. then came the soup and rice and then we were really cooking. the food was A-MAZING!! the galbi was so well seasoned and tender and since im not a huge red meat person that's a big compliment from me.  we def couldn't finish all the food on the table but i'm happy to have some waiting for me in the fridge for...well, now..lol....i highly recommend this place, reluctantly though because i want to keep it all to myself on a sat night without an hr wait. but you should go because the food is really awesome!!

27.description: On my first visit I took a friend, on our second visit just one week later we came with 5...  The food both times was off the chain!  English is not spoken here; leaping of faith is a necessary action with in these modest confines...  The service is, well, questionable at many levels, and then charming beyond understanding at other levels...  On both our visits we were the only non-Koreans in attendance, which is always a good sign when eating traditional ethnic food...  What really separates this place from most Korean BBQs is the use of traditional charcoal cooking pots at the table, and as we all know the flavor achieved using legit charcoal is like no other...  In our multiple visits we tried just about every beef option available and every last piece was flavorful juicy and just perfect to the last bite!  I have seen more sides at other places, but more is not always better, the Kim Chi here is off the hook!  I was devouring it straight up, in my lettuce wraps and even sashimi style hoisted atop little bites of meat perfection...This place is just great, but be prepared for a full experience, kind of like being in grandmas kitchen, not my grandma, but someone's, she had no sense of urgency but in the end it was all worth it and beyond any ones expectations...I will return!

32.description: I debated over four and five and the only reason i would give them a four is the price was just average, not a great deal.  however, the food was amazing.  after my first bite i said, "this is the best beef i've ever had".  just thinking about the charred, slightly sweet pieces of meat make my mouth water.  we had the marinated kalbi, maybe next time we will get the unmarinated kind.  service was a little slow, but the fact that one of the waitress spoke real english was a gift from heaven.  usually at korean places, all you get is broken english.  but our waitress spoke english as a first language! she also helped us not order too much.  she also explained that we had to get two orders to cook at the table.  if we wanted, we could have them cook it in the back, but there is a BIG difference in taste.  when it is cooked in the back it is cooked in a skillet of a stove, not on top of a wood and charcoal grill.  there would not have been that explanation if she didn't speak real english!  as others have said, there is no ambience here except for a lot of smoke.  it's just wooden tables with ghetto chairs, but you go for the meat not the decor.

44.description: Best 'saeng kalbi' place ever. (Saeng kalbi being unmarinated--you dip it in sesame oil/salt usually to eat. I haven't tried their marinated stuff but I'm sure it's fine--it's pretty hard to mess up). I don't know where they get their beef but seriously. I don't even like plain beef usually... but I get cravings for this place :) The meat is all self-cook (as usual) and it's cooked on coals (not an electric fire) which means you need to watch carefully to make sure you don't burn everything. But if the pan is too hot, just tell the people there and they'll stack another pan on top to adjust the rate of cooking.The decor is kind of bleh, but who cares. The restaurant is definitely clean. The ventilation system works pretty well if you fiddle with it, so you usually don't smell smoke-ish afterwards. They give lots and lots of side dishes... off the top of my head, they usually serve (for example): boochim (Korean pancakes), regular kimchi, bokkum kimchi (sauteed is the best word, I guess), radish kimchi, some sort of potato thing that shows up in some variation or another at kalbi restaurants, and egg-jjim (steamed egg). If you don't get the egg, you can ask for it. Also, the dwen-jang-jjigae (a common korean soup) here is exactly suited to my taste.I think the restaurant is mostly run by one lady (and a person or two in the kitchen who will bring out coals, etc) and she's super nice. But since she's usually one of the only people there there's sometimes a bit of a wait, depending on how many people are at the restaurant.Definitely try this place out, and don't get fooled by the interior decorations.

24.description: Interesting little mom and pop shop on the bryn mawr. We really didn't know what to expect, but what we definitely received was attitude and bad service. Our waitress, was rolling her eyes at us and making inappropriate comments that belittled us. We had to hunt her down to take our orders, after sitting around for about 30 minutes without water or menus. After we received both, it took another 20 minutes to order. We actually went to refill water ourselves, but then she was offended, saying "this water is warm, you'll get ice water later."but we were thirsty already!!! after 1 hour of waiting!She recommended the house specify, not marinated kalbi. Which was good, but in VERY small portions. The marinated kalbi was good too, but the best was the spicy pork. Big portions and big taste.We were cooking the spicy pork table side, and the waitress hurried to us and said "this is not how to cook, cook this way like you cook at home. Or you'll burn our pot."but we don't cook korean at home.Just random commends and lots of eye rolling. Of course she also added 20% tip to our total.Horrible.

7.description: DON'T COME HERE EVER!!!!!!!Wish there could be a zero star for this restaurant. The service is so bad that the lady started to raise her voice to us. The whole dinner, no one to get us water or food. THEY RIP YOU OFF!! You have to get two orders (meaning two each) on the menu with the "MP". And guess how much is the MP..its $32 each. We got ripped off big time today and had a fight the rude lady with she threatening to call the cops on us. I feel sorry for this restaurant!

40.description: the food here is pretty tasty.there's really no service.  the restaurant was empty when we first came and the lady barely said anything to us and only gave us what we ordered. then a group of obnoxious korean guys came in and all of a sudden the lady was super nice to them (as if she was scared of them or something)... they sit down and start lighting up their smokes! wtf!we look over in disgust and the lady asks us if there's something we need or if there's a problem and first we try to brush it off but she insists so we tell her we're bothered by the kids smoking and she takes the blame by saying 'oh i told them they could smoke indoors cus it's cold outside, plus you won't smell it since the fans are on'... obviously she didn't get that we were bothered about the kids' behaviors... i mean it's more about the principle... plus there are signs on the wall that state there's no smoking inside the restaurant... man, you gotta stand up for yourself lady...soon after two young ladies come in and act all as if the lady at the restaurant's their friend 'hi unni (big sister)....' bla bla... where are these young korean kids' manners?? i mean yea ok you're a regular at this restaurant but come on!  the lady at this restaurant could be your mom! have some respect!from a service stand-point, i don't think i'd want to return to a business like this.  we were the most civil and well-mannered people there and yet we got the short end of the stick... but if you're not korean (or part korean or familiar with the korean culture) maybe you won't have to deal with that kind of crap.an experience like this just gives a bad name to the korean community.  quite a pity...

30.description: I've been on a big KBBQ fix this entire week (third one this week) and we checked out Boo Il Friday night. It's a bit down the ways, but it was easy to find. It wasn't that crowded for a Friday night, however there is a smoking and non-smoking section. So... of course I was a little irked by the smoking section. We sat at a larger round table even though there were just two of us. But it was fine because it gave us more room to eat when all the food came out. The server we had was pretty stern/ straight forward. We started off with dumplings which were standard, followed by kimchi chiggae (reaaaaally burning-hot and spicy). We had about 7 sides of banchan, with one really good veggie that we couldn't figure out what it was. We ordered this pork bulgogi - which was prepared in a different way I guess. It came out in this iron pan a la Indian food and it was really spicy, but good. Abridged review:  fairly priced restaurant, good food, but not sure if I'd return.

46.description: the galbi here is excellent.  tender, juicy and marinated to perfection!  you cook your own meat and they give you tons of appetizer/side dishes that are standard at any korean bbq restaurants.the food here is delish but the atmosphere is so-so.  it has a dingy appeal to it. i just remember a lot of pressed wood panels.  but i come here for the food, not the decor.  the prices are standard korean bbq prices so i didn't feel gipped.this is a great place to bring your friends to eat meat while drinking korean liquor.  may i suggest the soju?

1.description: Food: galbi was good! But holy crap 32 dollars/per person?! It was also frozen. The side dishes were okay, but the bean paste soup was authentic korean soup (good thing). The lettuce that came with the food was fresh. They also use charcoals to grill food, which add more flavors.Service: it's crap. I get that korean ajummas (old ladies) are sometimes not nice, but she was extra rude just throwing the food on the table. She was also standing behind us and looking at us when we were counting our money, which was uncomfortable. Tl;dr food was good but expensive. The service was bad.

9.description: I just had probably the worst dining experience here. There was no service, the food fucking sucks, and the server is fucking rude. They treated us differently because we weren't Korean. They charged us three orders for two people. The total was $94! What the fuck? When confronted, she raised her voice and threatened us to call the cops! Avoid this place!

26.description: So this was my first experience doing Korean BBQ. And it was great. And to help those, who like me, were a bit confused on how to be initiated into the world of table-top Korean grilling I have written:Koren BBQ for White Girls 101Boo-il Galbi is a great place to have your first experience. The waitress who greeted us (as opposed to when we went to Chicago Kalbi and weren't even acknowledged, and had to stand awkwardly in the doorway behind a crowd until we gave up and left) was friendly and helpful. There was no language barrier, and she informed us how to pick, cook, and enjoy our food. So...TIP #1 - Ask your server for help, or see if you can bring an experienced friend along. Remember this is your meal, don't be afraid to ask for help to fully enjoy the experience!It appears that most places want you to purchase two orders of one dish to get a cooker at your table. The reason you can't order individual items is because each item may be cooked in a different way, and you have to order enough meat to make it worth it to make the fire. Plus, some items may not go along with others - ie: some may be cooked over flame, others in a small hot skillet. Thus,TIP #2 - Pick which meat your group likes best and order 2. Base your other choices on meats cooked in the same fashion. Refer to Tip 1 if you don't know which these are.As you wait for your little fire to arrive, you are provided with some sort of hot tea. While this was great because it was FREEZING in the restaurant (I believe due to the grill vents in the ceiling) the tea wasn't exactly.....everyone's cup of tea. It had a very...acquired taste. Thankfully once the fire arrived, we all warmed up even without the beverage.TIP #3 - You don't have to drink the tea, you can ask for water. And you can take your coat off when the grill arrives as you will defrost then.If you wonder why you are waiting it is because it takes them time to ready up your table top camp fire. Not too long though, about 10-15 minutes. When it comes out it IS rather exciting. With it you are provided an array of side dishes while you wait for your meat. Tip #4 = Try all the side dishes, even if you have no idea what they are.Then finally the meat arrives. We had the marinated short rib first, which was thin cuts of beautifully marbled steak. It also game with four large rib bone chunks (more on that later). Now it was time to cook!Tip #5 - Take the meat in the tongs and place several slices of meat on the grill, making sure they are flat. Let them cook for a minute or two (you will see the edges start to get a nice brown) and then flip them. You can also grill the garlic cloves, but be careful not to burn them.Tip #6 - Don't burn the meat! Once the meat has been cooked on both sides, snag it off with your chopsticks. DO NOT USE THE TONGS. They were just getting cuddly with some raw meat juices...not tasty.Tip #7 - Put your meat, a little rice, some sauce, a little garlic, and a little of the seaweed shreds in a leaf of lettuce. Roll and eat and talk about how good it is with your mouth full. It is also acceptable to shove the meat directly into your mouth, granted it isn't still burningly hot from the fire it just sat on.Tip #8 - The bone hunks sit on the grill at the edges, NOT in the middle. Let them cook, turning them occasionally, while you cook all your other meat. It takes them awhile and you can't always tell by sight. Once cooked, pull it off, let it cool, and eat the bits of meat attached to the bone. You may be provided scissors to cut the meat off (and any char from the long grill time) and for the true meat-lover, it is so, so worth it. This chewy, juicy meat has some of the best flavor and nutrition, thanks to the bone that gave it tasty awesomeness.In addition to the beef we had pork belly...which is not intestines (as the nonfoodie may initially think) but a type of BACON. Yum.Tip #9 - When cooking fattier meats (like bacon) on the charcoal grill, keep them on the edges. The melting fat makes the flame flare, and will potentially burn your bacon. Tragic.Tip #10 - The pork belly is served with a sesame seed oil with salt and pepper. A little touch of this to the pork belly is excellent, but don't go overboard.and finally...Tip #11 - Don't plan on going to a friend's house or anywhere fancy after this, unless they don't mind you smelling like fire and grilled meat. But really, why should you hang out with anyone who doesn't like the smell of grilled delicious meat?Overall the experience was a blast. Yes we were freezing until the fire was brought out, and the place could use some redecorating. But the service was awesome, the food was fantastic, and it was a FUN interactive dining experience. Bring your friends and grill it up, baby.

25.description: Perfect example of a Korean BBQ where if ya don't know whatcha gettin', you probably ain't gettin' the right thing!  But really, that's just a matter of how good your Korean is.  And mine is pretty damn horrid, but apparently just enough to get by!I've been a fan of Boo-Il Galbi since who knows when- basically since it opened like 20+ years ago.  And it's still the same sweet ol' owner who makes the same amazing food that never fails to remind me I'm home.  Obviously, the decor is a little shanty and could use a facelift- but the food is great and the loyal customers like myself really keep it going.And for folks actually reading this because you want to know what's good there... Korean BBQ, duh!  Ask for some marinated galbi (short ribs), thinly sliced ribeye, and pork belly- all equally awesome choices!  Also, I'm a huuuge fan of their doenjang chige (korean soybean paste soup).

12.description: I love that they use charcoal. That is it. That's all you need to know. Kara, our server, was really nice and amiable. I don't understand what my fellow Yelpers were complaining about. Maybe there was a misunderstanding? Who knows, but she was nice to us, and we enjoyed her company.My sister was in town and she wanted Korean BBQ so we came here. This is where my sister and I differ in our tastes--- she likes marinated meat, and she doesn't eat beef. What, why did you want me to take you to a Korean BBQ place??!! So for my sister's sake, we mostly ordered marinated meat. Boo-il Galbi's marinated meat were good, but I don't really have a taste for them. I prefer the non-marinated meat because the marinated ones seem a bit too sweet to me. But thankfully, my sister relented for galbi. So we had non-marinated beef short ribs. Yum!! The charcoal added a slight smoky flavor to it, and I was in heaven.The meat were priced at market price because as Kara explained, the price of beef were going up all over the world. Our total for 3 orders were approximately $101 for three people. Wow, a bit expensive.At the end, we were served doenjang jjigae. I found myself wondering if perhaps I've been spoiled in the past because boo-il galbi only gave me about half the serving I was used to. It was still good, but I prefer the doenjang jjigae elsewhere.

21.description: I've been to every Korean restaurant on Bryn Mawr and this is the only one that has BBQ. We ordered the marinated Kalbi, which was "market price" and should of been a clue that it would be expensive.I thought our waitress was a bit patronizing because she kept telling my husband and I what things were and how to cook. I wanted to say something, but my husband pointed out that the waitress had no idea that we've eaten Korean food a bazillion times and probably were doing things wrong.The meat was ok, the pan chan was a bit lacking, and our bill was very high. We ordered 2 Kalbi and an O.B. and it was almost $60.  I wouldn't go back because there are better BBQ spots than this one, but I appreciate that I have this option walking distance from my house.

17.description: There's quite a bit of difference in service at San Soo Gab San and Cho Sun Ok, in comparison to this place.  At those two Chicago staples, the older ladies have a language barrier mostly speaking Korean, and are so busy that some may confuse their lack of service as being rude.  No, lemme tell you about RUDE.  Karen, or Kara, or whatever her young smart ass, name is a Boo-il Galbi. The entire menu was written in Korean characters, with no pictures to point out to when ordering.  I prefaced we didn't' speak Korean, and didn't know how to correctly pronounce the names of certain dishes, and what do I get hit with?  1) rolling eyes2) smart ass, condescending comments3) smirksNow, I don't have any tolerance for BULLSHIT.  But, just for good measure, I let the first occurrence slide just in case I was being sensitive.  The second time, when she walked away, I asked my dinnermates their thoughts on her attitude.  Yep, these very laid back folks noticed it too.  However, being as laid back as they were, they still decided to stay, even when in fact, I wanted to LEAVE. "Fine," I said.  "but if she says anything else, I'm saying SOMETHING"Hence occurrence #3, which led to a verbal confrontation, and some threats of me leaving (you guys can stay, I'll holla).  Waitress apologized profusely, claiming she didn't even mean to come off that way, but C'MON! If you scoff at a customer for attempting to read the menu or ask a question, that's outright rude.  As I pointed out to her, I'd be glad to go and spend my money somewhere else for Korean bbq.  I have in fact, been on a Korean bbq tour, so it's not loss on my part. The kalbi was decent, their cha dul bae gi was bland and lackluster. But what I came here specifically upon another Yelper's suggestion, was the gaeran jim, the fluffy egg soufflé served at many Cali Korean bbq.  Their gaeran jim was quite disappointing, as it was very runny and tasted watery.  Their banchan wasn't plentiful like San Soo, or fresh like Cho Sun, so it was nothing to write home about.  All in all, everything was quite disappointing.  I'd go to one of the very many Korean restaurants in the area for better service and better food.

10.description: I went there with my parents and sister and the food was goodbut they lied about the price.they said the galbi was 18.95 and we ordered three servings and when the bill came out they marked it as 19.95. the thing is, we went there like four years ago. and they didn't bother changing the menu, and they told us they were going but they didn't.also, last time we came my dad did not put any tip and he paid with card, so the owner put in ten dollars on our own check. and she did not have any right to do so.she gave herself more than a 15% tip, and she didn't even deserve it.

5.description: This place used to be the best unmarinated kalbi in Chicago. Service was always bad but has gotten significantly worse to the point that I am embarrassed to bring any guests to this restaurant. Additionally, the pricing has become absolutely ridiculous ("market price" on my last trip was over $35 per order, will need at least one order to be enough per person). Don't eat here. Your ego and wallet will both regret it.

3.description: Wow this was a new experience.  Wish it was a good one, but it was not. Heard about this place providing very high quality beef.  Went there with some friends of my wife.  We ordered ribeye non-marinated.  We should have known when the meat was marked MP for both marinate and no marinated ribeye.When we were paying, we found out the rib was 34 bucks per person which was way out of proportion for the quality of meat.  Porkbelly was 20 bucks, which was obviously frozen. Now with all these stuff the server's remark that tip should be separately paid just irked us even more because the service was minimal/abysmal.  We seriously considered not paying the tip but decided to leave 10% because you could already see she would chase us to ask for the tip.At the end it just feels like we were scammed on our dinner, which wasn't common at all.

35.description: Two must-haves: the sang galbi and the deng jang chigae, which comes with the BBQ meats. I love this place for the food, but my main and huge complaint is the service. There is usually only one ahjumah working there and one bus boy. I think this ahjumah does the cooking and serving, so she is stretched thin and the result is neglectful service, not even rude service. I have no problems with rude service as long as I'm getting some attention. Geesh. The ambiance is lacking, of course, but Korean BBQ has an ambiance genre of its own. Overall, service is horrible, but the food is so darn good I come back periodically and put up with the neglectful service.

19.description: Tonight for dinner, I took my business partner's family to Boo-il.  They wanted U.S.A Beef as they are from singapore and U.S. beef is very hard to come by and also Very expensive.Although the service can be very slow, it's so casual, I usually go to the kitchen and let her know what I need and i'll just bring it back to the table.  Even though it can be pricey, you need to consider that very well marbled meat isn't easy to come by and don't forget that this is also cooked on charcoal.The place may look old and empty but it's full of heart and passion when it comes to the actual product they are selling.  THE FOOD.Seriously, don't be cheap when  you eat here.  Spend a little more and get the un-marinated kalbi sal.  This is truly the only way you can enjoy the quality of the USDA prime beef and appreciate the marbling.

28.description: Came here on a Tuesday night around 8 with a party of 4 and were the only people in the restaurant. This should be a 4 star review but the whole "you must purchase 2 of each choice" is really a head scratcher. We had the marinated beef short ribs which were EXCELLENT and pork bacon with kimchi and other assorted veggies (the latter was cooked in a gas skillet at our table). The short ribs were listed as "market price" and when we asked about the cost the woman kind of scrunched up her face and thought about it before (seemingly) pulling $21.95 out of her butt. Not highway robbery  by any means but it was still funny.Regardless- great food, appropriately friendly and helpful service - but having to buy 2 of each item you want is lame. The 4 of us would have split 3 items (it really is a lot of food) but since we had to get 2 of each I feel like we ended up paying an extra $20 for food we didn't need. Also: I didn't leave reeking like meat. Which was weird.

45.description: It was an interesting experience when we went there since we had kalbi that wasn't marinated and they give you a sesame oil/salt & pepper mixture dip for it. Typically I have marinated kalbi but it was still tasty in its own way.  Pan chan was good and loved the fact that we also had the steamed eggs dish.  I know some people may want more from this place in terms of atmosphere but I don't mind since I'm used to these kinds of places growing up and for me, it's the food that's the most important.

33.description: Yum. Exactly what everyone else said. Old school, no frills, come for the meat. We got right in at 8pm on a Saturday night, no wait for a table. There only appeared to be one wait person for all the tables. She was quick and efficient when the food was ready, and was nice to us when we asked questions, even through she had her hands full.There is parking in the back (and ample parking out front or in the neighborhood). Everything is delicious.

43.description: I was in the mood for Korean (well I'm always in a mood for something)so I yelped and found this restaurant.. so I thought I would give it a shot.I've had Korean BBQ before, but it was nothing like this. The meat was so so.. so.. tender.. and it was well seasoned... Not only that, you grill the meat yourself according to how you like it. Their Kim-Chi is the best I've ever tasted. The service is excellent, the lady was so helpful and she even rolled out food and was trying to feed me. Hahaha!Don't let the look of the restaurant fool you.. cause when I walk in, I had second guesses but I stayed anyways cause I was feeling very Korean-ny (at that time..). I didn't regret one bit, the food was awesome, the service is excellent.Look at the picture.. Doesn't it make you hungry? :)

2.description: Avoid this place at all cost. No service and the banchans (side dishes) that come with the main dishes are terrible. Galbi is "market price" -- well what the hell is MP for galbi? whooping $32 per 1 person serving. And when someone orders naeng-myun with galbi, you suppose to bring it out AFTER the customer finish the galbi. Well, the restaurant brings it "with" the galbi. Moreover, the yang-nyum naeng-myun is marinated with "red pepper paste", which you should NOT use this sauce in making the dish. Will never return this place again.

18.description: Interesting little mom and pop shop on the bryn mawr. We really didn't know what to expect, but what we definitely received was attitude and bad service. Our waitress, was rolling her eyes at us and making inappropriate comments that belittled us. We had to hunt her down to take our orders, after sitting around for about 30 minutes without water or menus. After we received both, it took another 20 minutes to order. We actually went to refill water ourselves, but then she was offended, saying "this water is warm, you'll get ice water later."but we were thirsty already!!! after 1 hour of waiting!She recommended the house specify, not marinated kalbi. Which was good, but in VERY small portions. The marinated kalbi was good too, but the best was the spicy pork. Big portions and big taste.We were cooking the spicy pork table side, and the waitress hurried to us and said "this is not how to cook, cook this way like you cook at home. Or you'll burn our pot."but we don't cook korean at home.Just random commends and lots of eye rolling. Of course she also added 20% tip to our total.Horrible.

41.description: If you're looking to eat some seriously good kalbi, this is the place . I'm a meat lover and I've been to lots of kalbi places in Korea but Boo Il impressed me with the meat quality. This place is just as good as really good kalbi places in Korea. The owner buys special quality kalbi. The saeng kalbi is the best here. I heard that boolgogi's not as good. And you get free jjigae and rice after eating kalbi. Highly recommend this place!!!

4.description: BEST un-marinated beef in the chicago area. It is a bit pricey but not overboard compared to other korean bbq restaurants in the area. If you want good consistent quality un-marinated beef korean style bbq, this is the place to go.Appetizer dishes are great as well.I especially LOVE the  here. It is the best! Plus the !! Is to die for. I had relatives from korea and from canada (montreal) and they all agreed that boo-il was the best. The  tastes really good because the owner makes her own batch of dwenjang(), which is fermented soy bean paste (traditional in korea-similar to miso paste).If you don't like spicy food, you should ask ahead that you want it mild because it has a little kick.

6.description: Seng kalbi is marbled well. Unless you like a real smoky taste ask for them to cook it with two grates instead of one. I love smoke but it overpowers the meat flavor.Probably the best non-all-you-can-eat kalbi place in Chicago. Don't waste your time at other "novel" places. Simple and good is all you need.Dwenjang jigae at the end of your meal!Went when it wasn't busy and got great service.

22.description: I love that they use charcoal. That is it. That's all you need to know. Kara, our server, was really nice and amiable. I don't understand what my fellow Yelpers were complaining about. Maybe there was a misunderstanding? Who knows, but she was nice to us, and we enjoyed her company.My sister was in town and she wanted Korean BBQ so we came here. This is where my sister and I differ in our tastes--- she likes marinated meat, and she doesn't eat beef. What, why did you want me to take you to a Korean BBQ place??!! So for my sister's sake, we mostly ordered marinated meat. Boo-il Galbi's marinated meat were good, but I don't really have a taste for them. I prefer the non-marinated meat because the marinated ones seem a bit too sweet to me. But thankfully, my sister relented for galbi. So we had non-marinated beef short ribs. Yum!! The charcoal added a slight smoky flavor to it, and I was in heaven.The meat were priced at market price because as Kara explained, the price of beef were going up all over the world. Our total for 3 orders were approximately $101 for three people. Wow, a bit expensive.At the end, we were served doenjang jjigae. I found myself wondering if perhaps I've been spoiled in the past because boo-il galbi only gave me about half the serving I was used to. It was still good, but I prefer the doenjang jjigae elsewhere.

15.description: Boo-il Galbi is a great restaurant if you are already used to Korean bbq. They actually use wood charcoal, which cooks the saeng(unmarinated) beef quickly and with a lovely sear. The few times I have been here, I have always ordered the saeng galbi. The quality of the meat is heads and shoulders above most other Korean restaurants. The meat comes pre cut in bite size rectangular cubes and has great marbling, probably from a prime or choice cut. Sear each side of meat for perhaps a minute and you are ready to go with either a traditional lettuce wrap, or with a sesame oil/salt/pepper dip and other traditional sides. Another plus to Boo-il is that the vents above the tables actually work. Unlike San Soo Gab San, where the minute you walk in, your clothes will be saturated with the smell of Korean bbq(not all that bad, unless you are headed out afterwards), you can  actually make plans afterwards and not worry too much about the smell. My only complaint, and a big enough one to deter me from ever going back again, is the price and the quantity. Their marinated/unmarinated galbi is subject to market price which is understandable as the cost of meat can rise, but it is too expensive for the quantity that you receive for two orders. Two orders of saeng galbi and a spicy tofu soup for $64...no alcohol. Add a couple of beers and a bottle of soju and you are looking at perhaps $100. That is too expensive. I will not talk about the service here because all Korean restaurants conduct service at a reactionary level. You want something? Grab their attention, flag them down. They might not like your request, but they will still probably get it for you. If you don't need anything, it is likely you will never be visited by them again unless it is to drop off the check. All in all a solid, if expensive, restaurant.

20.description: Tonight for dinner, I took my business partner's family to Boo-il.  They wanted U.S.A Beef as they are from singapore and U.S. beef is very hard to come by and also Very expensive.Although the service can be very slow, it's so casual, I usually go to the kitchen and let her know what I need and i'll just bring it back to the table.  Even though it can be pricey, you need to consider that very well marbled meat isn't easy to come by and don't forget that this is also cooked on charcoal.The place may look old and empty but it's full of heart and passion when it comes to the actual product they are selling.  THE FOOD.Seriously, don't be cheap when  you eat here.  Spend a little more and get the un-marinated kalbi sal.  This is truly the only way you can enjoy the quality of the USDA prime beef and appreciate the marbling.

36.description: We came here for a friend's birthday dinner, and was not disappointed.  I am surprised that it was kind of empty, but people did start trickling in after us.  While we waited for the last person to arrive we started out with fried dumplings, which were burning our tongues hot.   We then got 2 orders of the kalbi as there is a minimum of 2 and I think that they have to be the same too.  The kalbi was very good.  I usually leave Korean bbq spots stuffed, but I was full but not wheeling myself out.  The price was average, and the lady was really quiet and didn't see too much of her and would have appreciated another glass of water or tea.

14.description: I loved the bibimbap and kimche. I don't know what kind of "tea" that was served to us, but it was horrible. Other than that, I enjoyed. Pricy for small dishes though.

1.description: One of my favorite spots. The owners are always on deck and ready to make you feel like its your old tradition to stop in and catch a show.I'm in the entertainment business and when you just to chill, grab your favorite drink for a really low price (the place is a BYOB so no Bottle Service or over priced drinks), and listen to some of the best of Chicago's indy artists this is the spot.A rich history of music and culture jump off the wall and the tunes keep the party going. Nice neighborhood so you don't mind leaving late, and not far from the brown line for when you can't drive back home.Make this a Friday night stop to get a chill party started - I do.

2.description: I used to do the wild Hare and Exodus before they got trendy and lost the essence of a good reggae club...good music.  The Roots Room is a hidden gem in the Albany park neighborhood. You don't have to deal with paying for parking, Wrigley Field college students or the drugs and violence that plagues other Chicago clubs. Stann Champion has opened up a intimate spot, where the music, ambiance and crowd is just copasetic and groovy!  Plus you can carry in from Merla's kitchen next door.  Try the Roots Room... you'll love it.

0.description: I go to the Roots Room for a Business networking event. EVERY LAST TUESDAY of the Month.I enjoy the hosts, Tommy Love and Stann Chapman.The Business Card to Business Monthly Meetup is the ideal way to introduce your product, service, or business to new prospective buyers and clients.At our friendly Business Card to Business Networking Group we learn from each other through lively conversation and from select presenters who are subject matter experts.I enjoy meeting other entrepreneurs and getting a chance to build solid long term alliances, joint ventures and relationships.One of the unique aspects of meeting at the Roots Room is the opportunity to use the venue's performance layout to allow each participant to have the spotlight on him or her;  to showcase their business, and project their own personality.Join us every LAST TUESDAY of every month from 6p to 8p.

3.description: The flowers we got from here were beautiful and long lasting! And we couldn't have been happier with the selection or the service. This husband and wife owned flower store really felt warm and inviting! We'll definitely be using them again soon.

1.description: Donna's Garden is the sweetest shop in Sauganash!    The owners always greet you with a smile and a friendly welcome!   They are generous with the amount of flowers in each bouquet and advice on care.   Flowers are beautiful and long lasting!    They have been here for years because they treat their customers like old friends and offer a great variety!

2.description: We order from this shop frequently and are never disappointed! Excellent service and excellent quality!!

0.description: I've been going to Donna's Garden for years. The arrangements have never disappointed and the service is outstanding!When I order, I try my best to convey what I would like. I'm always blown away when I pick up. At Christmas, I had placed an order as a gift for my in-laws. When I entered the store, I saw this absolutely stunning arrangement on their table and commented "who ever is picking that up is lucky... it's gorgeous" and then I was informed that it was mine!... I was most definitely thrilled!Thank you Donna's Garden for beautiful, quality floral arrangements. You guys are the best!

12.description: I have shopped here multiple times. As another reviewer said, it is a bit creepy. I think it was a former grocery store... dingy, spartan.. but really great values! I love this place! quintessential Chicago!

3.description: We stumbled upon Krasny & Co. while trying to locate a cheap brew kettle for homebrewing.  The guy who greeted us was super helpful and knew right away what we were looking for based on the description.  The kettle he showed us was crazy expensive but very high quality.  We decided not to purchase it, but this place definitely can cater to your restaurant supply needs.

1.description: While most people have more traditional New Year's resolutions like losing weight, saving money, volunteering, blah, blah, blah, mine tend be something food-related, like trying a new restaurant every week or learning a new recipe. Those are resolutions I actually look forward to keeping! So this year, I challenged myself to learn to make a new cocktail every week, and with that, I'm also trying to use the proper glassware. I've been searching around for a classic coupe glass ( which also doubles as an old-school champagne glass) that wasn't inappropriately large, but the only ones I found were either way too big or were over $10 apiece. I didn't need anything fancy, just one to serve its purpose. Apparently this is a difficult thing to find. Why does anyone need a cocktail glass that holds 7 oz. of liquor? Three sips in and your drink is too warm. Ah, yes, it's the old "bigger is better" mentality.My hunt led me to Krasny. I'd always been curious about this place but due to its prohibitively inconvenient hours (M-F, 9-5), I could never make it in. I was taking the day off yesterday anyway, so I was finally able to put my curiosity to rest and check it out.Victory was mine! They carried three different sizes of coupe glasses (not to mention any other type of glass you could ever want) as well as other cooking tools, gadgets and assorted restaurant wares. As I feared, I could only purchase the glasses in multiples of a dozen. But at less than $40, I went for it. They're nothing fancy (just regular old Libbey brand), but they're exactly what I needed to start making all those fancy drinks.  And naturally while I was there, I stocked up on other kitchen tools and doodads. This stuff is utilitarian. They're not carrying plates that Alinea serves food on;  It's restaurant- grade, and meant for heavy use. The place itself is bare bones, wonderfully dingy, and retro in that old mom-and-pop-store kind of way. The owner is super helpful and knows everything about what he sells.What a great source. As I expand my cocktail-making repertoire, I will definitely be returning to procure the correct glassware and such.

2.description: I cannot rave about this place enough. They are so helpful every time I come in. They are able to look up my previous orders so they can help me find my products easily. And I just learned today that they do drop offs/deliveries for orders too. I have talked to some of the employees that work there and one guys has been there for 25 years! That says something about a company. I stumbled upon this place one day when I dropped off my dry cleaning next door. Once I stepped in, I knew I would never go to Restaurant Depot again. This was closer to my house and in regards to kitchen and dining room supplies, they have it all. Prices are very competitive too. If you own a restaurant/bar/catering business on the north side of town. Do yourself a favor and check out this place. You will not regret it.

9.description: One of my favorite stores in town. Over the years have hooked up with fabulous deals for DIY wedding reception, equipping new home, hosting house parties, supplies for baking hobby, just everything. I'm a loyal customer.

10.description: Having Thanksgiving at your place this year?  Or maybe just a big birthday bash?If you're frettin' about serving pans, paper plates, plastic glasses, or even toothpicks with the fancy twirls on top, just head over to Krasny & Co., Inc., restaurant and bar suppliers, and one of the fella's will put you right at ease.  With over 6,000 products these guys can literally take you from 'soup to nuts.'The shop is basically a warehouse but the prices are posted (all quite reasonable) and you can purchase both large and small quantities.I've been going to this place for years and many a party has run all the more smoothly thanks to Krasny & Co.

4.description: I agree with the other reviewers who love this place.  Because Krasny sells mainly to businesses that buy in bulk, some items are not available in small quantities for the home cook.  I couldn't buy 10 microwaveable containers--they are only sold by the case.  Still, 5 stars.

6.description: Score!  Nice and cheap cookware only blocks away from my apartment!  Sure this store is no-frills, but it's a treat just to find a restaurant supply company that's open to the public.I was in the pursuit of bread pans and being a loyal follower of the gospel of Alton Brown, I had to seek out a place like this to get a sane price on stuff like this.  They have a myriad of equipment for both front and back of house side of things.  They had nice big containers of your staple spices too that I'm considering trying out next time I run out of something and also the perfect minimalist dish set that unfortunately only caught my eye on the way out.I'll be recommending this place to my fellow amateur chef's in the near future.

0.description: If you've ever been in a bar or restaurant and saw a product they have and thought, "I could sure use that at home," get yourself to Krasny & Co.  This is where bars and restaurants come for everything they need and it is open to the public as well.I used them for a bar upgrade as I needed a dispenser for my demerara (I take my cocktails very seriously).  Other cheap items they had included bar spoons and strainers (which for some reason at places like Crate & Barrel are ridiculously overpriced) and a huge amount of different beer glasses, again for very cheap.It's restaurant grade, so don't come here looking for that wine glass you had at Alinea.  Instead, come here to stock up on the basics at great prices.338/365

5.description: If you're in need of barware, glassware, or pans, you'd do well to make a stop here before dropping hundreds of dollars at Williams Sonoma or Crate & Barrel.  Bars and restaurants shop here, and you should, too.  I was directed to Krasny by the lovely Melani of The Green Lady on Lincoln.  I was looking for tulip glasses for beer, and Melani mentioned that Krasny happened to carry very nice tulip glasses.  Krasny happened to be sold out of the tulip glasses on my initial visit, but the friendly gent working the counter put in an order and promised to hold them for me.  This gave me a chance to browse some of their other items.  Krasny is a great resource for anyone whose kitchen or bar needs a bit of an upgrade.  I picked up a few jiggers, a bar spoon, a cocktail strainger, and an olive oil bottle with a detachable spout, all for very cheap.  The quality of such items won't blow you away,  but at wholesale prices, it's very much worth a look.  Unless your tastes are very high end, you owe yourself a visit here.  Per the owner, 97% of their business goes to bars and restaurants.  However, they're happy to cater to individuals.  The only knock would be on their hours.  It's a 9-5 place (again, they almost solely to bars and restaurants), so you might have to slip away from work to manage a visit here.

13.description: i live near this place for 24 years when i need supplies for a event this is the place to go today i went here to buy some takeout trays  i got a good deal for a stack of 200 this place is AWESOME! i tell everyone i know about Krasny it's the place to go .

11.description: krasny has all of your needs whether you are a restauranteur or a domestic god or goddess. if you are expecting a lot of hand holding, forget about it. you will also have bragging rights when your friends see the industrial strength of your purchases. 1. survey the store shelves before you start asking questions.2. measure your oven before you purchase any pans to make sure they will fit.3. purchase the rolls of parchment to protect your cooking trays etc. the clean up will be a snap.3. be prepared to pay way under retail price and get quality beyond sur le table or williams sonoma. 4. enjoy for years to come, this stuff is made to last!

8.description: Dear friends were getting married. Matthew bakes really well. So, they asked me to bake their wedding cake. Of course I accepted. Then I realized, I didn't have pans big enough to accomplish this grand task... a cake big enough to feed 175 guests! I was pointed to Krasny & Co. by the owner of A Taste of Heaven. I followed the directions they gave me over the phone, and found myself parked behind, what looked like, an abandoned warehouse. I was scared, imagining what it would be like if I was touched inappropriately by a strange, foreign speaking, sweaty, tall, muscular man in the parking lot...right on the hood of my car. What if he touched the side of my face, and I felt strangely compelled to return his lusty emotions - what if he tore my shirt open and carressed my heaving, smooth chest....Oh, wait. I think of that all the time. Nevermind. I went inside.... It was a virtual smorgasbord of baking supplies!! Hurray! Cake pans, cake stands, icing spatulas, and cake decorating tips. They had lots of other fantastic things too, but I was focused on cake baking equipment. Everything in the store is laid out in rows - its hard to get confused. I couldn't find the cake stand I wanted, and they were able to help me quickly. The merchandise is quality restaurant grade stuff. I still have everything I bought. I return when I need to get something on the cheap for a dinner party - or party supplies. Does a restaurant need it? They have it. And the staff was friendly. It still feels a bit Mom & Pop...which I love. I totally suggest checking this place out for all your baking needs...and more!

14.description: Went here to buy a roasting pan for Thanksgiving. They didn't have one big enough. If you want cookie sheets, go for it. It was dingy and kinda creepy. The guy never even acknowledged I was there.

7.description: This place is old school. It's absolutely not a beautiful place. The employees are helpful but not pushy. Everything seemed to be reasonably priced, but I wish they carried eco-friendly options. They have everything from bulk spices and dry goods, to brooms, ketchup bottles, non slip floor mats, specials chalkboards, aprons, pots and pans, utensils... AHHH! I could go on for days. The selection was good.I will be back though, and soon!

12.description: My husband and I attended Krunch's BBQ wine tasting this last weekend and found both the class and the wines to be great!! I purchased a Groupon and the class was only $40 for 2 people so I was a bit skeptical as to how good the class and the wines would be for that dollar amount.  We have gone to many wine events from different venues (Webster Wine Bar, Randolf Wine cellars, Bin 36, corporate sponsored tastings, etc) and this was much more fun, as educational as the others, and had better value.We were pleasantly surprised at the quality of this event.  In addition, we had great BBQ food (different types of kebobs & salad), and homemade cheese cake which was delicious and perfectly paired with the bold red wine he had served.  If we wanted more wine of any of the 5 wine selection we tasted, Krunch left bottles in the front so we could pour more into our wine glasses.  When he ran out of a particular wine selection (after the tasting), he even opened up wine from his cellar to share with the class.  Some of the wines tasted are NOT the typical wines you find everywhere. He had wines that had limited distribution in Chicago.   We tasted and learned about wines we would never have known about otherwise.  His class does sell out fast but it is worth it if you can get in one. It is just very popular.  I tried for a couple months and was sort of giving up hope of every getting into a class.  Just be patient. Once you take a class you will realize why his classes sell out fast.  But he is very accommodating and tries to make sure you can get into a class. Overall great experience and will definately go back to one of his events again.

7.description: The reviews that give Krunch 1-star are unfair.  His wine tasting was a lot of fun.  He made it clear from the outset that his goal was to expose us to different tastes, not teach us to pair.Our tasting had three types of wine and a surprisingly delicious ratatouille with goat cheese that paired especially well with one of the red blends.  The surprise was that ratatouille is French (as were the wines), but the class was held in a German culture center called the Dank House.  The name is hilarious; the food, delicious.Krunch himself is a character.  Apparently he is the dark lord of Somalians or something, which I guess means he knows a lot about wine.  My retention isn't abnormally high when drinking wine, so actually I appreciated that he spared us the chemical breakdown of the fermentation process and kept his stories simple, entertaining, and funny.We went to this class with one of the Groupon (or similar) deals, so it came to about $17 per person, which was well worth it.  I gave him three stars because I would have liked to try a few more wines, and I would have liked to have the opportunity to buy wine from him at the end.My girlfriend and I had a really great night and met some funny people in the process.  Thanks, Krunch!

3.description: I had the same problem as one of the other reviews on here.  I bought  a Living Social coupon for a class and have not been able to schedule anything since.  The classes immediately "sold out" or got cancelled.  I've spoken  to the guy on the phone personally, and he was a major a**hole.  Said he would put me on a list of people to call when a class opened up then never called.I've been trying to get into a class for months and am convinced that no such class actually exists.  He's just stringing me on.  I have since contacted Living Social to complain and maybe get a refund, but they have not replied after two weeks.  Stay away from this guy and anything he's involved in.Too bad zero stars is not an option.

1.description: I bought a Groupon and registered for a class.  On the day of the class I rechecked the website to see if anything further was posted because I still had not seen the address where the class was being held.  I emailed Krunch asking if he could please pass the address along.  He called me letting me know that he had emailed out a few weeks prior an email asking to send in the voucher number and confirm your seat.  I never received the email nor a courtesy call to confirm that I was attending, he just gave my seat away.  I'm very unhappy with the customer service and like everyone else - it's very hard to even schedule a class as they are always "sold out."  I'm extremely frustrated and would not recommend anyone buy this in the future.  Also, I recommend as soon as you sign up, email him your voucher number and confirm that you are attending the class.  He doesn't have that written anywhere, but otherwise he may give away your seat.

2.description: I think Krunch claims to be a master sommelier confrerie, see en.wikipedia.or....  There's no membership list, so who knows.  I was annoyed that it was tough to register and that it was impossible to find out WHERE to go on game day. Seriously? People who work downtown have trouble getting to the northside at 6 pm during a work week.  Also, there was no food pairing lesson.  The majority of the class was guessing what wine was which grape.  I was annoyed that one of them was a BLEND.  Really? Who the heck can tell what grapes are in a blend, especially for beginners.  It wasn't a total rip off, but I'm not sure this guy is who he claims to be.UPDATE: My bad, I was wrong--Krunch claims to have the "International Grand Confrerie Sommelier" distinction (and not the other one I listed in my original review), for which a membership list is also not available.To settle all of this, I will gladly remove my 1-star rating if Krunch (1) stops sending me rude emails, and (2) successfully joins the Harvard Business School Alumni group on LinkedIn, to (partly) legitimize his claim that he has a PhD in Economics from Harvard. Although there's no way to prove whether Krunch does/doesn't carry the International Grand Confrerie Sommelier distinction, we can find out about the Harvard affiliation with some certainty.

9.description: SCAM SCAM SCAM!  Thief!  This is a scam! You cannot sign up for his wine and dinner pairings. If you purchased a dinner and wine package through amazon you are in for a rude awakening. The voucher will NOT work on his website.  He will NOT email you the address to the restaurant (he says customers will bother the restaurant owners prior to the event) he will NOT answer your emails or your phone calls.  I have been on the phone with amazon three times and have documented all of my contacts with amazon and "Bottled Grapes" The owner is not responding to emails or phone calls!  HORRIBLE! DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY! Do not try to contact me now, Mr. Krunch Kretschmar, my dinner was supposed to be this evening, but you never contacted the FOUR of us that purchased vouchers for your class!  I don't really care how you reply to this comment either, because if I had done my homework on Yelp, I would have seen that you have a ton of unhappy customers.  I will be contacting the Better Business Bureau next. THIEF!  You should not run a voucher program if you cannot provide BASIC customer service and provide the wine and dinner pairing you advertised.

18.description: I love Wine!!!!  I've attended several classes and am making an effort to go every month.  The information isn't dull and just the right pace.  It's a great evening out!  As soon as the email blasts come out, I make my plans with my group.

10.description: One of my favorite events this year....I can't wait to schedule again!  I had some difficulty coordinating a huge group of my (indecisive) friends to sign up for his classes together before too many spaces were filled....so Krunch was kind enough to make special arrangements to hold a class for my group exclusively!  He paired with a chef for the event, and the 2 of them planned everything perfectly!  The night included some light wine education, appropriate food pairing, cooking demo, and tasting.  They arraned it all according to the theme/region I requested.  They followed my specifications, then they took over the remaining details themselves.  What a fantastic night with 15 of my friends!  Krunch also brough along a tasting of his decadent chocolates from Beijo de Chocolat! (AMAZING!!)I would recommend organizing with crunch for a night with the girls (bridal shower event, bachelorette party event, birthday, etc) OR a great "couples" night!

13.description: My friends and I purchased Groupons and asked for a refund.  4000 Groupons were sold and we have been unable to get in a "class" because none are being scheduled, or there are so few that they are sold out immediately.Based on the orange cheese and Ritz cracker review, I'm glad we couldn't get in!

16.description: I am willing to give more stars if I could ever get into a wine tasting.  I have to agree with the reviewer who has been unable to get into a class.  I too was suppose to go to the Nov. class - the only one NOT full - but found out it was canceled when I emailed bottle grape to find out the location.  I was told there would be class in Dec. and i could register for that.  How much time should I have to spend on line to go to a bottle grape wine pairing?  I should have been put into the Dec. class automatically and given the option to withdraw if the date was not good.  After reading other reviews I don't know if it worth the effort to use my groupon or just accept I will loose the money - unless Bottled grape" will reimburse me - that would be a reasonable request. and my real name is Joan.

17.description: My husband and I attended an Italian wine class last night.  Krunch took time to explain so many details about wine tasting and pairing and even some history, that we had no clue about!  The food was awesome (we want that recipe!) and the venue was neat.  We were glad we went and would definitely do this again.  It was a good time meeting people and chatting as we ate and drank.  Thanks Krunch!

15.description: I love taking the wine classes and have attended several over the past year or so. Krunch makes wine so accessible and I learn so much every class. My favorite so far was the wine and barbecuing class. Who knew that wine tasted so good with hot dogs and potato salad!Unfortunately, I work out in Lombard so the trek into the city can be a bit daunting at times.

0.description: I attended Krunch's class last week with a friend.  We took a class on "Spanish Reds."Not only was the class educational, we had a lot of fun and met new friends.  This wine class offered more than just the regular taste and allowed us to pour our own drinks and share bottles around the class.  We tried four wines in the class and were able to understand their paring with and without food.  The class was great, but the venue was also really cool - held at a new business opening this spring Borelli's up on Lawrence Ave.

5.description: I went with the Living Social deal to one of the French wine and food pairings. Overall, I was just not that impressed but also didn't think it was as terrible as a lot of the reviews made it seem.I appreciated how Krunch explained everything and seemed really passionate about wines. I liked getting to taste the different wines and also that we were allowed to keep drinking the leftovers. We also met some nice people. What bothered me the most was that I expected actual food - instead, there was one dish (ratatouille) for all 3 wine pairings, but there wasn't even enough of it provided to feel satisfied or like I actually tried French foods. I assumed that a wine and food pairing from 7pm-9pm would include something more substantial. Also, I would've liked a smaller group of people because this was huge. If I had paid more for it, I would have felt kinda ripped off, but it was fine for what it was. If you want a casual wine and food tasting, go for it!

11.description: We attended a class which was supposed to focus on Italy's Friuli-Venezia Guila region.  The advertisement claims,"In this class, we'll explore the wines of the region and enjoy a multi-course meal typical to the region"Our multi-course meal included cheap cheese and grapes, and then spaghetti alfredo.  Neither of which were really authentic Italian let alone specific to the region.  Two of the wines were from Sicily -- not the supposed region we were learning about.  He gave no information about the region or even what makes Italian wines unique.

8.description: I bought the Groupon and was never able to use it because the vendor never updates his website. Non-responsive and unprofessional.

4.description: This guy can't possibly be for real.  I can't find a single source that will validate the International Grand Confrerie Sommelier title, his coursework at HBS, or his wrestling career at Florida State.That aside, the class was just odd.  Our food/wine pairing consisted of cheap store bought pasta served on paper plates accompanied by four wine selections. For an app, he served us orange and yellow cheese w/ Ritz crackers.He answered some questions and mostly talked about himself and his "credentials".This from a fancy pants titled International Grand Confrerie supposedly well versed in fine food and wine?  I'm no sommelier, but even I wouldn't serve orange cheese and Ritz crackers to guests.Odd.  Just.  Odd.

14.description: I purchased a Living Social deal back in March, and we just attended a class last night. It was fantastic!  I was seeing a lot of Spain/Portugal/France classes, and since we had a trip planned to Napa in July I had emailed Krunch asking him to host a CA class.  Which he did and we loved it.I agree, that the classes do fill up quickly, but he had told us earlier this summer that he would be posting/hosting a lot more classes this fall, which seems to be the case.  There seem to be a lot more offered now than there were earlier this summer.I think some of the other reviewers need to take it for one it is...you can't expect a stuffy/fancy black tie wine event here, this is a very personal/intimate evening, where Krunch invites you to his home (we had perfect weather, so it was fantastic to be sitting outside!).  While my boyfriend and I love wine, and drink it often, we are NOT fancy wine drinkers, and don't want to be. We just want to enjoy what we drink, and learn a little more about it as we go.  Krunch's class never made us feel like we weren't educated enough, or even should be...he was just there to share what he knew.We will definitely be going back, I think it would be fun to get a group of friends and make a night of it!

6.description: I attended one of Krunch's classes in May with a gal-pal at the Foster location (delicious chocolates and other sweet treats!) and another class and Krunch's house (hosted a BBQ) with my cousin.  Both were fun and relaxing.  At one point, Krunch ran out of wine and was kind enough to open some bottles from his secret stash!  Sure, there was not a full-on menu' but this was a class, not a dinner pairing.  I have participated in a plethora of wine tastings and I learned the most informational and fun facts at these two classes.  I never had a problem reserving two spots for each class and Krunch responded almost immediately to a question I had.I think this is a great way to be introduced to the wine world, thanks to Krunch and his girlfriend's laid back approach to presenting the information.

29.description: Dissapointed one too many times.  We ate one egg roll and tossed the left overs.  Unpredictable perhaps they have different cooks.  We'll be moving on to another Chinese Restaurant.  So long Hunan Wok.

42.description: Probably the BEST restaurant in the Northeastern Illinois area. Super cheap Chinese food, and not only cheap but some tasty stuff! Beats the crap out of all the stuff in the nearby area, and for under $6 for the lunch time buffet, it wins hands down in value. The staff here is amazing, the lady who always takes care of us is always super friendly, fast and genuinely happy to see regulars. The buffet, though not huge, is awesome. Their chicken wings rock, awesome crab Rangoon, and they even have those homemade donuts that all Chinese restaurants have. So yeah, if you're ever hanking for cheap eats on Bryn Mawr Avenue, definitely check out Hunan Wok.

23.description: The OLD OWNER is back!!!!! I was so excited when I ordered general tso's chicken last night and found out that the juiciness and the tenderness of the chicken has finally returned! The couple of times that I ordered from them after the old owner left was undeniably less tasty and was disappointing to say the least. But now, I'm so relieved to have discovered that they are back! I missed that friendly lady at the counter and their tasty food. Best Chinese food I've ever had, gotta try the chicken!

47.description: relatively fresh ingredients and not super greasy, but nothing too special. nice and cheap though when that matters, and the staff is really friendly. also it looks as if they haven't updated the decor since about 1971, which is just fine in my book.

8.description: I've lived in the North Park neighborhood for 19 years and feel lucky indeed to be able to walk around the corner to pick up scrumptious meals from Hunan Wok. Their steamed, healthy dishes are my fave, such as the tofu with mushroom and broccoli. It never takes more than 15 minutes for an order--usually 10 minutes. Love this place!

31.description: This is our FAVORITE chinese!  Everything is good. Love that they use white breast meat for chicken dishes. Try the sesame chicken house special.  Tried other restaurants and this is the best around here.

34.description: Hunan Wok is our favorite local delivery place and I love the buffet especially for the price and immediacy.  Can't always wait for lunch and not going to do drive through.   Fresh ingredients, nice chicken - I like the white well trimed chicken they use.  We have ordered from them for years, and have never had a delivery problem, always under 45 minutes, and never cold.   Egg rolls  and hot & sour soup are very good - which is my litmus test.  Really, try the buffet for lunch, simple, inexpensive and they are nice.

16.description: Stopped in for takeout, got crab rangoon and spicy orange chicken. The crab rangoon never made it home-absolutely awesome! The orange chicken did not disappoint; everything tasted fresh and I will definitely be coming back for more.

13.description: Ordered from here over the weekend. We ordered sesame chicken, orange chicken, and a third type of chicken which I do not recall. So, our food arrived and literally all the chicken we ordered was the exact same thing. Just chicken and broccoli, but the sauce was just a little different for each. Very disappointing and boring. The crab Rangoon was average and the dumplings seemed to me as if they weren't cooked to the end. Not ordering from here again.

11.description: Hunan Wok is a classic, delicious Chinese restaurant. Stopped in today for a quick lunch and had the broccoli with garlic sauce. Came with pork fried rice and an absolutely delicious bowl of hot and sour soup. Great deal, too: only $5.75! Maria, the owner, is a great hostess and very friendly and welcoming to all of her patrons. I will be back!
